column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Construction (see also piling and pipelines)
column4: Habitat structure changes - removal of substratum (extraction)
column5: Oil and gas drilling will cut through the seafloor to a reservoir beneath. Any open rock formations are sealed with cement plugs to prevent upward migration of wellbore fluids [3111]. Drilling wastes are a major component of the total waste streams from offshore exploration and production, with typically around 1,000 tonnes of cuttings resulting from an exploration or development well. Water-based mud cuttings are discharged at, or relatively close to sea surface during “closed drilling” (i.e. when steel casing and a riser is in place), whereas surface hole cuttings will be discharged at seabed during “open-hole” drilling. Use of oil based mud systems, for example in highly deviated sections or in water reactive shale sections, would require the onshore disposal or reinjection of the waste material. This pressure may also be caused by dredging/sea-bed preparation during the construction phase of structures and pipelines [JNCC0299; JNCC0300; JNCC0304].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Construction (see also piling and pipelines)
column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5:
Throughout the drilling process, drilling fluid known as ‘drilling muds’ is used in drilling engineering. Water-based drilling muds are comprised of a selection of (non-toxic) chemicals, seawater and weighting agents (which are commonly finely ground dense minerals such as barite or ilmenite). 
The past, discharge to sea of drill cuttings contaminated with oil based drill mud resulted in well documented acute and chronic effects at the seabed. These effects resulted from the interplay of a variety of factors of which direct toxicity (when diesel based muds were used) or secondary toxicity as a consequence of organic enrichment (from hydrogen sulphide produced by bacteria under anaerobic conditions) were probably the most important. However, the use of the discharge of oil based material in the marine environment is banned under European legislation [JNCC0299; JNCC0300; JNCC0305].
This pressure also relates to vessels associated with this activity and their movement. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) [4985]. Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). At least 23 confirmed discharges were attributed to vessel casualties including 13 pleasure craft and workboats, 8 fishing vessels, a general cargo vessel and a tug.  The largest vessel-casualty spill was seven tonnes and was due to a cargo vessel. Vessel casualties accounted for 54% of all confirmed discharges attributed to pleasure craft and workboats [4968; 4915].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Construction (see also piling and pipelines)
column5: Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures (such as jack-up platforms) involved in oil and gas construction may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083; 3088; 3195; 2797; 3107; 4334; 4339; JNCC302; JNCC0299; JNCC0301]. An assessment of the scale of impact of lighting from offshore oil structures in United Kingdom waters concluded that under certain weather conditions large numbers of birds can occasionally be attracted to offshore platforms. However, relatively few species were attracted in sizable numbers and those that were had large and stable breeding populations thus indicating that no significant environmental impact was occurring [5004]. Lighting can also occur as result of underwater activities such as ROVs [JNCC0314].

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Construction (see also piling and pipelines)
column4: Introduction of other substances (solid, liquid or gas)
column5:
Throughout the drilling process, drilling fluid known as ‘drilling muds’ is used in drilling engineering. Water-based drilling muds are comprised of a selection of (non-toxic) chemicals, seawater and weighting agents (which are commonly finely ground dense minerals such as barite or ilmenite). 
In the past, discharge to sea of drill cuttings contaminated with oil based drill mud resulted in well documented acute and chronic effects at the seabed. These effects resulted from the interplay of a variety of factors of which direct toxicity (when diesel based muds were used) or secondary toxicity as a consequence of organic enrichment (from hydrogen sulphide produced by bacteria under anaerobic conditions) were probably the most important. However, the use of the discharge of oil based material in the marine environment is banned under European legislation [JNCC0299; JNCC0300; JNCC0305].
This pressure also relates to vessels associated with this activity and their movement. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) [4985]. Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). At least 23 confirmed discharges were attributed to vessel casualties including 13 pleasure craft and workboats, 8 fishing vessels, a general cargo vessel and a tug.  The largest vessel-casualty spill was seven tonnes and was due to a cargo vessel. Vessel casualties accounted for 54% of all confirmed discharges attributed to pleasure craft and workboats [4968; 4915].

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Construction (see also piling and pipelines)
column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5:
Offshore oil and gas platforms have the potential to facilitate species range expansions and/or the introduction of non-native species into new geographic areas by serving as ‘stepping stones’ of vertical relief and hard substrate habitat across a soft seabed environments. Offshore oil and gas platforms are among the largest artificial structures in the marine environment [JNCC0303].
Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur. All vessels have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978; 5177]. 
Marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164]. There is concern that the expansion of non-indigenous species could alter local biodiversity and sometimes compete with native species, some of which are of commercial interest. This is especially the case in shallow coastal waters, subject to a multitude of human activities, including the construction of artificial hard substrata. The oil and gas industry provides direct and indirect pathways for alien invasive species, through vessel movements and structures [5000].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text). The risk of introducing new species may also increase with the range of vessel/boat activity – e.g. travelling from locations outside the UK.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Construction (see also piling and pipelines)
column5: Marine litter can be released into the marine environment by vessels including those involved in oil and gas infrastructure construction [4974; 3160]. Vessel and shipping related litter contributes approximately 2 % of the litter found on UK beaches. Shipping related litter contributed approximately 45 litter items per kilometre around the UK on average between 2003 and 2007 [4915; 3160].

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Construction (see also piling and pipelines)
column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5:
Jack-up drilling rigs are normally used in shallower water depths (usually at depths less than 100 m). The majority of these rigs have three or four legs, with each leg terminating in a spudcan of up to 20m diameter. Seabed disturbance associated with jack-up rigs is considered likely within a radius of 500m (taking into account of any additional rig stabilisation (rock dump) footprint. In deeper waters, semi-submersible rigs may be used. These typically use between 8 and 12 anchors to hold position, the radius of which depends on the water depth, seabed conditions and anticipated metocean conditions.  The depth of sediment over-turned by anchor-scarring would be of the order of several metres and exposed sediments are likely to be similar to existing surficial sediments [JNCC0299; JNCC0300].
Some offshore structures consist of a tubular framework (or jacket). Piles driven into the seafloor secure the jacket. Driving of piles for these structures will cause localised physical disturbance around the piles. 
The surface hole sections of exploration wells are typically drilled riserless, producing a localised (and transient) pile of surface-hole cuttings around the surface conductor. The persistence of cuttings discharged at the seabed is largely determined by the potential for it to be redistributed by tidal and other currents. After installation of the surface casing, the blowout preventer (BOP) is positioned on the wellhead housing. These operations (and associated activities such as ROV operations) may result in physical disturbance of the immediate vicinity (a few metres) of the wellhead [JNCC0299; JNCC0300].
The laying of pipelines, umbilicals and cables associated with the oil and gas industry can also cause localised physical disturbance. The footprint of disturbance is dependent on whether it is buried or not and the hydrology and sediment dynamics in the locality [JNCC0299].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Construction (see also piling and pipelines)
column5: Physical change in seabed type will occur due to placement of structures on the seabed such as spud cans, platform legs, gravity bases, rock dump to stabilise jack up rigs and during cementing operations. Scour protection in the form of gravel, rocks, sandbags, gabions, pre-formed concrete blocks or frond mats is routinely used for subsea structures and for pipelines to prevent free-spanning [3122; 3127; 3083; 3125; JNCC0299]. Piles can change the seabed type within the footprint of the piling works from soft sediment to an artificial substratum (typically steel) [4898; 4908; 4890; 4892]. Drill cutting waste consists of crushed rock cuttings from the borehole and remnants of drill mud. Drill cuttings have accumulated beneath drilling installations, particularly in the central and northern areas of the North Sea  due to the deep water and weak currents in this area[4915]. Field studies have shown that, for the majority of North Sea installations, biological communities are largely unaffected beyond a 500-m radius and that the area impacted by contaminated cuttings is reducing [JNCC0245; 4915; JNCC0336].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Construction (see also piling and pipelines)
column5: Pile and drill cuttings have accumulated beneath drilling installations in the central and northern areas of the North Sea, in the UK and Norwegian sectors due to the deep water and weak currents; there are none in the southern North Sea, where there are stronger ocean currents and wave action [4915]). Field studies have shown that, for the majority of North Sea installations, biological communities are largely unaffected beyond a 500-m radius and that the area impacted by contaminated cuttings is reducing [JNCC0245; 4915; JNCC0336].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Construction (see also piling and pipelines)
column5: Radioactive sources are used for logging formation parameters.  It has been calculated that 7.4 Tbq of alpha activity and 4.9 Tbq of beta activity were discharged in 2007 [JNCC0269; JNCC0267].

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Construction (see also piling and pipelines)
column5: Water-based mud cuttings are typically discharged at, or relatively close to the sea surface during closed drilling (i.e. when steel casing in the well bore and a riser to the rig are in place), whereas surface hole cuttings are normally discharged at seabed during open-hole drilling. In contrast to historic oil based mud discharges, potential smothering effects due to the discharge of cuttings drilled with water based muds (WBM) are usually subtle or undetectable, although the presence of drilling material at the seabed is often detectable close to the drilling location (<500m). Modelling of WBM cutting discharges has indicated that deposition of material is generally thin and quickly reduces away from the well. However, the discharge of drill cuttings and water-based fluids may cause some smothering in the direct near vicinity of the well location. Localised siltation can also occur as a result of the remobilisation (and subsequent deposition) of sediment on the seabed due to the placement of structures (such as drilling rigs, jack-up platforms, spudcans, gravity bases and pipelines) and any dredging required during construction  [JNCC0299; JNCC0300; JNCC0305; 5004].

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Construction (see also piling and pipelines)
column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Transition elements and organo-metals are used as marine anti-fouling agents on vessels. Historically the main ingredients in biocidal antifouling coatings have been copper or tributyltin (TBT). TBT has been banned on vessels under 25m in the UK since 1987. Since then biocides commonly used in the UK in antifoulants include Copper(I) oxide (cuprous oxide), Copper thiocyanate, Zinc pyrithione and ZineB (organosulfur compound) [JNCC0204; JNCC0326].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Construction (see also piling and pipelines)
column5:
Available measurements indicate that drilling activities produce mainly low-frequency continuous noise from several separate sources on the drilling unit. The primary sources of noise are various types of rotating machinery but the overall acoustic output depends on the type of operation. When drilling from semi-submersible rigs, noise is transmitted from the rig to the water column through submerged parts of the drilling unit hull, risers and mooring cables. If position is maintained by dynamic positioning, noise from thrusters may dominate the lower frequency band. Noise transmission from jack-up drilling units used in shallower water is less because of reduced surface area contact between the water column and submerged parts of the rig. Sound pressure levels  in the range of approximately 120dB re 1µPa in the frequency range 2-1400Hz is considered typical of drilling from a jack-up rig. Drilling duration may range from a few weeks for an exploration well, to several years in the case of a large development programme [JNCC0299; JNCC0304; 5004].
The overall source levels resulting from pipe laying operations are not typically measured. Noise levels are likely be dominated by the vessel noise associated with the installation. A pipeline installation which includes trenching and backfilling activities, is likely to be comparable to dredging activities [JNCC0299; JNCC0304; 5004].
Most vessels involved in the oil and gas industry are medium-size ships (50-100m length) which produce broadband source levels within the 165-180 dB re 1 µPa range and although there is considerable variability in associated frequency spectra, they tend to be similar to large vessels with dominant frequency below 1kHz) [JNCC0299]. 
Piling is required to fix subsea structures into the seabed such as manifolds and platform legs. The size of piles required are dependent upon a number of factors including the size of the structure to be installed and seabed conditions. Available source levels range from 210 dB (0-peak) re 1µPa @1m (for a 0.75 m pile) to 257 dB (0-peak) re 1µPa @1m (for a 4.2 m pile). 
Dredging is required to remove or alter areas of the seabed that are not optimal for infrastructure installation, for example, it may be necessary to remove large sand waves and flatten the seabed prior to pipelay activities [JNCC0304].
Explosives are typical used in oil and gas decommissioning rather than construction and are therefore not considered further as part of this activity [JNCC0304].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Construction (see also piling and pipelines)
column5: Vibration (particle motion) will be caused a range of activities in the construction of oil and gas infrastructure including drilling, piling and vessel movements. However, information of vibration levels for different activities is limited [JNCC0299; JNCC0304; 5004].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Construction (see also piling and pipelines)
column5: Vessels, machinery and people movement during oil and gas infrastructure construction can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as marine mammals and seabirds [5106; 5117; JNCC0299]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. The risk increases if bird species are especially sensitive eg red throated diver.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column5: Noise can arise from a range of activities during oil and gas operation and maintenance. Sources of airborne noise includes vessels, helicopters and noise emissions from production platforms (such as turbines, generators, compressors and drilling machinery) [3111; 3149; JNCC0299].  Above water noise may also come from cutting and lifting operations [4387; 1329; 3082]. However, the magnitude of pressure would depend on the scale, intensity and duration of the activity.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5:
Scour can occur around oil and gas infrastructure placed on the seabed such as piles, platform legs, cables, pipelines and gravity bases. For example, gas platform jacket leg scour of depths of 1.5 to 3.5m was recorded in the southern North Sea. In some cases, individual scour pits coalescing to form a depression (referred to as “ global scour”) can occur over a much bigger area, of the same order as the area of the structure supported by the piles [JNCC0299].
Vessel anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying the anchor and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery. Mooring chains from swinging moorings may scour the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide. The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials. For example, for an 11.5 tonne anchor penetration of up to 0.88 m occurred in soft sediment when the anchor was dropped and dragged 87 m [4971]. There is a tendency for the anchor to penetrate to deep depths in softer sediment as the opening of the anchor flukes prevents deep penetration in harder sediment [5076]. Typical maximum water depths for anchoring are between 100 m and 150 m.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column5: Infrastructure (such as jack-up rigs and semi-submersible rigs) only cover a localised area which constitutes a small fraction of the range of mobile species potentially sensitive to physical barriers. Such structures are therefore considered highly unlikely to block movements or migratory pathways to areas of critical habitat.  Noise associated with oil and gas operation and maintenance is considered unlikely to cause any barrier effects. However, oil and gas platforms are generally located offshore and away from confined waterbodies such as estuaries in which the risk of barrier impacts are considered greatest [JNCC0300].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column5: Scouring around oil and gas industry structures such as jack-up drilling rig legs, semi-submersible rigs, anchors, anchor chains, gravity base and jacket structures has the potential to cause localised and temporary increases in suspended sediment concentrations. Drilling can also increase suspended sediments though the discharge and subsequent dispersion of drill cuttings. Dispersion of mud and cuttings is influenced by various factors, including particle size distribution and density, vertical and horizontal turbulence, current flows and water depth. In deep water, the range of cuttings particle size results in a significant variation in settling velocity, and a consequent gradient in the size distribution of settled cuttings, with coarser material close to the discharge location and finer material very widely dispersed away from the location, generally at undetectable loading [JNCC0299; JNCC0300; JNCC0305]. The dragging of anchors and scouring caused by moorings can cause localised and temporary increases in suspended sediments [3223].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Bird collisions with vessels and oil and gas platforms can occur. These are documented to be higher at night on lighted structures near coastal areas. These are also more frequent under poor visibility [4337]. Mortality can occur directly with oil and gas infrastructure or through overexposure to heat from or incineration in flare stacks [JNCC0301]. Population level effects of direct platform mortality may be region and species specific depending on the numbers of platforms in operation and the species that encounter them during migration. For example, at a research platform in the North Sea a total of 442 birds of 21 species were found dead (the platform has no rotating turbine blades, but has a metmast and navigation lights) between October 2003 and December 2004. Over half of the strikes occurred on just two nights characterised by periods of very poor visibility with mist or drizzle and presumably increased attraction of the illuminated research platform [JNCC0301]. Some estimates of total annual bird mortality at oil and gas platforms in the North Sea are as high as 6,000,000 birds [JNCC0302].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: This pressure relates to the use of a vessel. Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120; 4987; JNCC0300]. Collision with underwater infrastructure associated with the oil and gas industry is considered unlikely given the lack of exposed rotating (or rapidly moving) underwater machinery. However, a lack of information exists regarding collision risk of animals (e.g. birds, fish, marine mammals) with underwater structures, especially for birds. The response of birds will depend on their detection of a device and any associated structures. The risk of collision may be increased if the devices alter the characteristics of the current, especially if such changes create new foraging opportunities, since this may impact on the manoeuvrability and underwater swimming agility of birds [4959; 5075]. Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column5: Electromagnetic fields (EMFs) are generated when electricity is transported through a cable. An industry standard AC offshore cable produces a magnetic (B) field component and an induced electric (iE) field component in the marine environment. Although submarine power cables are fully electrically insulated, it is the fluctuating magnetic field which induces the electric field in the environment. An electric field is also generated by the movement of water or objects (e.g. an animal) through the magnetic field in the same way that movements through the natural (geomagnetic) field of the earth induce an electric field [JNCC0299]. A number of marine taxa are potentially capable of responding to anthropogenic sources of electric and magnetic fields. The oil and gas industry  has a small number of high voltage electricity cables that supply power to oil and gas platforms [JNCC0296].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column4: Habitat structure changes - removal of substratum (extraction)
column5: Oil and gas drilling will cut through the seafloor to a reservoir beneath. Any open rock formations are sealed with cement plugs to prevent upward migration of wellbore fluids [3111]. Drilling wastes are a major component of the total waste streams from offshore exploration and production, with typically around 1,000 tonnes of cuttings resulting from an exploration or development well. Water-based mud cuttings are discharged at, or relatively close to sea surface during “closed drilling” (i.e. when steel casing and a riser is in place), whereas surface hole cuttings will be discharged at seabed during “open-hole” drilling. Use of oil based mud systems, for example in highly deviated sections or in water reactive shale sections, would require the onshore disposal or reinjection of the waste material. This pressure may also be caused by dredging/sea-bed preparation during the maintenance phase of structures and pipelines [JNCC0299; JNCC0300; JNCC0304].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5:
Formation water brought up with the hydrocarbons (known as Produced Water) is a source of potential contamination in the marine environment. The composition and characteristics of naturally-occurring chemical substances in Produced Water are closely coupled to the geological characteristics of each reservoir. It may sometimes also contain injection water and condensation water. The composition of Produced Water is complex and can comprise several thousand compounds that vary in concentration between wells and over the lifetime of a well. Compounds of concern in Produced Water include dispersed oil, aromatic hydrocarbons and alkylphenol [JNCC0299; JNCC0336].
Most studies of produced water toxicity and dispersion, in the UK and elsewhere) have concluded that the necessary dilution to achieve a No Effect Concentration (NEC) would be reached at <10 to 100m and usually less than 500m from the discharge point. However, it is not expected that significant discharges of produced water will be made from new hydrocarbon developments, since there is a regulatory preference for reinjection to a suitable subsurface formation [JNCC0299; JNCC0336].
Throughout the drilling process, drilling fluid known as ‘drilling muds’ is used in drilling engineering. Water-based drilling muds are comprised of a selection of (non-toxic) chemicals, seawater and weighting agents (which are commonly finely ground dense minerals such as barite or ilmenite). 
The past, discharge to sea of drill cuttings contaminated with oil based drill mud resulted in well documented acute and chronic effects at the seabed. These effects resulted from the interplay of a variety of factors of which direct toxicity (when diesel based muds were used) or secondary toxicity as a consequence of organic enrichment (from hydrogen sulphide produced by bacteria under anaerobic conditions) were probably the most important. However, the use of the discharge of oil based material in the marine environment is banned under European legislation [JNCC0299; JNCC0300; JNCC0305].
This pressure also relates to vessels associated with this activity and their movement. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) [4985]. Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). At least 23 confirmed discharges were attributed to vessel casualties including 13 pleasure craft and workboats, 8 fishing vessels, a general cargo vessel and a tug.  The largest vessel-casualty spill was seven tonnes and was due to a cargo vessel. Vessel casualties accounted for 54% of all confirmed discharges attributed to pleasure craft and workboats [4968; 4915].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column5: Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures (such as jack-up platforms) involved in oil and gas construction may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083; 3088; 3195; 2797; 3107; 4334; 4339; JNCC0302; JNCC0299; JNCC0301]. An assessment of the scale of impact of lighting from offshore oil structures in United Kingdom waters concluded that under certain weather conditions large numbers of birds can occasionally be attracted to offshore platforms. However, relatively few species were attracted in sizable numbers and those that were had large and stable breeding populations thus indicating that no significant environmental impact was occurring [5004]. Lighting can also occur as result of underwater activities such as ROVs [JNCC0314].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column4: Introduction of other substances (solid, liquid or gas)
column5:
Formation water brought up with the hydrocarbons (known as Produced Water) is a source of potential contamination in the marine environment. The composition and characteristics of naturally-occurring chemical substances in Produced Water are closely coupled to the geological characteristics of each reservoir. It may sometimes also contain injection water and condensation water. The composition of Produced Water is complex and can comprise several thousand compounds that vary in concentration between wells and over the lifetime of a well. Compounds of concern in Produced Water include dispersed oil, aromatic hydrocarbons and alkylphenol and heavy metals [JNCC0299; JNCC0336].
Most studies of produced water toxicity and dispersion, in the UK and elsewhere) have concluded that the necessary dilution to achieve a No Effect Concentration (NEC) would be reached at <10 to 100m and usually less than 500m from the discharge point. However, it is not expected that significant discharges of produced water will be made from new hydrocarbon developments, since there is a regulatory preference for reinjection to a suitable subsurface formation [JNCC0299; JNCC0336].
Throughout the drilling process, drilling fluid known as ‘drilling muds’ is used in drilling engineering. Water-based drilling muds are comprised of a selection of (non-toxic) chemicals, seawater and weighting agents (which are commonly finely ground dense minerals such as barite or ilmenite). 
The past, discharge to sea of drill cuttings contaminated with oil based drill mud resulted in well documented acute and chronic effects at the seabed. However, the use of the discharge of oil based material in the marine environment is banned under European legislation [JNCC0299; JNCC0300; JNCC0305].
This pressure also relates to vessels associated with this activity and their movement. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) [4985]. Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers) [4968; 4915].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5:
Offshore oil and gas platforms have the potential to facilitate species range expansions and/or the introduction of non-native species into new geographic areas by serving as ‘stepping stones’ of vertical relief and hard substrate habitat across a soft seabed environments. Offshore oil and gas platforms are among the largest artificial structures in the marine environment [JNCC0303].
Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur. All vessels have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978; 5177]. 
Marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164]. There is concern that the expansion of non-indigenous species could alter local biodiversity and sometimes compete with native species, some of which are of commercial interest. This is especially the case in shallow coastal waters, subject to a multitude of human activities, including the construction of artificial hard substrata. The oil and gas industry provides direct and indirect pathways for alien invasive species, through vessel movements and structures [5000].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text). The risk of introducing new species may also increase with the range of vessel/boat activity – e.g. travelling from locations outside the UK.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column5: Marine litter can be released into the marine environment by vessels including those involved in oil and gas operation [4974; 3160]. Vessel and shipping related litter contributes approximately 2 % of the litter found on UK beaches. Shipping related litter contributed approximately 45 litter items per kilometre around the UK on average between 2003 and 2007 [4915; 3160].

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5:
Scour can occur around oil and gas infrastructure placed on the seabed such as piles, platform legs, cables, pipelines and gravity bases. For example, gas platform jacket leg scour of depths of 1.5 to 3.5 m was recorded in the southern North Sea. In some cases, individual scour pits coalescing to form a depression (referred to as “ global scour”) can occur over a much bigger area, of the same order as the area of the structure supported by the piles [JNCC0299].
Vessel anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying the anchor and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery. Mooring chains from swinging moorings may scour the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide. The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials. For example, for an 11.5 tonne anchor penetration of up to 0.88 m occurred in soft sediment when the anchor was dropped and dragged 87 m [4971]. There is a tendency for the anchor to penetrate to deep depths in softer sediment as the opening of the anchor flukes prevents deep penetration in harder sediment [5076]. Typical maximum water depths for anchoring are between 100 m and 150 m.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column5: Physical change in seabed type will occur due to structures on the seabed such as spud cans, platform legs and gravity bases. Scour protection in the form of gravel, rocks, sandbags, gabions, pre-formed concrete blocks or frond mats is routinely used for subsea structures and for pipelines to prevent free-spanning [3122; 3127; 3083; 3125; JNCC0299]. Piles can change the seabed type within the footprint of the piling works from soft sediment to an artificial substratum (typically steel) [4898; 4908; 4890; 4892]. Drill cutting waste consists of crushed rock cuttings from the borehole and remnants of drill mud. Drill cuttings have accumulated beneath drilling installations,  particular in the central and northern areas of the North Sea due to the deep water and weak currents in this area  [4915]. Field studies have shown that, for the majority of North Sea installations, biological communities are largely unaffected beyond a 500-m radius and that the area impacted by contaminated cuttings is reducing [JNCC0245; 4915; JNCC0336].

Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column5: Drill cutting waste consists of crushed rock cuttings from the borehole and remnants of drill mud. Drill cuttings have accumulated beneath drilling installations in the central and northern areas of the North Sea, in the UK and Norwegian sectors due to the deep water and weak currents; there are none in the southern North Sea, where there are stronger ocean currents and wave action [4915]. Field studies have shown that, for the majority of North Sea installations, biological communities are largely unaffected beyond a 500 m radius and that the area impacted by contaminated cuttings is reducing [JNCC0245; 4915; JNCC0336].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column5: Oil and gas activities can result in an increase in naturally occurring radioactive material [JNCC0296]. The main sources of radioactive discharges from the oil and gas industry is produced water. Other sources are descaling operations and use of radioactive tracers. It has been calculated that 7.4 Tbq of alpha activity and 4.9 Tbq of beta activity were discharged in 2007 [JNCC0269; JNCC0267; JNCC0336].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column5: Water-based mud cuttings are typically discharged at, or relatively close to sea surface during closed drilling (i.e. when steel casing in the well bore and a riser to the rig are in place), whereas surface hole cuttings are normally discharged at seabed during open-hole drilling. In contrast to historic oil based mud discharges, potential smothering effects due to the discharge of cuttings drilled with water based muds (WBM) are usually subtle or undetectable, although the presence of drilling material at the seabed is often detectable close to the drilling location (<500m). Modelling of WBM cutting discharges has indicated that deposition of material is generally thin and quickly reduces away from the well. However, the discharge of drill cuttings and water-based fluids may cause some smothering in the direct near vicinity of the well location. Localised siltation can also occur as a result of the remobilisation (and subsequent deposition) of sediment on the seabed due to scour around structures (such as drilling rigs, jack-up platforms, spudcans, gravity bases, pipelines and anchors) and any dredging required during maintenance  [JNCC0299; JNCC0300; JNCC0305; 5004].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5:
Formation water brought up with the hydrocarbons (known as Produced Water) is a source of potential contamination in the marine environment. The composition and characteristics of naturally-occurring chemical substances in Produced Water are closely coupled to the geological characteristics of each reservoir. It may sometimes also contain injection water and condensation water. The composition of Produced Water is complex and can comprise several thousand compounds that vary in concentration between wells and over the lifetime of a well. Transitional elements of Produced Water include  copper and zinc [JNCC0299; JNCC0336].
Most studies of produced water toxicity and dispersion, in the UK and elsewhere) have concluded that the necessary dilution to achieve a No Effect Concentration (NEC) would be reached at <10 to 100m and usually less than 500m from the discharge point. However, it is not expected that significant discharges of produced water will be made from new hydrocarbon developments, since there is a regulatory preference for reinjection to a suitable subsurface formation [JNCC0299; JNCC0336].Transition elements and organo-metals are used as marine anti-fouling agents on vessels. Historically the main ingredients in biocidal antifouling coatings have been copper or tributyltin (TBT). TBT has been banned on vessels under 25m in the UK since 1987 and all vessels since 2008. Since then biocides commonly used in the UK in antifoulants include Copper(I) oxide (cuprous oxide), Copper thiocyanate, Zinc pyrithione and ZineB (organosulfur compound) [JNCC0204; JNCC0326].

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column5: Available measurements indicate that drilling activities produce mainly low-frequency continuous noise from several separate sources on the drilling unit. The primary sources of noise are various types of rotating machinery but the overall acoustic output depends on the type of operation. When drilling from semi-submersible rigs, noise is transmitted from the rig to the water column through submerged parts of the drilling unit hull, risers and mooring cables. If position is maintained by dynamic positioning, noise from thrusters may dominate the lower frequency band. Noise transmission from jack-up drilling units used in shallower water is less because of reduced surface area contact between the water column and submerged parts of the rig. Sound pressure levels  in the range of approximately 120dB re 1µPa in the frequency range 2-1400Hz is considered typical of drilling from a jack-up rig. Drilling duration may range from a few weeks for an exploration well, to several years in the case of a large development programme [JNCC0299; JNCC0304; 5004]. Most vessels involved in the oil and gas industry are medium-size ships (50-100m length) which produce broadband source levels within the 165-180 dB re 1 µPa range and although there is considerable variability in associated frequency spectra, they tend to be similar to large vessels with dominant frequency below 1kHz) [JNCC0299].

column3: Oil and gas infrastructure: Operation and maintenance
column5: Vessels, machinery and people movement during oil and gas operation and maintenance can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as marine mammals and seabirds [5106; 5117]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. The risk increases if bird species are especially sensitive eg red throated diver.

column3: Oil spills including oil spill response
column5: Noise arises from many activities in the marine environment which can evoke a disturbance response in marine mammals and birds [2825; 3269; 3227; 2074; 4869]. Oil spill responses can involve aerial and vessel support for observations [JNCC0235; JNCC0234] or clean up responses such as mechanical recovery, in-situ burning and chemical dispersants [JNCC0236; JNCC0234]. Aircraft can produce significant amounts of sound [3270; 5081]. The height, speed and noise of the aircraft are all factors to consider when determining potential impact. The use of vessels and the presence of people will result in an increase of above water noise. The operation of gear and vessels, as well as presence of people, may result in an increase in above water noise [4352] as seen on fishing vessels. However, the magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). Factors such as height, speed and size of aircraft would need to be taken into consideration.

column3: Oil spills including oil spill response
column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: Manual recovery of oil spills is common within intertidal areas and can include the use of pressure washers, shovels, rakes and heavy machinery (such as back hoes or front-end loaders) to remove oil and debris [JNCC0208; JNCC0315]. Anchors from vessels used in oil spill response can cause disturbance to the seabed upon deployment/recovery and due to dragging.  The anchors of large vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed up to 1 m, but depth of penetration by smaller inshore vessel anchors is expected to be less [4971].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil spills including oil spill response
column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Oil spill responses can involve aerial and vessel support for observations [JNCC0235; JNCC0234] or clean up responses such as mechanical recovery, in-situ burning and chemical dispersants [JNCC0236; JNCC0234]. Collisions can occur between aircraft and birds - the size, height and speed of the aircraft will be factor to consider [5080] and marine birds are frequently attracted to or become disorientated by artificial light sources, which can result in collision and therefore injury or death [4378; 2826]. Bird collisions with vessels [2826], have been recorded with the risk being greatest at night for lighted ships near coastal areas and when the vessel is relatively close to large breeding aggregations of seabirds (rather than further offshore). However, there are relatively few sources of quantified information relating to seabird strikes on vessels. Nocturnal bird strikes on vessels tend to occur when bright, artificial light sources are used at times of poor visibility, typically during bad weather, often angled outwards or upwards from the vessel [4466; 4378].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Factors such as height, speed and size of aircraft would need to be taken into consideration.

column3: Oil spills including oil spill response
column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Oil spill responses can involve  vessel support for observations [JNCC0235; JNCC0234] or clean up responses such as mechanical recovery, in-situ burning and chemical dispersants [JNCC0236; JNCC0234]. Vessels are documented to have collided with mobile marine species (particularly marine mammals). Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull. The most lethal and serious injuries are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120; 4987].There is no evidence to suggest mobile marine species are at risk from collisions with equipment used in oil spill response such as booms or skimmers.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column3: Oil spills including oil spill response
column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Anthropogenic sources of oil spills in the marine environment include accidental spillages and discharges during the offshore extraction of oil. The most frequent types of spill from offshore rigs have been drilling fluids (and base oil), diesel and crude oil. Topsides couplings, valves and tank overflows; and infield flowlines and risers are the most frequent sources of spills from production operations, with most spills being <1 tonne. Well control incidents (i.e. “blowouts” involving uncontrolled flow of fluids from a wellbore or wellhead) have only been observed very infrequently in UK waters. Oil spill can also occur through the transportation of oil (operational discharges, tanker accidents, pipeline leakages) and through the runoff of oil from onshore installations and industry [JNCC0299; 5004; 4915]. Oil released during a spill will contaminate the surface of the water, water column and seafloor as well as having an immediate impact on wildlife such as seabirds, benthic communities, marine mammals, [JNCC0203; JNCC0280; JNCC0219]. Depending on the type of spill, extent, location and environmental condition there can be varying long term impacts [JNCC0214; JNCC0236; JNCC0219].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil spills including oil spill response
column5: Oil spill responses can involve aerial and vessel support for observations  [JNCC0235; JNCC0234] or clean up responses such as mechanical recovery, in-situ burning and chemical dispersants  [JNCC0236; JNCC0234] . Under the Merchant Shipping (Distress Signals and Prevention of Collisions) Regulations 1996 all vessels in the UK must display lights in all weathers between sunset and sunrise including masthead lighting, sidelights, stern lights, towing lighting, all-round light and flash light [JNCC0254]. Marine birds are frequently attracted to and can become disorientated by artificial light sources, which can result in collision and therefore potentially injury or death [4378; 2826]. Light can also occur underwater as a result of ROVs used in oil spill response [JNCC0314].

column3: Oil spills including oil spill response
column4: Introduction of other substances (solid, liquid or gas)
column5:
Anthropogenic sources of oil spills in the marine environment include accidental spillages and discharges during the offshore extraction of oil. The most frequent types of spill from offshore rigs have been drilling fluids (and base oil), diesel and crude oil. Topsides couplings, valves and tank overflows; and infield flowlines and risers are the most frequent sources of spills from production operations, with most spills being <1 tonne. Well control incidents (i.e. “blowouts” involving uncontrolled flow of fluids from a wellbore or wellhead) have only been observed very infrequently in UK waters. Oil spill can also occur through the transportation of oil (operational discharges, tanker accidents, pipeline leakages) and through the runoff of oil from onshore installations and industry [JNCC0299; 5004; 4915]. Oil released during a spill will contaminate the surface of the water, water column and seafloor as well as having an immediate impact on wildlife such as seabirds, benthic communities, marine mammals, [JNCC0203; JNCC0280; JNCC0219]. Depending on the type of spill, extent, location and environmental condition there can be varying long term impacts [JNCC0214; JNCC0236; JNCC0219].
Chemicals are also used in oil spill response and remediation. Oil dispersants are a class of chemicals used to break up surface oil slicks can lead to reduced oiling of beaches and shorelines. Oil dispersants are typically solutions containing one or more surfactants. In addition, chemical surface washing agents are also used to promote oil removal from substrates [JNCC0316; JNCC0317].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Oil spills including oil spill response
column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Oil spill responses can involve aerial and vessel support for observations [JNCC0235; JNCC0234] or clean up responses such as mechanical recovery, in-situ burning and chemical dispersants [JNCC0236; JNCC0234].  Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling on vessels and gear and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur [3164; 3132; 2798; 4338; 4339; 5000]. All watercraft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978; 5177]. Marine species can be carried in vessels ballast water [3164]. There is concern that the expansion of non-indigenous species could alter local biodiversity and sometimes compete with native species, some of which are of commercial interest. This is especially the case in shallow coastal waters, subject to a multitude of human activities, including the construction of artificial hard substrata.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text). The risk of introducing new species may also increase with the range of vessel/boat activity – e.g. travelling from locations outside the UK.

column3: Oil spills including oil spill response
column5: Marine litter can be released into the marine environment by vessels including those involved in oil spill response [4974; 3160]. Shipping related litter contributes approximately 2 % of the litter found on UK beaches. Shipping related litter contributed approximately 45 litter items per kilometre around the UK on average between 2003 and 2007 [4915; 3160].

column3: Oil spills including oil spill response
column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: Manual recovery of oil spills is common within intertidal areas and can include the use of pressure washers, shovels, rakes and heavy machinery (such as back hoes or front-end loaders) to remove oil and debris [JNCC0208; JNCC0315]. This can potentially disturb sediment. Additionally, oil spill responses can involve aerial and vessel support for observations [JNCC0235; JNCC0234] or clean up responses such as mechanical recovery, in-situ burning and chemical dispersants [JNCC0236; JNCC0234]. Anchors from vessels used in oil spill response can cause disturbance to the seabed upon deployment/recovery and due to dragging.  The anchors of large vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed up to 1 m, but depth of penetration by smaller inshore vessel anchors is expected to be less [4971].

column3: Oil spills including oil spill response
column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Transition elements and organo-metals are used as marine anti-fouling agents on vessels. Historically the main ingredients in biocidal antifouling coatings have been copper or tributyltin (TBT). TBT has been banned on vessels under 25m in the UK since 1987. Since then biocides commonly used in the UK in antifoulants include Copper(I) oxide (cuprous oxide), Copper thiocyanate, Zinc pyrithione and ZineB (organosulfur compound) [JNCC0204; JNCC0326].

column3: Oil spills including oil spill response
column5: Oil spill responses can involve aerial and vessel support for observations [JNCC0235; JNCC0234] or clean up responses such as mechanical recovery, in-situ burning and chemical dispersants [JNCC0236; JNCC0234]. Vessel movement is an important source of underwater noise, with noise emitted typically varying with vessel size whereby larger vessels generate lower frequency sound. Although propeller cavitation is the main source of such noise, gear deployment/towing/hauling, turbulence around the hull will also result in noise being transmitted underwater by fishing vessels. For example, the source levels associated with small sea going vessels are typically 160-180 dB  (Peak) re 1 µPa-m (RMS) [3152].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. The risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed.

column5: Oil spill responses can involve  vessel support for observations [JNCC0235; JNCC0234] or clean up responses such as mechanical recovery, in-situ burning and chemical dispersants [JNCC0236; JNCC0234]. Vessel movement is an important source of underwater noise, with noise emitted typically varying with vessel size whereby larger vessels generate lower frequency sound. Vibration (particle motion) will be caused by vessels although information on how this propagates through the water column is limited.

column3: Oil spills including oil spill response
column5: Oil spill responses can involve aerial support for observations [JNCC0235]or aerial spraying o chemical dispersants [JNCC0236]. Aircraft movement can cause visual disturbance. The height, speed and noise of the aircraft are all factors to consider when determining impact [3077; 3134; 3270]. The movement of vessels and people involved in oil spill response, as well as that of  machinery, can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as fish, marine mammals, seabirds and coastal birds. However, the magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity, plus other factors such as species present and age, weather conditions and degree of habituation to disturbance source [2497; 2825; 3269; 2707; 4977; JNCC0317].

column5: In relation to fishing, the operation of gear and vessels, as well as presence of people, may result in an increase in above water noise. column5: This pressure refers to obstructions to species movement caused by physical barriers or prolonged exposure to noise, light, visual disturbance or changes in water quality. The likelihood of impact will depend on factors such as the spatial/temporal scale of the activity and its location in relation to migratory routes, and so the pressure will need to be considered on case-by-case basis to determine relevance to a given feature/site. Whilst it is considered that examples of the association between this sub-activity and pressure will be rare, potential causes include behavioural effects from the use of acoustic deterrents [3121] although this impact may be better considered by the pressure 'Underwater noise changes'.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity - including in relation to the size of the water body, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. More specifically, the risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed for prolonged periods of time in migratory channels for fish species.

However, there are relatively few sources of quantified information relating to seabird strikes on vessels. Nocturnal bird strikes on vessels tend to occur when bright, artificial light sources are used at times of poor visibility, typically during bad weather, often angled outwards or upwards from the vessel [4466; 4378].

Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120; 4987].

column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: This pressure relates to vessels associated with this activity and their movement. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers) [3096; 3164]

Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling on vessels and gear and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur [3164; 3132; 2798; 4338; 4339]. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978; 5177].
