column5: Despite international legislation such as Annex V of the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973 [3140], maritime activity is still a major source of litter. Marine litter can be released into the marine environment by vessels including those involved in fishing activities. Various types of litter result from fishing in general including galley waste, fish boxes, floats/buoys, nets, ropes, lines, pots, weights and micro-plastic particles resulting from disintegration of plastic gear [3160; 3118]. Fishing related litter contributed to 14 % of the litter identified during the UK Beachwatch survey in 2006 [3160; 3096] while surveys across 32 sites in European waters (continental shelves to canyons) found that derelict fishing gear was the second most abundant item encountered (34 % of total) [4459]. However, loss of nets is likely to be minimal for pelagic fishing nets compared to demersal nets.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Bycatch is associated with almost all fishing activities and is related to factors such as the gear type and its design (i.e. its selectivity), the targeted species and effort. Pelagic seines can result in the bycatch of a range of fauna including mammals (e.g. porpoise), turtles, elasmobranchs and birds [1419; 3130; 4354; 5215], the consequences of which can be significant for some species and populations [3130]. Much of the evidence relates to by-catch in purse seine tuna fisheries conducted for example in the Pacific or Indian Oceans.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Purse seines target dense, mobile schools of pelagic fish, such as herring and mackerel [JNCC0285; JNCC0359]. The status of herring and mackerel stocks are assessed annually by the International Council for Exploration of the Seas (ICES) [JNCC0360].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Pressure primarily relates to vessels associated with this activity. Transition elements and organo-metals are used as marine anti-fouling agents on vessels. Historically the main ingredients in biocidal antifouling coatings have been copper or tributyltin (TBT; banned on vessels under 25 m in the UK since 1987 and all vessels since 2008). Since then biocides commonly used in the UK in antifoulants include Copper(I) oxide (cuprous oxide), Copper thiocyanate, Zinc pyrithione and ZineB (organosulfur compound) [JNCC0204; JNCC0326]. Antifouling compounds like TBT and copper wash from ship coatings enter and persist in the marine environment, with highest concentrations generally found in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3164; 3155; 4915].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Vessel movement is an important source of underwater noise, with noise emitted typically varying with vessel size whereby larger vessels generate lower frequency sound. Although propeller cavitation is the main source of such noise, gear deployment/towing/hauling, turbulence around the hull and the use of fish finding sonars will also result in noise being transmitted underwater by fishing vessels. For example, the source levels associated with small sea going vessels and echosounders are typically 160-180 dB and 235 (Peak) re 1 µPa-m (RMS), respectively. Acoustic deterrents/harassing devices are an additional potential source of underwater noise [3152].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). The risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: This pressure is associated with the use of a vessel. The movement of vessels and people, as well as that of gear, can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as fish, marine mammals, seabirds and coastal birds. However, the magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity, plus other factors such as species present and age, weather conditions and degree of habituation to disturbance source [2497; 2825; 3269; 2707; 4977].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column5: Airborne noise from marine salvage operations can include a variety of equipment including vessel noise (such as heavy lift crane barges, support vessels, jack-up rigs), lifting helicopters and machinery (such as pumps and hoses; welding equipment; drilling and cutting equipment) [JNCC0325; JNCC0326].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: During salvage operations, abrasion and/or disturbance of the seabed may occur due to the direct removal of a wreck from the seabed and the use of vessels carrying out salvage works with either jackup legs which cause depressions on the seabed [3148] or anchors [3127].  Damage to the seabed may be caused by deployment of anchors from vessels used in salvage operations, the subsequent dragging and locking in of anchors could cause abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery [3223]. Additional rock protection may be placed on the seabed where required leading to abrasion/ disturbance [3148].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: The removal of wrecks and other structures as a result of marine salvage operations is expected to cause an increase in suspended sediments (particularly if the wreck is located on soft sediment seabed). The dragging of anchors used by vessels involved in salvage activities and salvage operations can also cause localised and temporary increases in suspended sediments [3223].  Depending on methods used, the removal of structures and scour protection may lead to temporary increases in suspended solids and siltation [4387].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Salvage operations can involve the use of large vessels (such as heavy lift crane barges) jack-up rigs and lifting helicopters [JNCC0325; JNCC0326].  Collisions can occur between aircraft and birds - the size, height and speed of the aircraft will be factor to consider [5080] and marine birds are frequently attracted to or become disorientated by artificial light sources, which can result in collision and therefore injury or death [4378; 2826]. Bird collisions with vessels [2826], have been recorded with the risk being greatest at night for lighted ships near coastal areas and when the vessel is relatively close to large breeding aggregations of seabirds (rather than further offshore). However, there are relatively few sources of quantified information relating to seabird strikes on vessels. Nocturnal bird strikes on vessels tend to occur when bright, artificial light sources are used at times of poor visibility, typically during bad weather, often angled outwards or upwards from the vessel [4466; 4378].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Salvage operations can involve the use of large vessels (such as heavy lift crane barges) [JNCC0325; JNCC0326].  Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120; 4987].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: During salvage there is the potential for possible spill of remnant pollutant fluids contained within a wreck including oil [JNCC0325; JNCC0326]. There is also the risk of accidental oil spills from vessels involved in salvage. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers) [3032; 3096; 3107; 3164; 4333; 4985].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Lighting will be required for salvage operations undertaken at night including the lighting of vessels, jack-up rigs and associated salvage machinery [JNCC0325; JNCC0326]. Under the Merchant Shipping (Distress Signals and Prevention of Collisions) Regulations 1996 all vessels in the UK must display lights in all weathers between sunset and sunrise including masthead lighting, sidelights, stern lights, towing lighting, all-round light and flash light [JNCC0254]. Marine birds are frequently attracted to and can become disorientated by artificial light sources, which can result in collision and therefore potentially injury or death [4378; 2826]. Light can also occur underwater as a result of ROVs used in salvage operations [JNCC0325].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Introduction of other substances (solid, liquid or gas)
column5: During salvage there is the potential for possible spill of remnant pollutants contained within a wreck including oil, chemicals and cargo [JNCC0325; JNCC0326]. The potential to cause impacts to the marine environment from a salvage spill will be dependant on a range of factors including the toxicity and amount of any cargo (and other remaining substances) present within a wreck.  There is also the risk of accidental oil spills from vessels involved in salvage. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers) [3032; 3096; 3107; 3164; 4333; 4985].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Salvage operations can involve the use of large vessels (such as heavy lift crane barges) and jack-up rigs  [JNCC0325; JNCC0326]. Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling on vessels and machinery and can be potentially harmful in locations where they do not naturally occur [3164; 3132; 2798; 4338; 4339; 5000]. All vessels have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978; 5177]. Marine species can be carried in vessels ballast water [3164]. There is concern that the expansion of non-indigenous species could alter local biodiversity and sometimes compete with native species, some of which are of commercial interest. However, specific evidence of the introduction and spread of non-native species as a direct result of salvage operations is limited.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text). The risk of introducing new species may also increase with the range of vessel/boat activity – e.g. travelling from locations outside the UK.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Marine litter can be released into the marine environment by vessels including those involved in salvage operations. Cargo within a wreck could also be  released accidentally during a salvage operation. Shipping related litter contributes approximately 2 % of the litter found on UK beaches. Shipping related litter contributed approximately 45 litter items per kilometre around the UK on average between 2003 and 2007 [4915; 3160].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: During salvage operations, penetration and/or disturbance of the seabed may occur due to the use of vessels carrying out salvage works with either jackup legs which cause depressions on the seabed [3148] or anchors [3127]. Additional rock protection may be placed on the seabed where required leading to abrasion/ disturbance [3148].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: The removal of a wreck on the seabed could potentially change the habitat from a hard substrate (e.g. the metal or wood of wreck) to a soft sediment habitat i.e. the sediment present directly below a wreck.  Additional rock may be placed on the seabed during salvage to cover exposed structures or provide a stable rock berm for the placement of jack-up legs [4387].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: If a salvage operation is carried out on a vessel or structure that is carrying a source of radioactivity (e.g. nuclear waste or a nuclear submarine) there is the risk that radionuclides could be realised into the marine environment [JNCC0238]. The potential to cause impacts to the marine environment from a spill of radioactive material from a wreck during salvage operations will be dependant on a range of factors including the radioactivity and amount of any radioactive cargo present within a wreck.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5:
The removal of wrecks and other structures as a result of marine salvage operations is expected to cause an increase in suspended sediments (particularly if the wreck is located on soft sediment seabed). This could cause an increase in siltation in the vicinity of a wreck. 
The dragging of anchors used by vessels involved in salvage activities can cause localised and temporary increases in suspended sediments [3223]. The settling out of suspended sediments is only expected to cause negligible increases in siltation.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column4: Synthetic compound contamination (incl. pesticides, antifoulants, pharmaceuticals).  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: During salvage there is the potential for the possible spill of remnant pollutants contained within a wreck including  synthetic compounds such as pesticides or pharmaceutical cargo [JNCC0325; JNCC0326]. The potential to cause impacts to the marine environment from a salvage spill will be dependant on a range of factors including the toxicity and amount of any cargo (and other remaining substances) present within a wreck.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: During salvage there is the potential for possible spill of remnant pollutants contained within a wreck including  transition elements such as iron which has been carried as cargo [JNCC0325; JNCC0326]. Moving a wreck could also disturb anti-fouling paint (which could contain TBT) present on the outside of a sunken vessel [JNCC0325; JNCC0326].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Sources of underwater noise from salvaging activities include vessel movements/ operations, lifting and removal operations [4387]. Vessel noise is probably the main source of persistent noise during salvaging activities. Although the majority of this will come from the propeller cavitation, onboard machinery and turbulence around the hull can also result in noise being transmitted underwater.  For example, the source levels associated with small sea going vessels are typically 160-180 dB  (Peak) re 1 µPa-m (RMS) [3152].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Vessels, machinery and people movement such as those involved in salvage operations can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as marine mammals and seabirds [5106; 5117]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. The risk increases if bird species are especially sensitive eg red throated diver.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Structures in the marine environment immediately interact with the local current regime [3083]. Removal of structures during salvage will allow local currents to return to those of the surroundings environment, unaffected by interaction with structures.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Wreck structures on or near the surface have the potential to interact with the local wave regime [3083]. Removal of structures during salvage will remove any sheltering effects of a wreck with respect to wave exposure, returning conditions to those of the surroundings environment.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Outfall pipe construction and repair require the use of vehicles and shipping all of which emit above water noise. Airborne noise can arise from many activities in the marine environment [3164]. The use of machinery, vessels, explosives and people will result in an increase of above water noise. Sources of airborne noise that might be involved in pipe construction include piling [1329; 3082]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the scale, intensity and duration of the activity.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: Outfall pipes are generally installed onto or into the seabed. This can require the movement of heavy machinery and vehicles across the surface of the surface of the seabed or coastal habitat and potentially also excavation/dredging works which can lead to abrasion/disturbance [3139; 4403; JNCC0332]. Outfalls may be constructed using bored tunnel with little disturbance of the seabed except at the discharge point. Onshore discharges that cross the foreshore have the potential to scour the seabed, especially across mudflats [JNCC0322].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Pipeline construction and maintenance, can result in barriers to species movement through increased noise (e.g. construction, shipping), lighting, presence of structures, changes to water quality and suspended sediments [2817; 3085; 3096; 3106; 3195; 2763; 3111; 3149; 2834; 3151]. The noise and turbidity arising from dredging operations, which may be required during pipeline construction, may pose a barrier to migration when occurring on or in proximity of specific migratory routes [3152; 3080; 2757].  The scale of the impact will depend on scale of activity and the location and will need to be considered on a case-by-case basis to determine relevance to given feature/site.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Sewage discharges can have significantly higher suspended sediment levels than the receiving environment. Outfall pipe construction can involve activities (e.g. excavation/dredging works) which create suspended sediment plumes [3126; 4401; 4440; 4403; 3139]. Onshore discharges that cross the foreshore have the potential to scour the seabed, especially across mudflats [JNCC0322] resulting in localised plumes of suspended sediment.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Outfall pipe construction and repair may require the use and movement of vessels. Marine birds are frequently attracted to or become disorientated by artificial light sources, which can result in collision and therefore injury or death [4378; 2826]. Bird collisions with vessels, including fishing vessels [2826], have been recorded with the risk being greatest at night for lighted ships near coastal areas and when the vessel is relatively close to large breeding aggregations of seabirds (rather than further offshore). However, there are relatively few sources of quantified information relating to seabird strikes on vessels. Nocturnal bird strikes on vessels tend to occur when bright, artificial light sources are used at times of poor visibility, typically during bad weather, often angled outwards or upwards from the vessel [4466; 4378; 4337].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Outfall pipe construction and repair may require the use and movement of vessels. Vessels are documented to have collided with mobile marine species (particularly marine mammals but also fish and seabirds). Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120; 4987]. A lack of information exists regarding collision risk of animals (e.g. birds, fish, marine mammals) with underwater structures, especially for birds. The response of birds will depend on their detection of a device and any associated structures. The risk of collision may be increased if the devices alter the characteristics of the current, especially if such changes create new foraging opportunities, since this may impact on the manoeuvrability and underwater swimming agility of birds [4959; 5075]. Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].

column5: Excessive nutrient and organic enrichment in the water column due to sewage outfall discharge can result in reduced oxygen levels in surrounding habitats [3126; 3139; 4403; 4401]. The pressure is also associated with sediment mobilisation and increased suspended sediments as well as the deposition of organic matter. The pressure can therefore result from outfall pipe construction during any excavation/dredging works as well as the outfall during operation [3161; 3164]. The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the dynamic nature of the area, the temperature and the sediment type, making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Genetic modification & translocation of indigenous species
column5: The construction and maintenance of outfalls will involve vessels travelling to the site from a number of other locations. The surfaces and ballast water of these vessels/vehicles could translocate native species. Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978; 5177]. Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164; 3070]. The vessels involved in outfall construction/maintenance are generally likely to be making short/local journeys and therefore the likelihood of this pressure occurring is considered to be very low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Habitat structure changes - removal of substratum (extraction)
column5: Outfalls are either buried or surface laid across coastal and seabed habitats. Where they are buried trench excavation into the sediment will be required [3139; 4403]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on a number of factors, including the construction method.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Although sewage sludge is no longer disposed of at sea, organic pollutants which are often found in sewage sludge include polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). The sum of 16 PAHs in sewage sludge samples (collected in southeastern Poland) ranged from 2,039 to 36,440 µg/kg; the highest value was noted in only one sewage sludge sample obtained from a location with an operating petrochemical industry (refinery) and a considerable contribution of treated industrial sewage [JNCC0279]. A survey of the digested sludge from 14 UK wastewater treatment plants was carried out to obtain contemporary UK data on the concentrations of certain classes of persistent organic compounds for which data are scarce and to assess whether UK sludge was likely to comply with the sludge limits for polynuclear aromatic hydrocarbons proposed by the EU; total concentrations ranged from 67 to 370 mg/kg dw [JNCC0243]. Outfall construction and repair require the use of vehicles and shipping all of which have the potential to release vessel oil and fuel (comprising PAHs) into the marine environment. Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers).
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: The pressure is potentially associated with navigation and operational lighting on vessels involved in outfall pipe construction and repair/maintenance. Under the Merchant Shipping (Distress Signals and Prevention of Collisions) Regulations 1996 all vessels in the UK must display lights in all weathers between sunset and sunrise including masthead lighting, sidelights, sternlights, towing lighting, all-round light and flash light [JNCC0254]. Lighting can affect marine species (namely birds and fish). Marine birds are frequently attracted to or become disorientated by artificial light sources, which can result in collision and therefore injury or death [4378; 2826]. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083; 3088; 3195; 2797; 3107; 4334; 4339]. Artificial light can repel or attract fish, which in turn can influence their foraging and schooling behaviour, spatial distribution, predation risk, migration and reproduction [4378].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Outfall discharges from sewerage sources can introduce a range of pathogens  (bacteria, viruses or parasites) into the marine environment which could be deemed damaging [3074; 3139; 4401; 4915]. Pathogens transmitted by human faeces are most commonly involved and the discharge of sewage polluted by human and animal pathogens into the sea represents the main source of bacterial pollution. Every pathogen present in seawater may be trapped and concentrated in the tissues of the bivalves and therefore represents a potential health hazard [JNCC0252].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column4: Introduction of other substances (solid, liquid or gas)
column5:
Outfalls from urban wastewater discharge a range of substances into the marine environment [3126; 4401]. These include organic matter, nutrients, contaminants (e.g. heavy metals, PAHs, PCBs, biocides, oil) and micro-organisms [3126]. The type of pollutants and the magnitude of loadings to the wastewater treatment system are a complex function of: Size and type of conurbation (commercial, residential, mixed); Plumbing and heating systems; Domestic and commercial product formulation and use patterns; Dietary sources and faeces; Atmospheric quality, deposition and run-off;
Presence and type of industrial activities; Use of metals, and other materials in construction; Urban land use; Traffic type and density; Urban street cleaning; Maintenance practices, for collecting systems and stormwater controls; and accidental releases [JNCC0358].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: This pressure relates to use of vessels during construction and maintenance/repair work on outfall pipes. The surfaces and ballast water of these vessels/vehicles could transport INIS. Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling on vessels and gear and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur [3164; 3132; 2798; 4338; 4339]. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978; 5177]. Thousands of marine species can also be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164; 3070]. The vessels involved in outfall construction/maintenance are generally likely to be making short/local journeys and therefore the likelihood of this pressure occurring is considered to be very low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text). The risk of introducing new species may also increase with the range of vessel/boat activity – e.g. travelling from locations outside the UK.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Litter can enter the marine environment as sewage related debris from treated and untreated  sewage discharged to estuarine and marine waters [JNCC0287]. Micro plastics are also  found in discharges. Although low concentrations of microplastics are generally found in sewage discharges, outfalls have the potential to act as a pathway to release microplastics given the large volumes of effluent discharged to the aquatic environment [JNCC0306]. In addition, the construction and maintenance phase of an outfall may require a number of vessels and vehicles in the marine environment which could cause litter. Some discharges may contain floating waste [3126; 3139; 4401]. Marine litter can be released into the marine environment by shipping vessels, either accidentally (inappropriate storage) or deliberately [4974; 3160]. Shipping litter includes pallets, strapping bans and drums. Cargo may also be washed overboard during stormy weather and contribute to coastal litter levels. Shipping related litter contributes approximately 2 % of the litter found on UK beaches. Shipping related litter contributed approximately 45 litter items per kilometre around the UK on average between 2003 and 2007 [4915; 3160]. The vessels involved in outfall construction and/or maintenance are relatively small to moderate in size and only likely to be making short journeys.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: There are several sources of nutrient enrichment in the marine environment, including urban wastewater discharges [3139; 4403; 4401]. Nutrient enrichment can lead to increases in the abundance and biomass of certain benthic and phytoplankton species, which in turn can increase production of higher trophic levels (e.g. fish). It can also lead to an increase in opportunistic macroalgae and excessive nutrient enrichment can result in anoxia, and consequently, to declines in biomass and diversity in the benthic and fish community [JNCC0242]. Seagrass beds are also particularly vulnerable to damage from nutrient over-enrichment [JNCC0307]. Nutrient over-enrichment of coastal waters can also lead to harmful algal blooms [JNCC0307]. This pressure can also result during any excavation/dredging works involved in the construction of outfall pipes [3161; 3164]. The mobilisation of sediment will result in an increase in suspended sediments and the release of organic matter and nutrients  [3145; 5121]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899]. The magnitude of pressure depends on intensity/scale of activity and hydrographic conditions [2834; 3276; 3198; 4939].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: There are several sources of organic enrichment in the marine environment, including urban wastewater discharges[3139; 4403; 4401]. This pressure can also result during any excavation/dredging works involved in the construction of outfall pipes. Sediment mobilisation during dredging can increase the levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145; 5121; 3139; 4401; 4403]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899]. For example, when the hydrographic conditions at a disposal site leads to the accumulation of sludge, then the organic carbon content of the sediments will be found to be high [JNCC0215]. Design of outfalls will seek to avoid unacceptable organic enrichment on local seabed.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: Outfalls are either buried or surface laid across coastal and seabed habitats. This requires the movement of heavy machinery and vehicles across the surface of the seabed or coastal habitat and potentially also excavation/dredging works which can lead to abrasion/disturbance [3139; 4403; JNCC0332]. During construction and maintenance, vessel anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying the anchor and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery.  The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials. For example, for an 11.5 tonne anchor penetration of up to 0.88 m occurred in soft sediment when the anchor was dropped and dragged 87 m [4971]. There is a tendency for the anchor to penetrate to deep depths in softer sediment as the opening of the anchor flukes prevents deep penetration in harder sediment [5076]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on a number of factors, including the construction method and intensity of activity.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: The seabed currents and the type of sediment will affect the accumulation and scouring of the sediment around the outfall pipe [5004].

column4: Physical loss (to land or freshwater habitat)
column5: Where outfalls are buried, trench excavation will be required which will remove the existing habitat and if not fully reinstated this could result in habitat loss. Rock armouring may also be placed over the pipe resulting in a loss in habitat [3139].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Outfalls from industrial areas may represent a source of radionuclide contamination [3126; 4442]. There may also be radionuclide contamination in discharge following the sewage treatment of hospital effluent which could potentially enter the aquatic environment [JNCC0308]. Within Scotland there are a large number of sewage treatment works which receive authorised radioactive discharges from the non-nuclear industry. For example, total radioactive material authorised to the Dalmuir sewer system to the west of Glasgow in Clydebank is 5.65 TBq/year, including relatively large quantities of Technetium-99m (99mTc) and Iodine-131 (131I) [JNCC0284].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column5: A range of substances are discharged from outfalls. These can include freshwater outputs which may decrease salinity levels [3126; 4401; 4441; 4403; 4485]. A change in the salinity of sewage water has a negative effect on the degradation of organic matter which in turn can affect the benthic community [JNCC0309]. The scale of the change in salinity is likely to be low and will depend on a number of factors, include the discharge rate/volume and the existing hydrodynamic environment.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column5: A range of substances are discharged from outfalls. These can include super saline brines which increase local salinity levels [3126; 4401; 4441; 4403; 4485]. A change in the salinity of sewage water has a negative effect on the degradation of organic matter which in turn can affect the benthic community [JNCC0309]. The scale of the change in salinity is likely to be low and will depend on a number of factors, include the discharge rate/volume and the existing hydrodynamic environment.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column5: Pipeline construction can create suspended sediment plumes and local smothering [3126; 4401; 4440; 4403; 3139]. During operation, the presence of pipeline structures on the seabed surface can induce changes in hydrodynamics which can cause increased siltation. Outfall discharge can have high suspended sediment concentrations causing locally increased sedimentation [3139; 4403].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Synthetic compound contamination (incl. pesticides, antifoulants, pharmaceuticals).  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Discharge from industrial outfall pipes can contain anti foulants and a range of synthetic compounds. Whilst heavily regulated, there is a risk of damaging concentrations being released were issues to arise [3126; 4401; 4403]. A vast array of synthetic organic compounds find their way into the sewage system, some of which will be degraded by sewage treatment, when it is provided, while others will pass through the system partially or wholly unchanged [JNCC0215]. A survey  of the digested sludge from 14 UK wastewater treatment plants was carried out to obtain contemporary UK data on the concentrations of certain classes of persistent organic compounds for which data are scarce and to assess whether UK sludge was likely to comply with the sludge limits for polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) proposed by the EU [JNCC0243]. Total PCB concentrations were 110-440 ug/kg dw [JNCC0243].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: All aquatic life forms have characteristic temperature preference and tolerance limits. Outfall discharges can be warmer than receiving water bodies and are therefore a source of thermal enhancement and ecological effect [3126; 4401; 4403; 4485].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Outfall discharges can include a range of agricultural and industrial chemicals including organic and metal contaminants [3126; 4401; 4403]. The contamination of the terrestrial environment with tributyltin (TBT) as a result of the disposal of contaminated harbour sediments, sewage sludge and/or biocide products has been raising concerns as it may pose a risk to soil invertebrates and plants [JNCC0246]. Transition elements and organo-metals are used as marine anti-fouling agents on vessels. Historically the main ingredients in biocidal antifouling coatings have been copper or tributyltin (TBT). TBT has been banned on vessels under 25 m in the UK since 1987. Since then biocides commonly used in the UK in antifoulants include Copper(I) oxide (cuprous oxide), Copper thiocyanate, Zinc pyrithione and ZineB (organosulfur compound) [JNCC0204; JNCC0326].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Vessels and machinery used during the construction and maintenance of outfall pipes will increase underwater noise levels. Shipping is an important source of underwater noise. Although the majority of this will come from the propeller cavitation, onboard machinery and turbulence around the hull can also result in underwater noise being transmitted underwater. Different parts of the vessel and different vessels emit sound pressures at different frequencies. Generally, the larger the vessel the more dominant the sound pressure levels at lower frequencies. Low frequency sounds generally travel further and have the potential of impacting larger areas [3164; 4921; 4995; 5173]. Dredgers involved in any excavation/trench works during pipe instalment will also generate elevated underwater noise [JNCC0319]. This pressure is likely to be infrequent and of a small scale.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: The construction and maintenance/repair of outfall pipes will involve the movement of vessels, vehicles and people which can create visual stimuli that evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as marine mammals, fish and birds [5106; 5117]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity plus other factors such as weather conditions [2497; 2825; 3091; 3269; 2707; 4977]. The number of vessels involved in this activity are very low and infrequent therefore the scale of this pressure is considered to be very low.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Pipeline structures siting proud of the seabed surface can induce changes in hydrodynamics specifically altering tidal flow direction and velocity [3091]. In particular, cross shore structures such as groynes and harbour arms can intercept flow paths, causing flows to divert around or across the structures [4892; 4893; 4894; 4873; 5075; 4960; 3125; 4961].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Outfall structures may affect local wave conditions by causing reflection, refraction and breaking of waves. This could increase or decrease wave energy in nearby areas [3161; 4403].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column5: The pressure relates to obstructions to species movement caused by habitat fragmentation from land claim or agricultural improvement and alteration of seed dispersal processes [JNCC0311].  The scale of the impact will depend on scale of activity and location and will need to be considered on a case-by-case basis to determine relevance to a given feature/site.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Activities that change the use of land, such as agricultural grazing, may change the amount of drainage and soil run off and therefore change the amount of suspended sediment in adjacent coastal areas [JNCC0246; JNCC0312].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: The pressure can result from the application of fertiliser on land to improve grazing or the deposition of manure from domestic animals [JNCC0250]. Excessive nutrient and organic enrichment in the water column from agricultural soil run off can result in reduced oxygen levels in surrounding habitats, especially after collapse of algal blooms, which can result in fish kills [3126; 3139; 4403; 4401; 4915; 2293; JNCC0312].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Pathogens (bacteria, viruses or parasites) transmitted by manure can enter the sea and could be result in adverse environmental effects. For example, every pathogen present in seawater may be trapped and concentrated in the tissues of the bivalves and therefore represents a potential health hazard [JNCC0252].

column5: There are several sources of nutrient enrichment in the marine environment which can result from agricultural (grazing) activities via the application of fertiliser on land to improve grazing or the deposition of manure from domestic animals. These can both add phosphorus and nitrogen to soils and water through various diffuse processes [JNCC0312]. Tertiary treatments on the major industrial and sewage treatment discharges can also be a significant sources of phosphorus  [JNCC0250]. This can lead to increased runoff to surrounding coastal areas [JNCC0250]. Excessive nutrient enrichment can lead to a risk of eutrophication, changes in the species composition of communities, algal blooms, development of hypoxic conditions due to decomposition of excess plant biomass or fatalities of fauna due to oxygen deficiencies [4915; 2293; JNCC0312].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column5: There are several sources of organic enrichment in the marine environment which can result from agricultural (grazing) activities via the application of organic fertiliser on land to improve grazing or the deposition of manure from domestic animals [JNCC0250], which can enter marine waters through runoff.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column5: Grazing on coastal land can increase soil compaction [JNCC0282].  Some research indicates that increased soil compaction increases sediment run off [JNCC0251]. Therefore, grazing cattle (and potentially other domestic animals) have the potential to increase soil runoff and therefore increase siltation rates in surrounding coastal areas. It should be noted that there is other research that suggests that compaction can lead to a decline in sediment loss which would reduce siltation rates [JNCC0313]. Grazing has been shown to reduce ground cover in some coastal habitats (machair grassland) [JNCC0201].  Reduced ground cover is linked to increased soil runoff which could increase siltation in surrounding coastal areas [JNCC0201]. Grazing can also cause erosion and in turn increased siltation where there is poaching particularly around creeks [JNCC0364].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: In general, human activity on the coast such as construction (e.g. of coastal defence structures) can create noise and visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in coastal birds [1533; 3154]. Based on such evidence, grazing activity, which may include the use of machinery and vehicles as well as the presence of people, may be expected to create visual disturbance if occurring close to the shore/coast. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity, plus other factors such as species present and age, weather conditions and degree of habituation to disturbance source [5106; 5117; 4977].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column5: The effects of trampling and lowering of the sward height also have potential implications for flood risk management; in that the wave attenuation properties of the marsh can be reduced as the sward gets shorter [1674]. In locations where the edge of the saltmarsh is eroding, or there is internal dissection as creeks erode headwards with sea level rise, the introduction of grazing may be detrimental to flood risk management as it could increase wave energy transmitted over the marsh towards the sea defence.

column5: Behavioural effects from the use of acoustic deterrents [3121; 3152; 4921] could prevent the movement of marine mammals and fish. However, the impacts from the latter may be better considered by the pressure 'Underwater noise changes'.

column5: Nets placed in the water (e.g. box nets, cone nets and curtain nets) or covering the top of an aquaculture cage (i.e. top net) are a common form of predator control in aquaculture [JNCC0256; 4414], leaving potential for non-target species (marine mammals, birds) to become entangled outside of predator control activities [4487; JNCC0334; JNCC0335]. Shooting of predators for the protection of aquaculture resources is a 'last resort' form of  predator control where non-lethal methods have proved unsuccessful. Shooting of seals requires a licence in Scotland and Northern Ireland [JNCC0220; JNCC0232].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column5: Underwater acoustic devices including acoustic deterrent devices (ADDs), which alert mammals to the presence of netting, and acoustic harassment devices (AHDs), which aim to keep animals away from cages as well as playing of predator vocalisations are all used in aquaculture predator control  deliberately transmitting noise into the water to deter large marine mammals such as seals and small semi-aquatic mammals such as otters. Most models of seal scarer currently available have source levels > 150 dB re 1µPa at 1m [JNCC0256; JNCC0202].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Though not the most common technique of predator control the use of personnel or scarecrows for deterring predators as a form of visual disturbance has some success [4414; JNCC0256] for mammals and birds. However, the magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity, plus other factors such as species present and their degree of habituation to disturbance source.

column5: The types of machinery and equipment used in tree removal (forestry operations) may include excavators, tractors, chainsaws, processing machinery (e.g. chippers) [JNCC0352] and vehicles, the use of which will generate airborne noise approximately in the range of 80-100 db [JNCC0310]. Such machinery/equipment operated close to the coast, together with the presence of people, may disturb receptors such as birds.

column5: The pressure is associated with sediment input arising from changes in forestation. The removal of stands of forestry and the impact of machinery on soil can increase surface runoff (containing soil and nutrients) [JNCC0355; JNCC0291; JNCC0228], with the potential for changes in suspended sediment concentrations in  water bodies which receive the runoff. In Scotland, forestry is identified as a major land use pressure within specific river basin management plans, where over 25% of Scottish lochs are classified as at risk of failing to meet WFD environmental objectives (in 2015) due to forestry related activities (note, it is not stated this is due to changes in suspended solids specifically) [JNCC0291]. Most evidence related to effects of forestry activity on water catchment areas/rivers and hence the evidence relating to this pressure in transitional or coastal waters is uncertain. It can be noted however that there are now controls on felling trees which should reduce this pressure, the magnitude of which would depend on where the forest stands are in relation to the runoff pathway to the marine environment.

The removal of stands of forestry and the impact of machinery on soil can increase surface runoff (containing soil and nutrients) [JNCC0355; JNCC0291; JNCC0228], with the potential for changes in suspended sediment concentrations (and subsequent siltation rate changes), nutrient/organic enrichment and subsequent deoxygenation in  water bodies which receive the runoff. Most evidence related to effects of forestry activity on water catchment areas/rivers and hence the evidence relating to this pressure in transitional or coastal waters is uncertain. column3: Extraction of genetic resources e.g. bioprospecting (also see other related activities in fishing and dredging)
column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: The pressure is likely to be associated with any anchors, which can cause damage to the seabed surface and subsurface layers upon deployment/recovery and due to dragging.  The anchors of large vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed up to 1 m, but depth of penetration by smaller inshore vessel anchors is expected to be less [4971]. The pressure could also result from the physical removal of living resources from the seabed, depending on the collection method/gear used (for example, abrasion/disturbance from diver's fins if hand collecting specimens subtidally), however, there is limited evidence relating to the impact of this specific activity (evidence relating to fin damage generally relates to recreational diving on coral reefs where the intensity of the activity would likely be higher).

column3: Extraction of genetic resources e.g. bioprospecting (also see other related activities in fishing and dredging)
column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Pressure relates to vessels associated with this activity and their movement. Bird collisions with vessels have been recorded with the risk being greatest at night for lighted ships near coastal areas and when the vessel is relatively close to large breeding aggregations of seabirds (rather than further offshore) [2826]. However, there are relatively few sources of quantified information relating to seabird strikes on vessels. Nocturnal bird strikes on vessels tend to occur when bright, artificial light sources are used at times of poor visibility, typically during bad weather, often angled outwards or upwards from the vessel [4466; 4378].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure.
