column3: Extraction of genetic resources e.g. bioprospecting (also see other related activities in fishing and dredging)
column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: This pressure relates to vessels associated with this activity and their movement. Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120; 4987].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column3: Extraction of genetic resources e.g. bioprospecting (also see other related activities in fishing and dredging)
column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: This pressure relates to vessels associated with this activity and their movement. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers) [3096; 3164; 3194; 4985].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Extraction of genetic resources e.g. bioprospecting (also see other related activities in fishing and dredging)
column5: The pressure is potentially associated with navigation and operational lighting on vessels. Under the Merchant Shipping (Distress Signals and Prevention of Collisions) Regulations 1996 all vessels in the UK must display lights in all weathers between sunset and sunrise including masthead lighting, sidelights, stern lights, towing lighting, all-round light and flash light [JNCC0254]. Marine birds are frequently attracted to or become disorientated by artificial light sources, which can result in collision and therefore injury or death [4378; 2826].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column3: Extraction of genetic resources e.g. bioprospecting (also see other related activities in fishing and dredging)
column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: This pressure relates to the use of vessels for this activity and their movement. Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling on vessels and gear and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur [3164; 3132; 2798; 4338; 4339]. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978; 5177]. Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164; 3070] and hence deliberate discharge of ballast water in coastal waters (as opposed to out at sea in deep water where the pressure/threat from INIS is less relevant) or accidental discharge of ballast water (e.g. in the event of an incident that affects the ships structure) may also result in the transfer of INIS to new locations. There is concern that the expansion of non-indigenous species could alter local biodiversity and sometimes compete with native species, some of which are of commercial interest.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text). The risk of introducing new species may also increase with the range of vessel/boat activity – e.g. travelling from locations outside the UK.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Extraction of genetic resources e.g. bioprospecting (also see other related activities in fishing and dredging)
column5: The extraction of genetic resources from the marine environment is an area of growing interest, especially in the deep sea [JNCC0340] and the use of marine organisms such as Porifera and Cnidaria for development of medicines can create value in previously non-commercial species [JNCC0340; JNCC0341]. Thousands of marine species have been collected for initial assessment but usually only in very small amounts. Few compounds are sufficiently promising to provoke re-collections where volumes can be larger, which may raise conservation concern, especially if the organism is rare, has a restricted distribution or is targeted in one small area [JNCC0342]. Some marine bioprospecting resources have been over collected (e.g. cone shells; non-UK species), however the limited information available suggests that marine bioprospecting impacts on the environment are minimal, at least compared with other human activities [JNCC0342; JNCC0343]. Furthermore, in general industry avoid dependency on small or restricted populations for economic and ecological reasons [JNCC0342].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column3: Extraction of genetic resources e.g. bioprospecting (also see other related activities in fishing and dredging)
column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Pressure primarily relates to vessels associated with this activity. Transition elements and organo-metals are used as marine anti-fouling agents on vessels. Historically the main ingredients in biocidal antifouling coatings have been copper or tributyltin (TBT; banned on vessels under 25 m in the UK since 1987 and all vessels since 2008). Since then biocides commonly used in the UK in antifoulants include Copper(I) oxide (cuprous oxide), Copper thiocyanate, Zinc pyrithione and ZineB (organosulfur compound) [JNCC0204; JNCC0326]. Antifouling compounds like TBT and copper wash from ship coatings enter and persist in the marine environment, with highest concentrations generally found in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3164; 3155; 4915].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Extraction of genetic resources e.g. bioprospecting (also see other related activities in fishing and dredging)
column5: Pressure relates to the use and movement of vessels for this activity. Vessel movement is an important source of underwater noise, with noise emitted typically varying with vessel size whereby larger vessels generate lower frequency sound. Although propeller cavitation is the main source of such noise, gear operation and turbulence around the hull will also result in noise being transmitted underwater by vessels [3152; 3096; 4921]. For example, the source levels associated with small sea going vessels are typically 160-180 dB re 1 µPa-m (RMS) [3152]. Underwater noise can result in disturbance particularly to mobile receptors such as fish, birds and mammals [3152; 4921; 2074; 3069; 4869].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column3: Extraction of genetic resources e.g. bioprospecting (also see other related activities in fishing and dredging)
column5: This pressure is associated with the use of a vessel. The movement of vessels and people, as well as that of gear, can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as fish, marine mammals, seabirds and coastal birds. However, the magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity, plus other factors such as species present and age, weather conditions and degree of habituation to disturbance source [2497; 2825; 3269; 2707; 4977].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. The risk increases if bird species are especially sensitive eg red throated diver.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column5: Noise arises from many activities in the marine environment [3227]. The presence of people, as well as vessels and all-terrain vehicles used to access species, may result in an increase in above water noise. However, the magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: Pressure would be exerted on intertidal habitats through harvesting of target species by hand or with apparatus such as rakes and forks. Further, abrasion is associated with the movement of people ('trampling') or indeed any vehicles used for access or participation in the harvesting activity (e.g. tractors or JCBs), and can result in damage to infauna and epifauna as well as sensitive habitats such as seagrass [1419; 1436; 4480; JNCC0345; JNCC0346]. Where vessels are used to provide access, the pressure is likely to be associated with any anchors, which can cause damage to the seabed surface and subsurface layers upon deployment/recovery and due to dragging [4971], or the vessel (including e.g. the propeller/wash) itself may cause abrasion if it comes into contact with the seabed in shallow water.  Mechanised harvesting of seaweeds (namely trawling/sledging/dredging) operate in areas of rocky substrate and therefore differ from other forms of dredging (e.g. scallop dredging) that physically disturb the underlying substrate [JNCC0345]. The magnitude will depend on a number of factors, including the harvesting method, the amount harvested, the duration of harvesting and the nature of the seabed (soft/hard).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Pressure relates to vessels associated with this activity and their movement. Marine birds are frequently attracted to or become disorientated by artificial light sources, which can result in collision and therefore injury or death [4378; 2826]. Bird collisions with vessels, including fishing vessels [2826], have been recorded with the risk being greatest at night for lighted ships near coastal areas and when the vessel is relatively close to large breeding aggregations of seabirds (rather than further offshore). However, there are relatively few sources of quantified information relating to seabird strikes on vessels. Nocturnal bird strikes on vessels tend to occur when bright, artificial light sources are used at times of poor visibility, typically during bad weather, often angled outwards or upwards from the vessel [4466; 4378; 4337].   However, it is anticipated that this activity would primarily be undertaken during daylight hours.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). The pressure is particularly associated with lit vessels/structures and so the prevalence of this may increase the risk (as will records of past collisions).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: This pressure relates to vessels associated with this activity and their movement. Vessels are documented to have collided with mobile marine species (particularly marine mammals but also fish and seabirds). Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120; 4987].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column5: Intensive bait digging can result in exposure of anoxic sediment layers [4447], leading to reduced oxygen availability in surface sediments. High numbers of structures associated with activities such as crab tiling may change patterns of water movement over intertidal habitats and hence changes in sediment characteristics, such as a shallower oxygenated zone [1441]. The spatial and temporal persistence of any change will depend on factors such as the intensity of the activity and levels of natural disturbance.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column4: Habitat structure changes - removal of substratum (extraction)
column5: Activities such as bait digging could cause this pressure through the displacement/removal of intertidal substrate [1441]. However, the magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity. Seaweed harvesting activities will not result in this pressure as they take place on harder rocky seabed and therefore do not involve the removal of substrate [JNCC0345].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: This pressure primarily relates to vessels associated with this activity and their movement. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) [JNCC0294]. Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled annually by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that lead to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers) [3164].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column5: The pressure is potentially associated with navigation and operational lighting on vessels involved in harvesting activities. Under the Merchant Shipping (Distress Signals and Prevention of Collisions) Regulations 1996 all vessels in the UK must display lights in all weathers between sunset and sunrise including masthead lighting, sidelights, sternlights, towing lighting, all-round light and flash light [JNCC0254]. Lighting can affect marine species (namely birds and fish). Marine birds are frequently attracted to or become disorientated by artificial light sources, which can result in collision and therefore injury or death [4378; 2826]. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083; 3088; 3195; 2797; 3107; 4334; 4339]. Artificial light can repel or attract fish, which in turn can influence their foraging and schooling behaviour, spatial distribution, predation risk, migration and reproduction [4378]. However, it is anticipated that this activity would primarily be undertaken during daylight hours.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: The removal of native seaweeds could provide opportunity for the establishment of non-native seaweeds which could pose a threat to native species [JNCC0347]. As non-native species are difficult to eradicate, their introduction may permanently change the character of a habitat [JNCC0348; JNCC0347], having implications for those species which rely on seaweeds to provide habitat, shelter and food. Areas most vulnerable to the introduction of non-native seaweeds are likely to be brackish and sheltered waters [JNCC0345]. This pressure also relates to use of a vessel for harvesting activities. The surfaces and ballast water of these vessels/vehicles could transport INIS. Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling on vessels and gear and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur [3164; 3132; 2798; 4338; 4339]. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978; 5177]. Thousands of marine species can also be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164; 3070].  The vessels involved in this activity are generally likely to be making short/local journeys and therefore the likelihood of this pressure occurring is considered to be very low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text). The risk of introducing new species may also increase with the range of vessel/boat activity – e.g. travelling from locations outside the UK.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column5: Marine litter is items made or used by people and deliberately discarded or unintentionally lost into the sea and on beaches. Despite international legislation such as Annex V of the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973 [3140], maritime activity is still a major source of litter. Alongside existing legislation, potential mitigation measures are discussed in various sources of literature [2752; 3160; JNCC0239]. The use of vessels for harvesting seaweed could cause litter. Some discharges may contain floating waste [3126; 3139; 4401]. Marine litter can be released into the marine environment by shipping vessels, either accidentally (inappropriate storage) or deliberately [4974; 3160]. Shipping litter includes pallets, strapping bans and drums. Cargo may also be washed overboard during stormy weather and contribute to coastal litter levels. Shipping related litter contributes approximately 2 % of the litter found on UK beaches. Shipping related litter contributed approximately 45 litter items per kilometre around the UK on average between 2003 and 2007 [4915; 3160]. The size and number of vessels that are involved in seaweed harvesting are small and therefore likely to result in a low scale/likelihood of litter entering the marine environment.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column5: Seaweeds have an important role in nutrient cycling [JNCC0345]. The removal of seaweeds by harvesting may therefore have implications for nutrient cycling. Large accumulations of beach-cast seaweeds can occur along the coastline creating a source of recycled nutrients, which can be of benefit to the local ecology of nearshore habitats [JNCC0349; JNCC0350; JNCC0351]. The removal of beach cast seaweed by harvesting activities would therefore remove this source of nutrients. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column5: Seaweeds have an important role in inputting detritus and dissolved organic matter (DOM) into the ecosystem and supporting the marine food web [JNCC0345; JNCC0353]. The removal of seaweeds by harvesting may therefore have implications for this secondary production. Beach-cast seaweed and associated particulate organic matter play a central role in sandy beach food webs [JNCC0351]. As beach-cast seaweed rots on the shore, it provides food in the form of organic matter for a range of invertebrates [JNCC0354; JNCC0351]. Large accumulations of beach-cast seaweeds can occur along the coastline creating a source of detrital material, which can be of benefit to the local ecology of nearshore habitats [JNCC0349; JNCC0350; JNCC0351]. The removal of beach cast seaweed by harvesting activities would therefore remove this source of organic matter. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: Pressure would be exerted on intertidal habitats through harvesting of target species by hand or with apparatus such as rakes and forks. Further, abrasion is associated with the movement of people ('trampling') or indeed any vehicles used for access or participation in the harvesting activity (e.g. tractors or JCBs), and can result in damage to infauna and epifauna as well as sensitive habitats such as seagrass [1419; 1436; 4480; JNCC0345; JNCC0346]. Where vessels are used to provide access, the pressure is likely to be associated with any anchors, which can cause damage to the seabed surface and subsurface layers upon deployment/recovery and due to dragging [4971], or the vessel (including e.g. the propeller/wash) itself may cause abrasion if it comes into contact with the seabed in shallow water. Mechanised harvesting of seaweeds (namely trawling/sledging/dredging) operate in areas of rocky substrate and therefore differ from other forms of dredging (e.g. scallop dredging) that physically disturb the underlying substrate [JNCC0345]. The magnitude will depend on a number of factors, including the harvesting method, the amount harvested, the duration of harvesting and the nature of the seabed (soft/hard).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column5: Seaweeds provide a complex habitat structure for many species of marine algae, plants and animals [JNCC0345]. Various marine fauna occupy areas on the holdfast, stipe and fronds of seaweeds [JNCC0365]. For example, the holdfast of larger kelp species is capable of supporting a very large number of species and a diverse range of species assemblages [JNCC0361; JNCC0362]. As beach-cast seaweed rots on the shore, it provides shelter for a range of invertebrates  [JNCC0354; JNCC0351]. Harvesting can result in the bycatch of invertebrate/algae species living on or adjacent to the targeted seaweed species. Hand cutting/picking or gathering is more selective and therefore will involve removing less non-target species than mechanical harvesting/gathering which is more indiscriminate. Bait digging can result in bycatch of fish, invertebrates and birds [1419; 1436; 1441; 4409]. The scale/magnitude of the pressure will depend on a number of factors, including the harvesting method, intensity and location.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column5: Harvesting activities target a range of species. The targeted species may themselves be of conservation importance, or may form part of a biotope or the wider community composition associated with designated features/sub-features [1419; 1436; 4362; JNCC0345].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Pressure primarily relates to vessels associated with this activity and their movement. Transition elements and organo-metals are used as marine anti-fouling agents on vessels. Historically the main ingredients in biocidal antifouling coatings have been copper or tributyltin (TBT). TBT has been banned on vessels under 25 m in the UK since 1987. Since then biocides commonly used in the UK in antifoulants include Copper(I) oxide (cuprous oxide), Copper thiocyanate, Zinc pyrithione and ZineB (organosulfur compound) [JNCC0204; JNCC0326]. The size and number of vessels involved in this activity are very low and therefore the scale and likelihood of this pressure is considered to be very low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column5: This activity may involve use of a vessel. Generally, the larger the vessel the more dominant the low frequency sounds which travel farther and have the potential of impacting larger areas [3164; 4921; 4995; 5173]. Small sea going vessels typically produce broadband noise at source levels of 160-180 dB re 1µPa-m (RMS) [4908; 4915].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column5: Harvesting and bait digging activities including vehicle movement and people presence and movement can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as fish, marine mammals, seabirds and coastal birds [1441; 2497; 2763; 3134; 3154; 3106].  The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity, plus other factors such as weather conditions [5106; 5117; 4977].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Some species of seaweed (e.g. kelp) have the ability to modify their local environment by altering water flow and sedimentation rates [JNCC0345; JNCC0356]. Kelp habitats are able to attenuate current flow, an effect which can range from the seabed up to twice the height of the kelp [JNCC0356]. The harvesting of these species, therefore, will result in a change in local water flow and sediment transport. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale and intensity of the activity.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Harvesting - seaweed and other sea-based food (bird eggs, shellfish, etc.)
column5: Some species of seaweed (e.g. kelp) have the ability to modify their local environment by dissipating wave energy [JNCC0345; JNCC0357]. Harvesting, could result in the loss of the wave damping effects of seaweed which may result in increases in coastal erosion and/or flooding events [JNCC0345]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale and intensity of the activity.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Outfall and intake pipe construction and repair require the use of vehicles and shipping all of which emit above water noise. Noise can arise from many activities in the marine environment [3164]. The use of machinery, vessels, and explosives as well as the presence of people will result in an increase of above water noise. Sources of airborne noise that might be involved in pipe construction include piling [1329; 3082]. The magnitude of pressure will depend on the scale, intensity and duration of the activity.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: Outfall and intake pipes are installed onto or into the seabed. This requires the movement of heavy machinery and vehicles across the surface of the seabed or coastal habitat and potentially also excavation/dredging works which can lead to abrasion/disturbance [3139; 4403; JNCC0332]. Onshore discharges that cross the foreshore have the potential to scour the seabed, especially across mudflats [JNCC0322].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Coastal development, including pipeline construction, can result in barriers to species movement through increased noise (e.g. construction, shipping, acoustic deterrents), lighting, presence of structures, changes to water quality and suspended sediments [2817; 3085; 3096; 3106; 3195; 2763; 3111; 3149; 2834; 3151]. The noise and turbidity arising from dredging operations, which may be required during pipeline construction, may pose a barrier to migration when occurring on or in proximity of specific migratory routes [3152; 3080; 2757]. The scale of the impact will depend on scale of activity and the location and will need to be considered on a case-by-case basis to determine relevance to given feature/site.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Outfall and intake pipe construction can involve activities (e.g. excavation/dredging works) which create suspended sediment plumes [3126; 4401; 4440; 4403; 3139]. Onshore discharges that cross the foreshore have the potential to scour the seabed, especially across mudflats [JNCC0322] resulting in localised plumes of suspended sediment.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Intake pipes from the marine environment can result in the entrainment or impingement of fish (adult and larvae), birds and marine mammals [4443; 4402].  Outflow and intake pipe construction and repair may require the use and movement of vessels. Vessels are documented to have collided with mobile marine species (particularly marine mammals but also fish and seabirds). Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120; 4987]. A lack of information exists regarding collision risk of animals (e.g. birds, fish, marine mammals) with underwater structures, especially for birds. The response of birds will depend on their detection of a device and any associated structures. The risk of collision may be increased if the devices alter the characteristics of the current, especially if such changes create new foraging opportunities, since this may impact on the manoeuvrability and underwater swimming agility of birds [4959; 5075]. Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Intake pipes in the marine environment can result in the entrainment or impingement of fish (adult and larvae), birds and marine mammals [4443; 4402].  Outflow and intake pipe construction and repair may require the use and movement of vessels. Vessels are documented to have collided with mobile marine species (particularly marine mammals but also fish and seabirds). Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120; 4987].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Genetic modification & translocation of indigenous species
column5: The construction and maintenance of outfall and intake pipes will involve vessels travelling to the site from a number of other locations. The surfaces and ballast water of these vessels/vehicles could translocate native species. Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978; 5177]. Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164; 3070]. The vessels involved in outflow/intake construction and/or maintenance are generally likely to be making short/local journeys and therefore the likelihood of this pressure occurring is considered to be very low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Habitat structure changes - removal of substratum (extraction)
column5: Pipelines can be installed onto or into the seabed. Where they are buried, trench excavation into the sediment will be required [3139; 4403]. Abstracted water can contain particulate matter and the pumping of 1 mg/l suspended solids in 20 l/s of water during one year will result in the removal of over 0.6 tonnes of ground. It is generally recommended therefore that the content of particulate matter in abstracted water is minimised to prevent the risk of ground settlement [JNCC0225].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Outflow/intake pipe construction and repair require the use of vehicles and shipping all of which have the potential to release vessel oil and fuel (comprising PAHs) into the marine environment. Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). If the site is contaminated, there is a risk that drilling or excavation for heat abstraction loops, could lead to pollution of groundwater or migration of contaminants [JNCC0225].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: The pressure is potentially associated with navigation and operational lighting on vessels involved in outflow/intake pipe construction and repair/maintenance. Under the Merchant Shipping (Distress Signals and Prevention of Collisions) Regulations 1996 all vessels in the UK must display lights in all weathers between sunset and sunrise including masthead lighting, sidelights, sternlights, towing lighting, all-round light and flash light [JNCC0254]. Lighting can affect marine species (namely birds and fish). Marine birds are frequently attracted to or become disorientated by artificial light sources, which can result in collision and therefore injury or death [4378; 2826]. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083; 3088; 3195; 2797; 3107; 4334; 4339]. Artificial light can repel or attract fish, which in turn can influence their foraging and schooling behaviour, spatial distribution, predation risk, migration and reproduction [4378].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: This pressure relates to use of a vessels during construction and maintenance/repair work on outflow/intake pipes. The surfaces and ballast water of these vessels/vehicles could transport INIS. Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling on vessels and gear and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur [3164; 3132; 2798; 4338; 4339]. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978; 5177]. Thousands of marine species can also be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164; 3070]. The vessels involved in outflow/intake construction and/or maintenance are generally likely to be making short/local journeys and therefore the likelihood of this pressure occurring is considered to be very low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text). The risk of introducing new species may also increase with the range of vessel/boat activity – e.g. travelling from locations outside the UK.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: The construction and maintenance phase of an outflow/intake pipe may require a number of vessels and vehicles in the marine environment which could cause litter. Some discharges may contain floating waste [3126; 3139; 4401]. Marine litter can be released into the marine environment by shipping vessels, either accidentally (inappropriate storage) or deliberately [4974; 3160]. Shipping litter includes pallets, strapping bans and drums. Cargo may also be washed overboard during stormy weather and contribute to coastal litter levels. Shipping related litter contributes approximately 2 % of the litter found on UK beaches. Shipping related litter contributed approximately 45 litter items per kilometre around the UK on average between 2003 and 2007 [4915; 3160]. The vessels involved in outflow/intake construction and/or maintenance are relatively small to moderate in size and only likely to be making short journeys. The likelihood of this pressure occurring is therefore considered to be low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: This pressure can result during any excavation/dredging works involved in the construction of intake/outflow pipes. The mobilisation of sediment will result in an increase in suspended sediments and the release of organic matter and nutrients  [3145; 5121]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899]. The magnitude of pressure depends on intensity/scale of activity and hydrographic conditions [2834; 3276; 3198; 4939].

column5: This pressure can result during any excavation/dredging works involved in the construction of intake/outflow pipes. Sediment mobilisation during dredging can increase the levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145; 5121; 3139; 4401; 4403]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899]. The magnitude of pressure would depend on intensity/scale of activity and hydrographic conditions [2834; 3276; 3198; 4939].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: Pipelines can be installed onto or into the seabed. This requires the movement of heavy machinery and vehicles across the surface of the seabed or coastal habitat and potentially also excavation/dredging works which can lead to abrasion/disturbance [3139; 4403; JNCC0332].   During construction and maintenance vessel anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying the anchor and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery.  The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials. For example, for an 11.5 tonne anchor penetration of up to 0.88 m occurred in soft sediment when the anchor was dropped and dragged 87 m [4971]. There is a tendency for the anchor to penetrate to deep depths in softer sediment as the opening of the anchor flukes prevents deep penetration in harder sediment [5076].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: The seabed currents and the type of sediment will affect the accumulation and scouring of the sediment around the outfall/intake pipe [5004].

column4: Physical loss (to land or freshwater habitat)
column5: Where outflow pipes are buried, trench excavation will be required which will remove the existing habitat and if not fully reinstated this could result in habitat loss. Rock armouring may also be placed over the pipe resulting in a loss in habitat [3139].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Pipeline installation can create suspended sediment plumes and local smothering [3126; 4401; 4440; 4403; 3139]. During operation, the presence of pipeline structures on the seabed surface can induce changes in hydrodynamics which can cause increased siltation [3139; 4403].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Synthetic compound contamination (incl. pesticides, antifoulants, pharmaceuticals).  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Discharge from heat abstraction exchanger outflow pipes can contain pollutants (e.g. anti-freeze, biocide, corrosion and scale inhibitors) [JNCC0225]. Whilst heavily regulated there is a risk of damaging concentrations being released were issues to arise [3126; 4401; 4403].

column5: Discharges from outfall pipes from heat abstraction exchangers can enter the marine environment at a range of reduced temperatures (2°C to 7°C cooler) and potentially decrease local environmental temperatures [JNCC0229; JNCC0230].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Transition elements and organo-metals are used as marine anti-fouling agents on vessels. Historically the main ingredients in biocidal antifouling coatings have been copper or tributyltin (TBT). TBT has been banned on vessels under 25 m in the UK since 1987. Since then biocides commonly used in the UK in antifoulants include Copper(I) oxide (cuprous oxide), Copper thiocyanate, Zinc pyrithione and ZineB (organosulfur compound) [JNCC0204; JNCC0326]. The number of vessels involved in this activity are very low and therefore the scale and likelihood of this pressure is considered to be very low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Vessels and machinery used during the construction phase will increase noise levels. Shipping is an important source of underwater noise. Although the majority of this will come from the propeller cavitation, onboard machinery and turbulence around the hull can also result in underwater noise being transmitted underwater. Different parts of the vessel and different vessels emit at different frequencies. Generally, lower frequency with increasing size. Low frequency sounds generally travel farther and have the potential of impacting larger areas [3164; 4921; 4995; 5173]. Dredgers involved in any excavation/trench works during pipe instalment will also generate elevated underwater noise [JNCC0319].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: The construction and maintenance/repair of outfall/intake pipes will involve the movement of vessels, vehicles and people which can create visual stimuli that evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as marine mammals, fish and birds [5106; 5117]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity plus other factors such as weather conditions [2497; 2825; 3091; 3269; 2707; 4977]. The number of vessels involved in this activity are very low and therefore the scale and likelihood of this pressure is considered to be very low.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Pipeline structures sitting proud of the seabed surface can induce changes in hydrodynamics specifically altering tidal flow direction and velocity [3091].

column5: Outfall structures may affect local wave conditions by causing reflection, refraction and breaking of waves. This could increase or decrease wave energy in nearby areas [3161; 4403].

column5: Marine archaeological research involves the use of vessels and people which can result in an increase in above water noise. Noise from many activities in the marine environment can evoke a disturbance response in marine mammals and birds [2825; 3269; 3227; 2074; 4869]. However, the magnitude of pressure would depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity.

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: The pressure could result from the physical removal of artefacts, contact between gear and the seabed and also anchoring associated with the activity. A range of hand tools and machinery are used to excavate artefacts underwater [JNCC0363]. These include hand trowels and a hose attached to a dredge engine that sucks the seafloor sediments onto a floating screen deck for examination of artefacts [JNCC0363]. The scale of the impact will depend on the nature, location and scale of the activity but is likely to be localised and short-lived.

column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Marine archaeological research involves the use and movement of vessels. Marine birds are frequently attracted to or become disorientated by artificial light sources, which can result in collision and therefore injury or death [4378; 2826]. Bird collisions with vessels, including fishing vessels [2826], have been recorded with the risk being greatest at night for lighted ships near coastal areas and when the vessel is relatively close to large breeding aggregations of seabirds (rather than further offshore). However, there are relatively few sources of quantified information relating to seabird strikes on vessels. Nocturnal bird strikes on vessels tend to occur when bright, artificial light sources are used at times of poor visibility, typically during bad weather, often angled outwards or upwards from the vessel [4466; 4378; 4337].

Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120; 4987].

column5: The pressure is associated with sediment mobilisation and increase of suspended sediments as well as the deposition of organic matter. The removal of artefacts and/or use of vessels may disturb sediment and result in localised changes in oxygen levels. The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the dynamic nature of the area, the temperature and the sediment type, making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891].

column5: The pressure primarily relates to vessels associated with this activity and their movement. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers) [3096; 3164; 3194; 4985].

column5: This pressure relates to the use of a vessel for this activity. Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling on vessels and gear and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur [3164; 3132; 2798; 4338; 4339]. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978; 5177]. Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164; 3070].
