column5: This pressure relates to the use of a vessel for this activity. Marine litter can be released into the marine environment by shipping vessels including cargo, bulk carrier, military, surveillance, research, passenger ships and non-commercial vessels, either accidentally (inappropriate storage) or deliberately [4974; 3160]. Shipping litter includes pallets, strapping bans and drums, as well as litter derived from containers lost at sea. Cargo may also be washed overboard during stormy weather and contribute to coastal litter levels. Shipping related litter contributes approximately 2 % of the litter found on UK beaches. Shipping related litter contributed approximately 45 litter items per kilometre around the UK on average between 2003 and 2007 [4915; 3160]. The vessels involved in marine archaeological research are relatively small in size and only likely to be making short journeys. The likelihood of this pressure occurring is therefore considered to be low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: The pressure would result from the physical removal of artefacts (using machinery, tools or by hand), contact between gear and the seabed and also anchoring associated with the activity. Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying the anchor and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery. Mooring chains from swinging moorings may scour the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide. The anchors of large vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed up to 1 m, but of course depth of penetration by smaller inshore vessel anchors is expected to be less [4971].  Small vessel anchors have been found to cause surface ‘scars’ of typically 1-4 m2 [5175].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: This pressure relates to the use of a vessel. Propellers from ships can cause localised scour of the seabed around the berth pockets in port locations [5174]. Ship movements can also result in erosion at the margins of the channel [3145]. Vessels involved in marine archaeological research are generally small and therefore unlikely to result in any significant disturbance of sediments from channel margins.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: The pressure primarily relates to vessels associated with this activity and their movement. TBT has been banned on vessels under 25 m in the UK since 1987 and all vessels since 2008. Since then biocides commonly used in the UK in antifoulants include Copper(I) oxide (cuprous oxide), Copper thiocyanate, Zinc pyrithione and ZineB (organosulfur compound) [JNCC0204; 4985]. Antifouling compounds like TBT and copper wash from ship coatings with larger concentrations in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3032; 3096; 3107; 3164; 4333; 4985]. The number of vessels involved in this activity are very low and therefore the scale and likelihood of this pressure is considered to be very low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Marine archaeological research involves the use and movement of vessels. Vessel movement is an important source of underwater noise, with noise emitted typically varying with vessel size whereby larger vessels generate lower frequency sound. Although propeller cavitation is the main source of such noise, gear operation and turbulence around the hull will also result in noise being transmitted underwater by vessels [3152; 3096; 4921]. For example, the source levels associated with small sea going vessels are typically 160-180 dB re 1 µPa-m (RMS) [3152]. Underwater noise can result in disturbance particularly to mobile receptors such as fish, birds and mammals [3152; 4921; 2074; 3069; 4869].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: This activity will involve the movement of vessels which can create visual stimuli that evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as marine mammals, fish and birds [5106; 5117]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity plus other factors such as weather conditions [2497; 2825; 3091; 3269; 2707; 4977]. The number of vessels involved in this activity are very low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column5: Outflow pipe construction and repair require the use of vehicles and shipping all of which emit above water noise. Airborne noise can arise from many activities in the marine environment [3164]. The use of machinery, vessels, explosives and people will result in an increase of above water noise. Sources of airborne noise that might be involved in pipe construction include piling [1329; 3082]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the scale, intensity and duration of the activity.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: Outflow pipes are generally installed onto or into the seabed. This can require the movement of heavy machinery and vehicles across the surface of the seabed or coastal habitat and potentially also excavation/dredging works which can lead to abrasion/disturbance [3139; 4403; JNCC0332]. Outfalls are often located in bored tunnels so there is little disturbance except where outfall penetrates above surface at discharge point. The scale and magnitude of the pressure will depend on the method of construction. Onshore discharges that cross the foreshore have the potential to scour the seabed, especially across mudflats [JNCC0322].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column5: Coastal development, including pipeline construction, can result in barriers to species movement through increased noise (e.g. construction, shipping, acoustic deterrents), lighting, presence of structures, changes to water quality and suspended sediments [2817; 3085; 3096; 3106; 3195; 2763; 3111; 3149; 2834; 3151]. The noise and turbidity arising from dredging operations, which may be required during pipeline construction, may pose a barrier to migration when occurring on or in proximity of specific migratory routes [3152; 3080; 2757]. The scale of the impact will depend on the scale of the activity and the location and will need to be considered on a case-by-case basis to determine relevance to a given feature/site. Onshore thermal discharges that cross the foreshore have the potential to displace longshore-migrating fish or other biota into deeper water (sometimes known as the "travelator effect") [JNCC0322]. This is most likely to affect juvenile fish such as glass eels or flounder, which ascend estuaries along the margins using selective tidal stream transport [JNCC0322]. Thermal plumes are regulated and therefore the scale of change is considered to be low.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column5: Outflow pipe construction can involve activities (e.g. excavation/dredging works) which create suspended sediment plumes [3126; 4401; 4440; 4403; 3139]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the construction method. Onshore discharges that cross the foreshore have the potential to scour the seabed, especially across mudflats [JNCC0322] resulting in localised plumes of suspended sediment.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Outflow pipe construction and repair may require the use and movement of vessels. Marine birds are frequently attracted to or become disorientated by artificial light sources, which can result in collision and therefore injury or death [4378; 2826]. Bird collisions with vessels, including fishing vessels [2826], have been recorded with the risk being greatest at night for lighted ships near coastal areas and when the vessel is relatively close to large breeding aggregations of seabirds (rather than further offshore). However, there are relatively few sources of quantified information relating to seabird strikes on vessels. Nocturnal bird strikes on vessels tend to occur when bright, artificial light sources are used at times of poor visibility, typically during bad weather, often angled outwards or upwards from the vessel [4466; 4378; 4337].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Outflow pipe construction and repair may require the use and movement of vessels. Vessels are documented to have collided with mobile marine species (particularly marine mammals but also fish and seabirds). Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120; 4987]. A lack of information exists regarding collision risk of animals (e.g. birds, fish, marine mammals) with underwater structures, especially for birds. The response of birds will depend on their detection of a device and any associated structures. The risk of collision may be increased if the devices alter the characteristics of the current, especially if such changes create new foraging opportunities, since this may impact on the manoeuvrability and underwater swimming agility of birds [4959; 5075]. Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column5: Dissolved oxygen (DO) levels in waters receiving a thermal discharge can be reduced in two ways; firstly, the solubility of oxygen in seawater depends primarily on salinity and temperature so raising the temperature will lower the oxygen solubility; however, this will only affect the DO level when the ambient level is at or close to saturation and secondly, the biological and chemical oxygen demand is accelerated at higher temperatures [JNCC0322]. These are most likely to be of concern in polluted waters, particularly in estuarine environments. The depletion of DO in thermal discharge zones of any UK nuclear plants has not been a notable concern in the past [JNCC0226]. The pressure is also associated with sediment mobilisation and increase of suspended sediments as well as the deposition of organic matter. The pressure can therefore result from outflow pipe construction during any excavation/dredging works as well as the outflow during operation [3161; 3164]. The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the dynamic nature of the area, the temperature and the sediment type, making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column4: Genetic modification & translocation of indigenous species
column5: The construction and maintenance of outflow pipes will involve vessels travelling to the site from a number of other locations. The surfaces and ballast water of these vessels/vehicles could translocate native species. Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978; 5177]. Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164; 3070]. The vessels involved in outflow pipe construction/maintenance are generally likely to be making short/local journeys and therefore the likelihood of this pressure occurring is considered to be very low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column4: Habitat structure changes - removal of substratum (extraction)
column5: Outflow pipes are either buried or surface laid across coastal and seabed habitats. Where they are buried, trench excavation into the sediment will be required [3139; 4403]. Outfalls can also be bored tunnels resulting in little disturbance of seabed except at discharge point.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Outflow pipe construction and repair require the use of vehicles and shipping all of which have the potential to release vessel oil and fuel (comprising PAHs) into the marine environment. Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers).
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column5: The pressure is potentially associated with navigation and operational lighting on vessels involved in outflow pipe construction and repair/maintenance. Under the Merchant Shipping (Distress Signals and Prevention of Collisions) Regulations 1996 all vessels in the UK must display lights in all weathers between sunset and sunrise including masthead lighting, sidelights, sternlights, towing lighting, all-round light and flash light [JNCC0254]. Lighting can affect marine species (namely birds and fish). Marine birds are frequently attracted to or become disorientated by artificial light sources, which can result in collision and therefore injury or death [4378; 2826]. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083; 3088; 3195; 2797; 3107; 4334; 4339]. Artificial light can repel or attract fish, which in turn can influence their foraging and schooling behaviour, spatial distribution, predation risk, migration and reproduction [4378].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column4: Introduction of other substances (solid, liquid or gas)
column5: Outflow pipes from power stations discharge a range of substances into the marine environment [3126; 4401]. These include contaminants (residual oxidants, by-products from use of biocides and radionuclides) and heated water [3126]. Whilst heavily regulated, there is a risk of damaging concentrations of contaminants being released were issues to arise [3126; 4401; 4403; JNCC0322]. Nuclear licensed sites in the UK discharge radioactive waste as liquid and/or gas as part of their operations. However, levels are well below dose limits enforced to protect the public [JNCC0218].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: This pressure relates to use of a vessels during construction and maintenance/repair work on outflow pipes. The surfaces and ballast water of these vessels/vehicles could transport INIS. Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling on vessels and gear and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur [3164; 3132; 2798; 4338; 4339]. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978; 5177]. Thousands of marine species can also be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164; 3070]. The vessels involved in outflow pipe construction/maintenance are generally likely to be making short/local journeys and therefore the likelihood of this pressure occurring is considered to be very low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text). The risk of introducing new species may also increase with the range of vessel/boat activity – e.g. travelling from locations outside the UK.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column5: The construction and maintenance phase of an outflow pipe may require a number of vessels and vehicles in the marine environment which could cause litter. Some discharges may contain floating waste [3126; 3139; 4401]. Marine litter can be released into the marine environment by shipping vessels, either accidentally (inappropriate storage) or deliberately [4974; 3160]. Shipping litter includes pallets, strapping bans and drums. Cargo may also be washed overboard during stormy weather and contribute to coastal litter levels. Shipping related litter contributes approximately 2 % of the litter found on UK beaches. Shipping related litter contributed approximately 45 litter items per kilometre around the UK on average between 2003 and 2007 [4915; 3160]. The vessels involved in outflow pipe construction and/or maintenance are relatively small to moderate in size and only likely to be making short journeys. The likelihood of this pressure occurring is therefore considered to be low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column5: Higher water temperatures may accelerate nutrient cycling and growth rates of algae. This may raise concerns over development of eutrophic algal blooms, including those of toxic species. Development of large mats of blue-green algae around the Turkey Point plant outfall in Florida was associated with the thermal discharge but blue-greens favour temperatures in the mid-thirties Celsius and are therefore unlikely to develop in UK coastal waters where µT values are kept below the WFD uplift standard of 3°C [JNCC0322]. This pressure can also result during any excavation/dredging works involved in the construction of outflow pipes [3161; 3164]. The mobilisation of sediment will result in an increase in suspended sediments and the release of organic matter and nutrients  [3145; 5121]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899]. The magnitude of pressure depends on intensity/scale of activity and hydrographic conditions [2834; 3276; 3198; 4939].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column5: This pressure can result during any excavation/dredging works involved in the construction of outflow pipes. Sediment mobilisation during dredging can increase the levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145; 5121; 3139; 4401; 4403]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899]. The magnitude of pressure would depend on intensity/scale of activity and hydrographic conditions [2834; 3276; 3198; 4939].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: Outflow pipes are either buried or surface laid across coastal and seabed habitats. This requires the movement of heavy machinery and vehicles across the surface of the surface of the seabed or coastal habitat and potentially also excavation/dredging works which can lead to abrasion/disturbance [3139; 4403; JNCC0332]. Outfalls can also be constructed by bored tunnels with little disturbance of seabed except at the discharge point. During construction and maintenance, vessel anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying the anchor and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery.  The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials. For example, for an 11.5 tonne anchor penetration of up to 0.88 m occurred in soft sediment when the anchor was dropped and dragged 87 m [4971]. There is a tendency for the anchor to penetrate to deep depths in softer sediment as the opening of the anchor flukes prevents deep penetration in harder sediment [5076].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column5: The seabed currents and the type of sediment will affect the accumulation and scouring of the sediment around the outflow pipe [5004]. If the outflow pipe is laid on the surface then this will result in the introduction of hard substrata.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column4: Physical loss (to land or freshwater habitat)
column5: Where outflow pipes are buried, trench excavation will be required which will remove the existing habitat and if not fully reinstated this could result in habitat loss. Rock armouring may also be placed over the pipe resulting in a loss in habitat [3139]. Outfalls can also be constructed by bored tunnels with little disturbance of seabed except at the discharge point.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column5: Outflow from power stations may represent a source of radionuclide contamination [3126; 4442]. Nuclear licensed sites in the UK discharge radioactive waste as liquid and/or gas as part of their operations. However, levels are well below dose limits enforced to protect the public [JNCC0218].

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column5: Salinity decrease associated with cooling water discharge could arise from: discharge of cooling water abstracted from a region where salinity is lower than that of the receiving water. The associated salinity decrease is likely to be small and undetectable beyond the mixing zone [JNCC0226; JNCC0322].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column5: Salinity increase associated with cooling water discharge could arise from: discharge of cooling water abstracted from a region where salinity is higher than that of the receiving water; concentration of salts in purge water from seawater cooling towers (indirect cooling only); and/or concentration of salts within any desalination facility provided to supply freshwater to the site. In any of these cases the associated salinity change would be small and unlikely to be detectable beyond the mixing zone [JNCC0226; JNCC0322].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column5: Pipeline construction can create suspended sediment plumes and local smothering depending on the construction method [3126; 4401; 4440; 4403; 3139]. During operation, the presence of pipeline structures on the seabed surface can induce changes in hydrodynamics which can cause increased siltation [3139; 4403].

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column4: Synthetic compound contamination (incl. pesticides, antifoulants, pharmaceuticals).  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Discharge from power station outflow pipes contain residual oxidants and by-products from use of biocides (mainly chlorine-based) in the receiving water bodies. Whilst heavily regulated, there is a risk of damaging concentrations being released were issues to arise [3126; 4401; 4403; JNCC0322].

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column5:
Electric power plants require cooling water to complete the steam cycle. Low-energy steam from the turbines is condensed in large heat exchangers or condensers, with the condensed water being reused in the steam cycle. In directly cooled power stations this process of condensation uses large quantities of cooling water, with a nuclear power station of 1,600 MW generating capacity requiring c.70 m3 s-1. An increased temperature of the discharged water may affect the ecology of the surrounding area. In temperate regions, directly cooled coastal or estuarine power stations discharge cooling water typically between 8-12°C above the ambient water temperature into the receiving water body. The cooling water at discharge is unlikely to rise much above 30°C. The effluent, being warmer, is almost invariably less dense than the receiving environment (notwithstanding possible salinity differences) and thus tends to rise to the surface, with a persistent interface between these two water bodies maintained by this density difference, although the diffuser system will be designed to aid mixing. Heat is lost from the effluent plume predominantly by radiation to both air and water, but also, and increasingly as it cools, by mixing with the receiving water, this latter effect being of more significance in more turbulent waters. These factors tend to localize the area of potential environmental impact [JNCC0211]. When tidal flows are strong,
around the mid-flood and mid-ebb periods, the plume will be elongated and run parallel to the shoreline; at slack high and low water conditions, the plume will expand radially and develop greater width [JNCC0322]. In an estuarine channel this will cause it to occupy a greater proportion of the channel cross-section. The seabed immediately beneath the plume therefore receives little warming effect.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Outflow discharges can include a range of heavy metal contaminants [3126; 4401; 4403; JNCC0322]. Zinc and copper contamination has been reported in discharges from US power plants and although copper alloys have been used in the UK, the use of titanium in modern cooling water condensers eliminates this source. Titanium itself does not dissolve in seawater and presents no toxic risk. Other sources of heavy metals at large power stations relate principally to burning fossil fuels and scrubbing the resulting flue-gases, therefore are not associated with nuclear generation [JNCC0322]. Any use of copper elsewhere in the cooling system, for example in screenwell surface treatments or within intake screen materials (Cu/Ni alloy) would potentially give rise to copper within the discharge but dissolution rates are low. Transition elements and organo-metals are used as marine anti-fouling agents on vessels. Historically the main ingredients in biocidal antifouling coatings have been copper or tributyltin (TBT). TBT has been banned on vessels under 25 m in the UK since 1987. Since then biocides commonly used in the UK in antifoulants include Copper(I) oxide (cuprous oxide), Copper thiocyanate, Zinc pyrithione and ZineB (organosulfur compound) [JNCC0204; 4985].

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column5: Vessels and machinery used during the construction and maintenance of outflow pipes will increase underwater noise levels. Shipping is an important source of underwater noise. Although the majority of this will come from the propeller cavitation, onboard machinery and turbulence around the hull can also result in underwater noise being transmitted underwater. Different parts of the vessel and different vessels emit sound pressures at different frequencies. Generally, the larger the vessel the more dominant the sound pressure levels at lower frequencies. Low frequency sounds generally travel further and have the potential of impacting larger areas [3164; 4921; 4995; 5173]. Dredgers involved in any excavation/trench works during pipe instalment will also generate elevated underwater noise [JNCC0319].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column5: The construction and maintenance/repair of outflow pipes will involve the movement of vessels, vehicles and people which can create visual stimuli that evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as marine mammals, fish and birds [5106; 5117]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity plus other factors such as weather conditions [2497; 2825; 3091; 3269; 2707; 4977]. The number of vessels involved in this activity are very low and therefore the scale and likelihood of this pressure is considered to be very low.

column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Pipeline structures sitting proud of the seabed surface can induce changes in hydrodynamics specifically altering tidal flow direction and velocity [3091]. In particular, cross shore structures such as groynes and harbour arms can intercept flow paths, causing flows to divert around or across the structures [4892; 4893; 4894; 4873; 5075; 4960; 3125; 4961]. Outfalls can also be constructed by bored tunnels with little change in the seabed except at the discharge point.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column3: Power station thermal and nuclear discharges
column5: Outflow structures may affect local wave conditions by causing reflection, refraction and breaking of waves. This could increase or decrease wave energy in nearby areas [3161; 4403]. Outfalls that are constructed by bored tunnels will result in little change in the seabed and therefore wave exposure.

column5: Both satellites and aircraft can be used for remote sensing surveys. Aircraft can produce significant amounts of sound [3270; 5081]. The threshold noise level for aircraft to result in a disturbance reaction in geese was 49 dB for alert response and 58 dB for flight response [JNCC0329]. The study provided evidence that noise rather than a visual cues triggered the behavioural response. An initial study found that airborne noise produced by unmanned aerial vehicles (i.e. drones)  was perceived to be more of a nuisance to humans than ground vehicles [JNCC0327]. The height and speed of the aircraft are all factors to consider when determining potential noise impact.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). Factors such as height, speed and size of aircraft would need to be taken into consideration.

column5: Both satellites and aircraft can be used for remote sensing surveys. Collisions can occur between aircraft and birds [JNCC0330; JNCC0331]. The size, height and speed of the aircraft will be factor to consider [5080].

column5: Both satellites and aircraft can be used for remote sensing surveys. Aircraft movement can cause visual disturbance. The height, speed and noise of the aircraft are all factors to consider when determining visual disturbance [3077; 3134; 3270]. A study found that 80% of quadricopter drone flights were able to approach unaffected birds to 4 m [JNCC0328]. Approach speed, drone colour and repeated flights had no measurable impact on bird behaviour, yet they reacted more to drones approaching vertically [JNCC0328].

column5: Seismic survey from a vessel creates a variety of airborne noise sources including vessel engine sound, noise from human presence on a vessel and the movement of survey equipment such as airguns  [JNCC0300; JNCC0304]. However, the magnitude of pressure would depend on the scale, intensity and duration of the activity.

column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Bird collisions with vessels have been recorded with the risk being greatest at night for lighted ships near coastal areas and when the vessel is relatively close to large breeding aggregations of seabirds (rather than further offshore) [2826]. However, there are relatively few sources of quantified information relating to seabird strikes on vessels. Nocturnal bird strikes on vessels tend to occur when bright, artificial light sources are used at times of poor visibility, typically during bad weather, often angled outwards or upwards from the vessel [4466; 4378].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: This pressure relates to the use of a vessel used in surveying. Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120; 4987].

column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: This pressure relates to the use of vessels for seismic survey. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year [3032; 3096; 3107; 3164; 4333; 4985].

column5: Vessels used in seismic survey require lighting during dark periods. Under the Merchant Shipping (Distress Signals and Prevention of Collisions) Regulations 1996 all vessels in the UK must display lights in all weathers between sunset and sunrise including masthead lighting, sidelights, stern lights, towing lighting, all-round light and flash light [JNCC0254]. Marine birds are frequently attracted to and can become disorientated by artificial light sources, which can result in collision and therefore potentially injury or death [4378; 2826].

column4: Introduction of other substances (solid, liquid or gas)
column5: This pressure relates to the use of vessels for seismic survey. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year [3032; 3096; 3107; 3164; 4333; 4985].

column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Seismic surveys involve the use of vessels. Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling on vessels and gear and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur [3164; 3132; 2798; 4338; 4339; 5000]. All watercraft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978; 5177]. Marine species can be carried in vessels ballast water [3164]. There is concern that the expansion of non-indigenous species could alter local biodiversity and sometimes compete with native species, some of which are of commercial interest. This is especially the case in shallow coastal waters, subject to a multitude of human activities, including the construction of artificial hard substrata.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text). The risk of introducing new species may also increase with the range of vessel/boat activity – e.g. travelling from locations outside the UK.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Marine litter can be released into the marine environment by vessels [4974; 3160]. Shipping related litter contributes approximately 2 % of the litter found on UK beaches. Shipping related litter contributed approximately 45 litter items per kilometre around the UK on average between 2003 and 2007 [4915; 3160].

column4: Synthetic compound contamination (incl. pesticides, antifoulants, pharmaceuticals).  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Moreover, antifouling compounds like TBT and copper wash from ship coatings with larger concentrations in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3032; 3096; 3107; 3164; 4333; 4985].

column5: Transition elements and organo-metals are used as marine anti-fouling agents on vessels. Historically the main ingredients in biocidal antifouling coatings have been copper or tributyltin (TBT). TBT has been banned on vessels under 25m in the UK since 1987. Since then biocides commonly used in the UK in antifoulants include Copper(I) oxide (cuprous oxide), Copper thiocyanate, Zinc pyrithione and ZineB (organosulfur compound) [JNCC0204; JNCC0326].

column5: Seismic surveys use high energy noise sources aimed through the water column to probe below the seafloor. This usually involves the rapid release of compressed air to produce an impulsive signal. Source levels are typically between 200-266 re 1µPa@1m, with most energy below 200 Hz [JNCC0299; JNCC0304]. Vessels are also an important source of underwater noise. Although the majority of this will come from the propeller cavitation, onboard machinery and turbulence around the hull can also result in underwater noise being transmitted underwater. Different part of the vessel and different vessels emit at different frequencies. Generally, lower frequency with increasing size. Low frequency sounds generally travel farther and have the potential of impacting larger areas [4921].

column5: Vessels, machinery and people movement (such as those involved in seismic surveys) can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as marine mammals and seabirds [5106; 5117]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity.

column5: Intake pipe construction and repair require the use of vehicles and shipping all of which emit above water noise. Noise can arise from many activities in the marine environment [3164]. The use of machinery, vessels, explosives, people will result in an increase of above water noise. Sources of airborne noise that might be involved in pipe construction include piling [1329; 3082]. However, the magnitude of pressure would depend on the scale, intensity and duration of the activity.

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: Pipelines can be installed onto or into the seabed. This requires the movement of heavy machinery and vehicles across the surface of the surface of the seabed or coastal habitat and potentially also excavation/dredging works which can lead to abrasion/disturbance [3139; 4403; JNCC0332].

column5: Coastal development, including pipeline construction, can result in barriers to species movement through increased noise (e.g. construction, shipping, acoustic deterrents), lighting, presence of structures, changes to water quality and suspended sediments [2817; 3085; 3096; 3106; 3195; 2763; 3111; 3149; 2834; 3151]. The noise and turbidity arising from dredging operations, which may be required during pipeline construction, may pose a barrier to migration when occurring on or in proximity of specific migratory routes [3152; 3080; 2757]. The scale of the impact will depend on scale of activity and the location and will need to be considered on a case-by-case basis to determine relevance to given feature/site.

column5: Intake pipe construction can involve activities (e.g. excavation/dredging works) which create suspended sediment plumes [3126; 4401; 4440; 4403; 3139]. The scale of the impact will depend on the nature, scale and location of the construction activity and will need to be considered on a case-by-case basis to determine relevance to a given feature/site.

column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Intake pipe construction and repair may require the use and movement of vessels. Marine birds are frequently attracted to or become disorientated by artificial light sources, which can result in collision and therefore injury or death [4378; 2826]. Bird collisions with vessels, including fishing vessels [2826], have been recorded with the risk being greatest at night for lighted ships near coastal areas and when the vessel is relatively close to large breeding aggregations of seabirds (rather than further offshore). However, there are relatively few sources of quantified information relating to seabird strikes on vessels. Nocturnal bird strikes on vessels tend to occur when bright, artificial light sources are used at times of poor visibility, typically during bad weather, often angled outwards or upwards from the vessel [4466; 4378; 4337].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Intake pipes from the marine environment can result in the entrainment or impingement of fish (adult and larvae), birds and marine mammals [4443; 4402].  Intake pipe construction and repair may also require the use and movement of vessels. Vessels are documented to have collided with mobile marine species (particularly marine mammals but also fish and seabirds). Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120; 4987]. A lack of information exists regarding collision risk of animals (e.g. birds, fish, marine mammals) with underwater structures, especially for birds. The response of birds will depend on their detection of a device and any associated structures. The risk of collision may be increased if the devices alter the characteristics of the current, especially if such changes create new foraging opportunities, since this may impact on the manoeuvrability and underwater swimming agility of birds [4959; 5075]. Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098]. Intake pipes are generally buried except at the intake point and therefore risk of collision is considered to be very low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column5: The pressure is associated with sediment mobilisation and increase of suspended sediments as well as the deposition of organic matter. The pressure can result from intake pipe construction during any excavation/dredging works [3161; 3164]. The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the dynamic nature of the area, the temperature and the sediment type, making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Genetic modification & translocation of indigenous species
column5: The construction and maintenance of intake pipes will bring vessels and vehicles to the site from a number of other locations. The surfaces and ballast water of these vessels/vehicles could translocate native species. Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978; 5177]. Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164; 3070]. The vessels involved in intake construction and/or maintenance are generally likely to be making short/local journeys and therefore the likelihood of this pressure occurring is considered to be very low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Habitat structure changes - removal of substratum (extraction)
column5: Pipelines can be installed onto or into the seabed. Where they are buried, trench excavation into the sediment will be required [3139; 4403]. Abstracted water can contain particulate matter and the pumping of 1 mg/l suspended solids in 20 l/s of water during one year will result in the removal of over 0.6 tonnes of ground. It is generally recommended therefore that the content of particulate matter in abstracted water is minimised to prevent the risk of ground settlement [JNCC0225].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Intake pipe construction and repair require the use of vehicles and shipping all of which have the potential to release vessel oil and fuel (comprising PAHs) into the marine environment. Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers).
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: The pressure is potentially associated with navigation and operational lighting on vessels involved in intake pipe construction and repair/maintenance.  Under the Merchant Shipping (Distress Signals and Prevention of Collisions) Regulations 1996 all vessels in the UK must display lights in all weathers between sunset and sunrise including masthead lighting, sidelights, sternlights, towing lighting, all-round light and flash light [JNCC0254]. Lighting can affect marine species (namely birds and fish). Marine birds are frequently attracted to or become disorientated by artificial light sources, which can result in collision and therefore injury or death [4378; 2826]. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083; 3088; 3195; 2797; 3107; 4334; 4339]. Artificial light can repel or attract fish, which in turn can influence their foraging and schooling behaviour, spatial distribution, predation risk, migration and reproduction [4378].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: This pressure relates to use of vessel during construction and maintenance/repair work on intake pipes. The surfaces and ballast water of these vessels/vehicles could transport INIS. Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling on vessels and gear and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur [3164; 3132; 2798; 4338; 4339]. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978; 5177]. Thousands of marine species can also be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164; 3070]. The vessels involved in intake construction and/or maintenance are generally likely to be making short/local journeys and therefore the likelihood of this pressure occurring is considered to be very low. The intake pipe structure may also provide a colonisation surface wherever it occurs above the surface of the seabed.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text). The risk of introducing new species may also increase with the range of vessel/boat activity – e.g. travelling from locations outside the UK.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: The construction and maintenance phase of an intake pipe may require a number of vessels and vehicles in the marine environment which could cause litter. Some discharges may contain floating waste [3126; 3139; 4401]. Marine litter can be released into the marine environment by shipping vessels, either accidentally (inappropriate storage) or deliberately [4974; 3160]. Shipping litter includes pallets, strapping bans and drums. Cargo may also be washed overboard during stormy weather and contribute to coastal litter levels. Shipping related litter contributes approximately 2 % of the litter found on UK beaches. Shipping related litter contributed approximately 45 litter items per kilometre around the UK on average between 2003 and 2007 [4915; 3160]. The vessels involved in intake construction and/or maintenance are relatively small to moderate in size and only likely to be making short journeys. The likelihood of this pressure occurring is therefore considered to be low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: This pressure can result during any excavation/dredging works involved in the construction of intake pipes. The mobilisation of sediment will result in an increase in suspended sediments and the release of organic matter and nutrients  [3145; 5121]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899]. The magnitude of pressure depends on intensity/scale of activity and hydrographic conditions [2834; 3276; 3198; 4939].

column5: This pressure can result during any excavation/dredging works involved in the construction of intake pipes. Sediment mobilisation during dredging can increase the levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145; 5121; 3139; 4401; 4403]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899]. The magnitude of pressure would depend on intensity/scale of activity and hydrographic conditions [2834; 3276; 3198; 4939].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: Pipelines can be installed onto or into the seabed. This requires the movement of heavy machinery and vehicles across the surface of the seabed or coastal habitat and potentially also excavation/dredging works which can lead to abrasion/disturbance [3139; 4403; JNCC0332]. Temporary structures placed on the bed to allow for construction (e.g. rigs) may also result in penetration and/or disturbance of the seabed.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: The seabed currents and the type of sediment will affect the accumulation and scouring of the sediment around the intake pipe [5004]. The construction of the intake pipe may require the creation of a trench that involves the removal and/or replacement of surface seabed material.
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Fish are drawn into the intakes and may suffer physical damage and come into contact with poor water quality e.g. thermal, pressure and toxic contaminants.  The organisms drawn in depend on the location, design and flow rate of the intakes. Impingement occurs when marine organisms are trapped against intake screens by the velocity and force of water flowing through them. Fish entrained and not recovered from the system will die.  The fate of the recovered organism differs between intake and fish recovery system designs and among marine life species, age, and water conditions. Some hardy species may be able to survive impingement and be returned to the sea, but the 24-hour survival rate of less robust species and/or juvenile fish may be less than 10% [JNCC0206]. Entrainment occurs when smaller organisms pass through an intake screen and into the process equipment. Organisms entrained into process equipment are generally considered to have a mortality rate of 100%. [JNCC0293].
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Pipeline construction can create suspended sediment plumes and local smothering [3126; 4401; 4440; 4403; 3139]. During operation, the presence of pipeline structures on the seabed surface can induce changes in hydrodynamics which can cause increased siltation [3139; 4403].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Transition elements and organo-metals are used as marine anti-fouling agents on vessels. Historically the main ingredients in biocidal antifouling coatings have b+E26een copper or tributyltin (TBT). TBT has been banned on vessels under 25 m in the UK since 1987. Since then biocides commonly used in the UK in antifoulants include Copper(I) oxide (cuprous oxide), Copper thiocyanate, Zinc pyrithione and ZineB (organosulfur compound) [JNCC0204; 4985]. The number of vessels involved in this activity are very low and therefore the scale and likelihood of this pressure is considered to be very low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: Vessels and machinery used during the construction and maintenance of intake pipes will increase underwater noise levels. Shipping is an important source of underwater noise. Although the majority of this will come from the propeller cavitation, onboard machinery and turbulence around the hull can also result in underwater noise being transmitted underwater. Different parts of the vessel and different vessels emit sound pressures at different frequencies. Generally, the larger the vessel the more dominant the sound pressure levels at lower frequencies. Low frequency sounds generally travel further and have the potential of impacting larger areas [3164; 4921; 4995; 5173]. Dredgers involved in any excavation/trench works during pipe instalment will also generate elevated underwater noise [JNCC0319].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows JNCC's evidence quality assurance policy (2014). See here for more information: http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=6675. A confidence score is assigned to JNCC evidence to meet Evidence Quality Guidance Note 1.

column5: The construction and maintenance/repair of intake pipes will involve the movement of vessels, vehicles and people which can create visual stimuli that evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as marine mammals, fish and birds [5106; 5117]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity plus other factors such as weather conditions [2497; 2825; 3091; 3269; 2707; 4977]. The number of vessels involved in this activity are very low and therefore the scale and likelihood of this pressure is considered to be very low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Pipeline structures sitting proud of the seabed surface can induce changes in hydrodynamics specifically altering tidal flow direction and velocity [3091]. In particular, cross shore structures such as groynes and harbour arms can intercept flow paths, causing flows to divert around or across the structures [4892; 4893; 4894; 4873; 5075; 4960; 3125; 4961]. Intake pipes are generally buried and therefore anticipated to result in little change in the seabed and flow environment except at the intake point.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column5: Intake structures may affect local wave conditions by causing reflection, refraction and breaking of waves. This could increase or decrease wave energy in nearby areas [3161; 4403]. Intake pipes are generally buried and therefore anticipated to result in little change in the seabed and wave environment except at the intake point.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column5: Noise can arise from many activities in the marine environment. The use of machinery, vessels, explosives or people will result in an increase of above water noise. Some examples of sources of airborne noise are drilling rigs and support vessels [3111; 3149] used to service aquaculture facilities [2834; 3151]. However, the magnitude of pressure would depend on the scale, intensity and duration of the activity.

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: Exploratory drilling over water involves the use of mobile offshore drilling units and includes jackups, semi-submersibles and drillships. The drill will cut through the seafloor to a reservoir beneath. If the well does not contain commercial quantities of hydrocarbons, the site will be decommissioned. Any open rock formations are sealed with cement plugs to prevent upward migration of wellbore fluids [3111].

column5: This pressure relates to the use of a vessel. Propellers from ships can cause localised scour of the seabed around the berth pockets in port locations [5174]. Ship movements can also result in erosion at the margins of the channel [3145].

column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: This pressure relates to the use of a vessel. Bird collisions with vessels occurs and it is documented to higher particularly at night on lighted ships near coastal areas. These are more frequent also under poor visibility [4337]
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: This pressure relates to the use of a vessel. Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involve collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120; 4987]. A lack of information exists regarding collision risk of animals (e.g. birds, fish, marine mammals) with underwater structures, especially for birds. The response of birds will depend on their detection of a device and any associated structures. The risk of collision may be increased if the devices alter the characteristics of the current, especially if such changes create new foraging opportunities, since this may impact on the manoeuvrability and underwater swimming agility of birds [4959; 5075]. Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
