column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: The use of slipways by vessels originating from other regions and the discharge of ballast or waste water may introduce non-indigenous species to an area. Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177]. Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164],[3145],[3070].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity - including in relation to the size of the water body, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). More specifically, the risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed for prolonged periods of time in migratory channels for fish species.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: The construction of slipway will require the excavation, movement and disturbance of the seabed/habitat in the footprint and vicinity of the slipway. Maintenance of the slipway may occur through scraping, sweeping or pressure washing which may lead to removal or disturbance of substrate on or surrounding the slipway [3161].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The construction of slipway will require the excavation, movement and disturbance of the seabed/habitat in the footprint and vicinity of the slipway. Maintenance of the slipway may occur through scrapping, sweeping or pressure washing which may lead to removal or disturbance of substrate on or surrounding the slipway. The pressure is associated with sediment mobilisation and increased of suspended sediments. The pressure can result from dredging [1441],[1436],[2834],[3096],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3163],[3186]. The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the dynamic nature of the area, the temperature and the sediment type, making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: During construction the excavated material will be deposited on the seabed surface and heavy deposition of suspended sediment plumes may occur in the immediate vicinity [3161].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: During construction significant sedimentation may occur. During operation changes in hydrodynamics, current flow and sediment dynamics around the slipway may result in changes in nearby sedimentation rates [3161].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: During slipway construction vehicles and machinery will be moved across the seabed/habitat surface causing abrasion. During operation the movement of vessels and vehicles onto, off and around the slipway may cause abrasion, trampling and erosion [3145],[3077].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Structures placed in the marine environment immediately interact with the local current regime. Structures added to the coastal environment as a result of coastal defence schemes, coastal developments, artificial reefs, etc., can change local flow conditions. In particular, cross shore structures such as groynes and harbour arms can intercept flow paths, causing flows to divert around or across the structures [5075].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Slipway structure may effect local wave conditions by causing reflection, refraction and breaking of waves. This could increase or decrease wave energy in nearby areas [3161].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Physical loss (to land or freshwater habitat)
column5: The construction of a slipway will result in the permanent excavation and or smothering of habitat by man made structures [3161],[4890].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Construction activities and the placement of structures in the marine environment can cause localised and temporary changes in suspended sediments, including those driven into the seabed (such as piles used in berths) or placed on the seabed (such as geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) [3145],[4892],[4890]
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The materials used for construction or placement activities can alter seabed type, materials used include: timber; iron and steel; concrete; clay, silt, sand, gravel or stone/rock; plastic or other synthetic materials [3161].  Construction activities associated with excavation and navigation dredging result in the physical removal of substrate and associated habitats and species resulting in a change in seabed type.  The degree of change will depend on the sensitivity and recoverability of the communities and frequency, duration and magnitude of activity.  Changes in seabed type can also arise from the alteration of the topography, hydrography, and sediment compositions associated resulting from these activities.  Alteration of hydrodynamic conditions as a result of capital dredge (or land reclaim) can change seabed sediment composition and distribution e.g. reduced current flow causing deposition of finer sediment and consequential change in benthic community. Capital dredging can also remove substrate to a depth that the underlying substrate is altered, thus result in a change in habitat and benthic community [2838],[3134],[3145],[3159],[4899],[4379],[4380].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Port and harbour structures: Construction (if relevant see also 'Slipway: Maintenance and construction')
column5: The pressure is associated with sediment mobilisation and increased of suspended sediments as well as the deposition of organic matter.  The pressure can result from a variety of ports and harbour activities including dredging, dredge disposal including alternative disposal and beneficial use of sediments , mobilisation of sediment due to vessel movements and construction activities [2834],[3096],[3153],[3161],[3163],[3106],[3159].  The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the dynamic nature and physical characteristics of the area, sediment type, temperature; making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891].  For example the release of organic rich sediments during dredging or disposal can result in the localised removal of oxygen from the surrounding water [3159],[2834],[3163],[4899].  Dredging activities in areas with an existing problem with dissolved oxygen, or extensive dredging of sediments with a high chemical oxygen demand, could affect dissolved oxygen.  However, in practice, monitoring data suggests that such effects are unlikely in most cases [4902].  Following the placement of dredged material at a disposal site, there is the potential for some localised reduction in dissolved oxygen concentrations in the water column.  Given the dynamic nature of many disposal sites, the water column is likely to be rapidly re-oxygenated, making any changes localised and very short-lived [3163],[2834],[4891].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Ports and harbour (from construction, maintenance or operational ) activities including vessel, vehicle movement, plus people presence and movement can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as fish, marine mammals, seabirds and coastal birds [2497],[2763],[3134],[3154],[3106].  The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity, plus other factors such as species present and age, weather conditions, degree of habituation to disturbance source [5106],[5117],[4977].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur [3164],[3132],[3070].  All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177].  Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water, these include bacteria and other microbes, small invertebrates, eggs, cysts and larvae of various species.  It is estimated that 4,500 different species are carried around the world at any one time in ballast tanks.  During the last three decades, a significant number of introduced, non-indigenous species have been transported through ships’ ballast tanks [5023],[3164].  Artificial structures in the marine environment e.g. breakwaters and jetties, have the potential to act as ‘stepping stones’ for the spread of non-native species.  For example, the Australasian barnacle has been found to colonize concrete breakwaters rapidly in the Netherlands [5086].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity - including in relation to the size of the water body, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). More specifically, the risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed for prolonged periods of time in migratory channels for fish species.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: A variety of ports and harbour activities can result in penetration/disturbance/abrasion of the seabed; including structures placed (e.g. geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) or driven (e.g. piles) into the seabed [3106],[2838],[3159],[3161],[3145],[4912],[4903],[4913],[3223].  Piles used in coastal developments can be driven to depths of over -30 m Chart Datum, tubular piles are typically 1-2 m diameter, sheet piles typically 0.5-1 m wide and 0.1-0.2 m thick [4896],[4898],[4890].  Vessel movements can cause localised scour of the seabed, in shallow water, berth pockets, and navigation channels [5174],[3145].  Anchors can penetrate and disturb the seabed on deployment/recovery and due to dragging of the anchor and anchor chain.  The anchors of large vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed up to 1 m [4971], while small vessel anchors have been found to cause surface ‘scars’ of typically 1-4 m2 [5175]; and scouring of 6 m radius has been recorded on intertidal mudflats caused by anchor chains [5179],[4981].  Mooring chains from swinging moorings can also scour/disturb the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide [3223].  Navigation dredging and excavation activities result in the penetration of the seabed due to the physical removal of substrate [3082],[2838],[3159]; the depth of penetration during capital dredging can be several metres.  For example, in Southampton it was necessary to deepen the existing berths by 4-6 m as part of a berth extension project [4890].  The depth of material removed during maintenance dredging varies greatly, generally between 0.5 m and 2 m of sediment is removed [4897],[4904].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: During marine dredging and recharge operations, sediment is released into the water column via one of the following: physical disturbance of seabed sediments by the drag head during sediment recovery or through the deposit of the material in the intertidal environment.  This sediment will be dispersed by tide and current and settle by gravity to the seabed.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Construction activities and the placement of structures in the marine environment can cause localised and temporary changes in suspended sediments and siltation, including those driven into the seabed (such as piles used in berths) or placed on the seabed (such as geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) [3145],[4892],[4890]
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: A variety of ports and harbour activities can result in abrasion/disturbance of the seabed; including structures placed (e.g. geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) or driven (e.g. piles) into the seabed [3106],[2838],[3159],[3161],[3145],[4912],[4903],[4913],[3223].  Piles used in coastal developments can be driven to depths of over -30 m Chart Datum, tubular piles are typically 1-2 m diameter, sheet piles typically 0.5-1 m wide and 0.1-0.2 m thick [4896],[4898],[4890].  Vessel movements can cause localised scour of the seabed, in shallow locations, berth pockets, in navigation channels [5174],[3145].  Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying/recovery plus abrasion caused by anchor dragging and the anchor chain.  The anchors of large vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed unto 1 m, depth of penetration by smaller inshore vessel anchors is expected to be less [4971].  Small vessel anchors have been found to cause surface ‘scars’ of typically 1-4m2 [5175]; while scouring of 6m radius has been recorded on intertidal mudflats caused by anchor chains [5179],[4981].  Mooring chains from swinging moorings can also scour the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide [3223].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Structures or material placed in the marine environment associated with ports and harbours (including solid and piled structures) will change the form/profile of an area of seabed or an estuary.  This results in localised changes flow rates and tidal regime, intercepting flows causing changes in speed and direction to flow round, past, or across new structures e.g. coastal developments, ports and harbour structures, jetties, breakwaters, land reclaim, dredge disposal, habitat creation.  The magnitude and effect will be related to the size, type, and shape of the structure/placement of material, the magnitude of change to the seabed/estuary profile compared to the overall size of the system/estuary [2817],[3079],[3154],[3159],[3153],[3161],[3106],[3082],[4892],[4893],[3145],[5075],[4873].  For example a large reclaim or structure at the mouth of an estuary could result in  changes which impact an entire estuary and the surrounding marine environment, whereas a new small structure within an estuary is likely to result in more limited localised changes [4892],[3079],[4376].  Similarly changing seabed/estuary profile due to the removal of substrate (capital dredging) or structures (decommissioning) will result in similar changes, causing localised changes to the hydrodynamic flow in an area.  The magnitude and type of effect relates to the overall size of the excavation/removal compared to the overall size of the system/estuary, these changes are then sustained by maintenance dredging [3145],[4899],[2838],[3082],[3134].  For example, flow speed changes of just over 0.1 m/s were predicted for a large capital dredging in Southampton Water [4891].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Physical loss (to land or freshwater habitat)
column5: Ports and harbour developments through land reclaim, construction of new structures can result in the loss of marine habitat to terrestrial/freshwater habitat; the scale and type of loss is depend on the scale and type of construction project [3096],[3106],[2838],[3153],[3154].  For example, the Cardiff Barrage which was built as part of a dockland redevelopment project in 1999 involved the loss of c. 200 ha of intertidal habitat in Cardiff Bay and conversion to a freshwater lake [4381].  In Southampton Water berth extensions since the 1960s has reclaimed over 80 ha of subtidal and intertidal habitat with individual projects varying in size from several hectares to over 40 ha [4890].  Dredged material (capital and maintenance) has been used for land reclamation, creation of freshwater/terrestrial habitats [2838],[3163],[3153],[4382].  For example, maintenance dredging spoil was used to reclaim over 170ha of land in Dibden Bay, Southampton Water between 1930 and 1970 [4890].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The materials used for construction or placement activities can alter seabed type, materials used include: timber; iron and steel; concrete; clay, silt, sand, gravel or stone/rock; plastic or other synthetic materials [3161].  Construction and presence of structures in ports and harbours will cause a change in habitat type, typically from soft sediment to a hard substratum type; examples include steel piles used in berths/jetties, concrete and rock used in breakwaters/quays [4892],[4890].  Construction activities associated with excavation and navigation dredging result in the physical removal of substrate and associated habitats and species resulting in a change in seabed type.  The degree of change will depend on the sensitivity and recoverability of the communities and frequency, duration and magnitude of activity.  Changes in seabed type can also arise from the alteration of the topography, hydrography, and sediment compositions associated resulting from these activities.  Alteration of hydrodynamic conditions as a result of capital dredge (or land reclaim) can change seabed sediment composition and distribution e.g. reduced current flow causing deposition of finer sediment and consequential change in benthic community. Capital dredging can also remove substrate to a depth that the underlying substrate is altered, thus result in a change in habitat and benthic community [2838],[3134],[3145],[3159],[4899],[4379],[4380].

column5: Outfall discharges from industrial, sewerage and agricultural sources can introduce a range of pathogens and parasites into the marine environment which could be deemed damaging [3074],[3139],[4401],[4485].

column5: The materials used for construction or placement activities can alter seabed type, materials used include: timber; iron and steel; concrete; clay, silt, sand, gravel or stone/rock; plastic or other synthetic materials [3161].  Construction and presence of structures in ports and harbours will cause a change in habitat type, typically from soft sediment to a hard substratum type; examples include steel piles used in berths/jetties, concrete and rock used in breakwaters/quays [4892],[4890].  Construction activities associated with excavation and navigation dredging result in the physical removal of substrate and associated habitats and species resulting in a change in seabed type.  The degree of change will depend on the sensitivity and recoverability of the communities and frequency, duration and magnitude of activity.  Changes in seabed type can also arise from the alteration of the topography, hydrography, and sediment compositions associated resulting from these activities.  Alteration of hydrodynamic conditions as a result of capital dredge (or land reclaim) can change seabed sediment composition and distribution e.g. reduced current flow causing deposition of finer sediment and consequential change in benthic community. Capital dredging can also remove substrate to a depth that the underlying substrate is altered, thus result in a change in habitat and benthic community [2838],[3134],[3145],[3159],[4899],[4379],[4380].

column5: Ports construction and maintenance works and on-going operations can result in underwater noise, including from vessels, dredging, engineering works.  Underwater noise can result in disturbance particularly to mobile receptors such as fish, bird, mammals [3152],[3164],[3159],[3106],[2074],[3128],[3069],[4995].  Shipping vessels are important source of underwater noise, and is the dominant contributor to ambient noise in shallow water areas close to shipping lanes and in deeper waters [5173],[5172].  Shipping noise is most evident in the 50-300 Hz frequency range, with the majority of noise coming from propeller cavitation, on-board machinery, and turbulence around the hull.  The noise emitted from vessels varies, in general larger vessels generate lower frequency sound.  The source levels associated with large ships (supertankers/container ships) is in the range 180-190 dB re 1µPa-m (RMS).  Small sea going vessels typically produce broadband noise at source levels of 160-180 dB re 1µPa-m (RMS) [3096],[4908].  Measurements of underwater noise from backhoe dredging operations have indicated that the highest levels of underwater noise occur when the excavator is in contact with the seabed.  Dredging produces broadband and continuous sound, mainly at lower frequencies (<1 kHz; source sound pressure levels 160 to more than 190 dB re 1 µPa at 1 m) [4908],[3152].  However it is impulsive/impact sound generated by explosives/piling which causes the most concern of injury and displacement of mobile species from underwater noise [3152],[2074],[3128],[3069].  Impact piling generates high levels of underwater noise, a typical peak to peak source noise pressure levels underwater for tubular piles used in coastal environments range of 220-235 dB re. 1 uPa @ 1 m. Sheet piling noise is generally lower with typical predicted peak to peak source noise level of 212 dB re. 1 uPa @ 1 m (for 600 mm sheet pile) [4908].Engineering works in coastal environments using blasting to remove unwanted hard substrate can to produce source peak noise levels of 257 dB re: 1 µPa (borehole blasting with a charge of 20 kg ) [4916].

column5: The pressure is potentially associated with construction, maintenance, operational lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4339].

column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Pressure associated with vessels and vessel movements associated with this sub-activity, also presence of relevant underwater structures.  Seabirds can be impacted directly by a wide range of artificial light sources within marine environment: seabirds can be attracted to and collide with lighthouses, coastal resorts and other urban lighting, offshore hydrocarbon platforms, commercial fishing vessels and other boats using lights [4378],[4337].  Evidence indicates some bird species are attracted to light sources, which may increase the risk of bird strikes.  Most related studies conclude that increased darkness, coupled with inclement weather, increases attraction by birds to lighted vessels and structures.  Birds drawn to light often become disoriented and can then collide with these vessels/structures resulting in injury and death [4377].  In the case of vessels, it known that nocturnal bird strikes tend to occur when bright, artificial light sources are used at times of poor visibility, typically during bad weather, often angled outwards or upwards from the vessel and when the vessel is relatively close to large breeding aggregations of seabirds (rather than further offshore); however, here are relatively few sources of quantified information relating to seabird strikes on vessels [4378],[4337].

column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Pressure associated with vessels and vessel movements associated with this sub-activity, also presence of relevant underwater structures.  Vessels are documented to have collided with mobile marine species (particularly marine mammals).  Almost all vessel sizes and classes have been involved in collisions with marine mammals, including cargo ships, ferries (particularly the newer models of high-speed ferry), cruise liners, navy ships, recreational vessels, and research vessels.  Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull.  The most lethal and serious injuries are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots [5120].  Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long.  Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120],[4987].  A lack of information exists regarding collision risk of animals (e.g. birds, fish, marine mammals) with underwater structures, especially for birds.  The response of birds will depend on their detection of a device and any associated structures.  The risk of collision may be increased if the devices alter the characteristics of the current, especially if such changes create new foraging opportunities, since this may impact on the manoeuvrability and underwater swimming agility of birds [4959],[5075].  Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].

column5: Noise can arise from many activities in the marine environment, the use of machinery, vessels, equipment, explosives, and people will generate airborne (above water) noise.  Port construction, maintenance, and operation activities generate airborne noise and can increase noise above background/ambient noise levels; this can result in disturbance particularly to mobile receptors such as fish, bird, mammals [2817],[3085],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3164],[3082],[2763].  Examples of noise sources vessels, construction plant/operations, piling, operational use of machinery [2817],[1533],[3136],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3169],[3145].  However, the magnitude of pressure would depend on the scale, intensity, and duration of the activity, and relative increase in noise above the natural ambient background noise levels and the type of noise generated [3136],[3078],[3195],[1536].

column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5:
The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Moreover, antifouling compounds like TBT and copper wash from ship coatings with larger concentrations in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3096],[3106],[3107],[3164],[3155],[4985].

Activities can also result in the re-mobilisation of contaminants/substances (e.g. from sediments) during construction/maintenance/operational activities.  The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of existing contamination and intensity of activity.  High levels of contaminants do occur in fine sediments of some industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated areas/sediments is rare in the England [4899],[3145],[2838],[3159].

column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177]. Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity - including in relation to the size of the water body, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). More specifically, the risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed for prolonged periods of time in migratory channels for fish species.

column5: Marine litter can be released into the marine environment by shipping vessels including cargo, bulk carrier, military, surveillance, research, passenger ships and non-commercial vessels, either accidentally (inappropriate storage) or deliberately [4974],[3160]. Shipping litter includes pallets, strapping bans and drums, as well as litter derived from containers lost at sea. Cargo may also be washed overboard during stormy weather and contribute to coastal litter levels. Shipping related litter contributes approximately 2 % of the litter found on UK beaches. Shipping related litter contributed approximately 45 litter items per kilometre around the UK on average between 2003 and 2007 [4915],[3160].

column5: Noise can arise from many activities in the marine environment. The use of machinery, vessels, explosives, people will result in an increase of above water noise. Some examples of sources of airborne noise are drilling rigs and support [3111],[3149], vessels used to service aquaculture facilities [2834],[3151],  vessels used in coastal developments and flood defences [2817],[3085],[2838],[3136],[3153],[3154],[3132], military activities, aggregate extraction [3152], cabling operations [3158],[3164], piling [1329],[3082], etc. However, the magnitude of pressure would depend on the scale, intensity and duration of the activity.

column5: There are several sources of organic and nutrient enrichment in the marine environment: outflows of domestic/industrial origin, sludge, sediment resuspension, aquaculture food and faeces, and others. Sediment mobilisation during dredging can increase the levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145],[5121]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899]. Fish farming generates large amounts of particulate organic waste products, and surrounding sediments are affected by this surplus of organic matter. The extent of impacts is determined from the quantity and quality of the input and environmental conditions at the location [4939]. Deposition of faeces and pseudo-faeces may lead to organic enrichment of seabed.  Nutrient waste may be generated through excretion by reared organisms or direct enrichment by or remineralisation of feed inputs. However, magnitude of pressure would depend on intensity/scale of activity and hydrographic conditions [2834],[3276],[3198],[4939]. Disposal of waste material into the marine environment includes the regulated discharge of wastewater and the disposal of hazardous and non-hazardous waste [4915].

The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the dynamic nature of the area, the temperature and the sediment type, making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891].

column5: Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177]. Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity - including in relation to the size of the water body, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). More specifically, the risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed for prolonged periods of time in migratory channels for fish species.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5:
Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying the anchor and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery. Mooring chains from swinging moorings may scour the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide. 
The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials. For example, for an 11.5 tonne anchor penetration of up to 0.88 m occurred in soft sediment when the anchor was dropped and dragged 87 m [4971]. There is a tendency for the anchor to penetrate to deep depths in softer sediment as the opening of the anchor flukes prevents deep penetration in harder sediment [5076]. Typical maximum water depths for anchoring are between 100 m and 150 m.

column5: Dredging during operation of a tidal range project has the potential to lead to localised and temporary increases in siltation rate [4384],[3127]. The level and area of impact depend on a number of factors including localised hydrodynamics and seabed substrate [3122].

column5: The use of dredging in the maintenance and operation of tidal range has the potential to lead to localised and temporary increases in siltation rate [4384],[3127]. The level and area of impact depend on a number of factors including localised hydrodynamics, type of foundation and seabed substrate [3122].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: During operation abrasion and/or disturbance of the seabed may occur due to dredging and the use of  vessels carrying out other maintenance and repair works with either jackup legs which cause depressions on the seabed [3148] or anchors [3127]. Additional scour protection may be placed on the seabed where required leading to abrasion/ disturbance [3148]. Damage to the seabed may be caused by deployment of anchors from vessels used in maintenance of the array, the subsequent dragging and locking in of anchors and through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery [3223].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Structures placed in the marine environment immediately interact with the local current regime. The physical presence of an energy generating device could lead to diffraction or funnelling of waves and currents, reductions in the wave energy reaching the coast and changes in local wave patterns [4960]. This may lead to the development of scour pits adjacent to foundations or secondary scour around scour protection [3148]. Artificial reefs may have directly negative impacts through changes in current velocities and direction [4980],[5018],[5021],[2293]. Structures added to the coastal environment as a result of coastal defence schemes, coastal developments, artificial reefs, etc., can change local flow conditions. In particular, cross shore structures such as groynes and harbour arms can intercept flow paths, causing flows to divert around or across the structures [4892],[4893],[4894],[4873],[5075],[4960],[3125],[4961].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Emergence regime changes, including tidal level change considerations
column5: Operation of tidal range projects will involve operation of large structures which by their nature are intended to change the local emergence regime through empounding and channelling flow [5196],[5075].

column5: Marine litter can be released into the marine environment by shipping vessels including cargo, bulk carrier, military, surveillance, research, passenger ships and non-commercial vessels, either accidentally (inappropriate storage) or deliberately [4974],[3160]. Shipping litter includes pallets, strapping bans and drums, as well as litter derived from containers lost at sea. Cargo may also be washed overboard during stormy weather and contribute to coastal litter levels. Shipping related litter contributes approximately 2 % of the litter found on UK beaches. Shipping related litter contributed approximately 45 litter items per kilometre around the UK on average between 2003 and 2007 [4915],[3160].

column5: Operational noise of energy installations is unlikely to be ecologically significant although there is very little information on the sound levels produced by their operation. There are also very few (if any) directed studies of the response of fish and marine mammals to noises and vibrations produced by operational [5195]. In the case of tidal stream farms the operational noise from a small number of units may not exceed threshold levels, but the cumulative noise production from large numbers of units has the potential to mask the communication and echolocation sounds produced by aquatic organisms in the vicinity of the structures. Similar assumptions may apply to tidal range projects. Resolution of the significance or otherwise of noise impacts will require information about the energy generating device's acoustic signature (e.g., sound pressure levels across the full range of frequencies) for both individual units and multiple-unit arrays, similar characterization of ambient noise in the vicinity of the farm, the hearing sensitivity of fish and marine mammals that inhabit the area, and information about the behavioural responses to anthropogenic noise (e.g., avoidance, attraction, changes in schooling behaviour or migration routes) [ 5194]. Underwater noise impacts may result  from vessel movement [4921],[4995],[5173],[5172].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Maintenance lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light emissions associated with offshore structures could have a potential impact through attraction of birds due to illumination by navigational lights and subsequent increase in the risk of collision [3125]. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4339].

column5: The pressure refers to obstructions to species movement caused by physical barrier or prolonged exposure to noise, light, visual disturbance or changes in water quality. The scale of the impact will depend on scale of activity and the location and will need to be considered on case-by-case basis to determine relevance to given feature/site. The presence of tidal energy projects can lead to a behavioural response (displacement from habitat and extension of flights/movement) for mobile species, effectively causing a barrier to movement [5162],[5166]. They may represent a barrier to movement of migrating or feeding animals and may potentially result in displacement of migration routes and displacement of feeding animals. Such displacements may incur heavier energetic costs, which may ultimately affect survival or breeding success  [3125]. Noise arising from other long-lived operations using explosives such as harbour construction or military activities can also alter migration routes of sensitive species [4990]. Coastal development can result in barriers to species movement through increased noise (e.g. construction, shipping, acoustic deterrents), lighting, presence of structures, changes to water quality and suspended sediments [2817],[3085],[3096],[3106],[3195],[2763],[3111],[3149],[2834],[3151].

column5: The materials used for construction or placement activities can alter seabed type, materials used include: timber; iron and steel; concrete; clay, silt, sand, gravel or stone/rock; plastic or other synthetic materials [3161].  Construction activities associated with excavation and navigation dredging result in the physical removal of substrate and associated habitats and species resulting in a change in seabed type.  The degree of change will depend on the sensitivity and recoverability of the communities and frequency, duration and magnitude of activity.  Changes in seabed type can also arise from the alteration of the topography, hydrography, and sediment compositions associated resulting from these activities.  Alteration of hydrodynamic conditions as a result of capital dredge (or land reclaim) can change seabed sediment composition and distribution e.g. reduced current flow causing deposition of finer sediment and consequential change in benthic community. Capital dredging can also remove substrate to a depth that the underlying substrate is altered, thus result in a change in habitat and benthic community [2838],[3134],[3145],[3159],[4899],[4379],[4380].

column5: The construction and use of slipways at night will introduce light onto nearby habitats which could effect the way birds behave. The pressure is potentially associated with construction, maintenance, operational lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4339].

column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5:
Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120],[4987].
A lack of information exists regarding collision risk of animals (e.g. birds, fish, marine mammals) with underwater structures, especially for birds. The response of birds will depend on their detection of a device and any associated structures. The risk of collision may be increased if the devices alter the characteristics of the current, especially if such changes create new foraging opportunities, since this may impact on the manoeuvrability and underwater swimming agility of birds [4959],[5075]. Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].

column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: The construction and use of slipways by vessels may expose the marine environment to bilge,  waste water and other chemicals used in vessel maintenance. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Moreover, antifouling compounds like TBT and copper wash from ship coatings with larger concentrations in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3032],[3096],[3107],[3164],[3145],[4333],[4985].

column5: The construction of slipway will require the excavation, movement and disturbance of the seabed/habitat in the footprint and vicinity of the slipway. Maintenance of the slipway may occur through scraping, sweeping or pressure washing which may lead to removal or disturbance of substrate on or surrounding the slipway. The pressure is associated with sediment mobilisation and increase of suspended sediments as well as the deposition of organic matter. The pressure can result from dredging [1441],[1436],[2834],[3096],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3163],[3186]. The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the dynamic nature of the area, the temperature and the sediment type, making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891].

column4: Genetic modification & translocation of indigenous species
column5: The construction and maintenance of outfalls will bring vessels and vehicles to the site from a number of other locations. The surfaces and ballast water of these vessels/vehicles could translocate native species . Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177]. Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164],[3070].

column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: Outflow pipes/outfalls are either buried or surface laid across coastal and seabed habitats. Either method will require the movement of vehicles and machinery across the surface causing heavy abrasion and at least small levels of excavation [3191],[4403].  During construction and maintenance vessel anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying the anchor and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery.  The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials. For example, for an 11.5 tonne anchor penetration of up to 0.88 m occurred in soft sediment when the anchor was dropped and dragged 87 m [4971]. There is a tendency for the anchor to penetrate to deep depths in softer sediment as the opening of the anchor flukes prevents deep penetration in harder sediment [5076]. Typical maximum water depths for anchoring are between 100 m and 150 m.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Outfall discharges can have significantly higher suspended sediment levels than the receiving environment. This is especially the case with outflow from storm overflow or surface drainage. Pipeline construction can also create suspended sediment plumes [3126],[4401],[4440],[4403],[3139].

column5: Pipeline structures on the seabed surface can induce changes in hydrodynamics which can cause increased siltation. Outflow discharge can have high suspended sediment concentrations causing locally increased sedimentation [3139],[4403].

column5: Pipelines are installed onto or into the seabed. This requires the movement of heavy machinery and vehicles across the surface of the surface of the seabed or coastal habitat [3139].

column5: Outfall discharges can enter the marine environment at a range of elevated temperatures and persistently increase local environmental temperatures to damaging levels [3126],[4401],[4403],[4485].

column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Pipeline structures sitting proud of the seabed surface can induce changes in hydrodynamics specifically altering tidal flow direction and velocity [3091]. Structures placed in the marine environment immediately interact with the local current regime.  Structures added to the coastal environment as a result of coastal defence schemes, coastal developments, artificial reefs, etc., can change local flow conditions. In particular, cross shore structures such as groynes and harbour arms can intercept flow paths, causing flows to divert around or across the structures [4892],[4893],[4894],[4873],[5075],[4960],[3125],[4961].

column5: Outfall structures may effect local wave conditions by causing reflection, refraction and breaking of waves. This could increase or decrease wave energy in nearby areas [3161],[4403].

column4: Physical loss (to land or freshwater habitat)
column5: Where outflow pipes are buried, trench excavation will be required which will remove the existing habitat and if not fully reinstated this could result in habitat loss. Rock armouring may also be placed over the pipe resulting in a loss in habitat [3139].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The construction phase of an outflow pipe will require a number of vessels and vehicles in the marine environment which could cause litter. Some discharges may contain floating waste [3126],[3139],[4401]. Marine litter can be released into the marine environment by shipping vessels including cargo, bulk carrier, military, surveillance, research, passenger ships and non-commercial vessels, either accidentally (inappropriate storage) or deliberately [4974],[3160]. Shipping litter includes pallets, strapping bans and drums, as well as litter derived from containers lost at sea. Cargo may also be washed overboard during stormy weather and contribute to coastal litter levels. Shipping related litter contributes approximately 2 % of the litter found on UK beaches. Shipping related litter contributed approximately 45 litter items per kilometre around the UK on average between 2003 and 2007 [4915],[3160].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Vessels and machinery used during the construction phase will increase noise levels. Shipping is an important source of underwater noise. Although the majority of this will come from the propeller cavitation, onboard machinery and turbulence around the hull can also result in underwater noise being transmitted underwater. Different parts of the vessel and different vessels emit at different frequencies. Generally, lower frequency with increasing size. Low frequency sounds generally travel farther and have the potential of impacting larger areas [3164],[4921],[4995],[5173].

column5: The pressure is potentially associated with construction, maintenance, operational lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4339].

column5: The pressure refers to obstructions to species movement caused by physical barrier(s) or prolonged exposure to noise, light, visual disturbance or changes in water quality. The scale of the impact will depend on scale of activity and the location and will need to be considered on a case-by-case basis to determine relevance to given feature/site.  Noise arising from other long-lived operations using explosives such as harbour construction or military activities can also alter migration routes of sensitive species [4990]. Coastal development can result in barriers to species movement through increase noise (e.g. construction, shipping, acoustic deterrents), lighting, presence of structures, changes to water quality and suspended sediments [2817],[3085],[3096],[3106],[3195],[2763],[3111],[3149],[2834],[3151]. Coastal defences can also result in barrier to species by restricting access to rivers/streams/estuaries or to species adapted to sea level rise and coastal change [2817],[3096],[3154]. The noise and turbidity arising from dredging operations may pose a barrier to migration when occurring on or in proximity of specific migratory routes [3152],[3080],[2757].

column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Bird  collisions with vessels occurs and it is documented to higher particularly at night on lighted ships near coastal areas. These are more frequent also under poor visibility  [4337]

column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5:
Inflow and intake pipes from the marine environment can result in the entrainment or impingement of fish (adult and larvae), birds and marine mammals [4443],[4402].  During construction vessels may be used, if so species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120],[4987].
A lack of information exists regarding collision risk of animals (e.g. birds, fish, marine mammals) with underwater structures, especially for birds. The response of birds will depend on their detection of a device and any associated structures. The risk of collision may be increased if the devices alter the characteristics of the current, especially if such changes create new foraging opportunities, since this may impact on the manoeuvrability and underwater swimming agility of birds [4959],[5075]. Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].

column4: Habitat structure changes - removal of substratum (extraction)
column5: Managed realignment may result in the removal of land or coastal defences (hard or soft) to allow inundation by water to occur. Terrestrial habitats may therefore become estuarine or marine [3085],[2838],[3138],[3153],[3154],[3161].

column5: Outflow pipe construction and repair require the use of vehicles and shipping all of which emit above water noise. Noise can arise from many activities in the marine environment [3164]. The use of machinery, vessels, explosives, people will result in an increase of above water noise. Some examples of sources of airborne noise are drilling rigs and support [3111],[3149], vessels used to service aquaculture facilities [2834],[3151],  vessels used in coastal developments and flood defences [2817],[3085],[2838],[3136],[3153],[3154],[3132], military activities, aggregate extraction [3152], cabling operations [3158],[3164], piling [1329],[3082], etc. However, the magnitude of pressure would depend on the scale, intensity and duration of the activity.

column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Outfall discharges can include a range of agricultural and industrial chemicals including organic and metal contaminants [3126],[4401],[4403].

column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Outfall discharges have the potential to introduce hydrocarbons into the marine environment through industrial effluent and run off/drainage sources [3126],[3139],[4401],[4403].  The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Moreover, antifouling compounds like TBT and copper wash from ship coatings with larger concentrations in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3032],[3096],[3107],[3164],[4333],[4985].

column5: There are several sources of organic and nutrient enrichment in the marine environment: outflows of domestic/industrial origin, sludge, sediment resuspension, aquaculture food and faeces, and others [3139],[4403],[4401]. Sediment mobilisation during dredging can increase the levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145],[5121]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899]. Deposition of faeces and pseudo-faeces may lead to organic enrichment of seabed.  Nutrient waste may be generated through excretion by reared organisms or direct enrichment by or remineralisation of feed inputs. However, magnitude of pressure would depend on intensity/scale of activity and hydrographic conditions [2834],[3276],[3198],[4939]. Disposal of waste material into the marine environment includes the regulated discharge of wastewater and the disposal of hazardous and non-hazardous waste [4915],[3126].

column5: There are several sources of organic and nutrient enrichment in the marine environment: outflows of domestic/industrial origin, sludge, sediment resuspension, aquaculture food and faeces, and others. Sediment mobilisation during dredging can increase the levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145],[5121],[3139],[4401],[4403]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899]. The extent of impacts is determined from the quantity and quality of the input and environmental conditions at the location [4939]. Deposition of faeces and pseudo-faeces may lead to organic enrichment of seabed.  Nutrient waste may be generated through excretion by reared organisms or direct enrichment by or remineralisation of feed inputs. However, magnitude of pressure would depend on intensity/scale of activity and hydrographic conditions [2834],[3276],[3198],[4939]. Disposal of waste material into the marine environment includes the regulated discharge of wastewater and the disposal of hazardous and non-hazardous waste [4915],[3126].

column5: Excessive nutrient and organic enrichment in the water column due to outfall discharge can result in reduce oxygen levels in surrounding habitats [3126],[3139],[4403],[4401].The pressure is associated with sediment mobilisation and increased of suspended sediments as well as the deposition of organic matter. The pressure can result from a variety of activities including dredging, aquaculture, outflow, etc [3161],[3164]. The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the dynamic nature of the area, the temperature and the sediment type, making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891].

column5: Vessels, vehicles and people movement can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as marine mammals and seabirds [5106],[5117]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity. Removal of structures will remove any visual disturbance to bird species.

column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177]. Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164]. There is a world-wide concern of the expansion of non-indigenous species because they alter local biodiversity and sometimes compete with native species, some of which of commercial interest. This is especially the case in shallow coastal waters, subject to a multitude of human activities, including the construction of artificial hard substrata. The oil and gas industry provides a direct and indirect pathways for alien invasive species, through vessel movements and structures [5000].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity - including in relation to the size of the water body, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). More specifically, the risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed for prolonged periods of time in migratory channels for fish species.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The dragging of anchors used by vessels involved in decommissioning activities can cause localised and temporary increases in suspended sediments [3223]. Excavation around jacket legs from the seabed and excavation at the pipeline ends will physically disturb the sediment in the local area. Depending on methods used, the removal of structures and scour protection may lead to temporary increases in suspended solids and siltation [4387].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The dragging of anchors used by vessels involved in decommissioning activities can cause localised and temporary increases in suspended sediments [3223]. The settling out of suspended sediments is only expected to cause negligible increases in siltation. Excavation around jacket legs from the seabed and excavation at the pipeline ends will physically disturb the sediment in the local area. Depending on methods used removal of turbines foundations and scour protection may lead to temporary increases in suspended solids and siltation [4387].

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: During decommissioning, abrasion and/or disturbance of the seabed may occur due to the use of  vessels carrying out decommissioning works with either jackup legs which cause depressions on the seabed [3148] or anchors [3127]. Additional rock protection may be placed on the seabed where required leading to abrasion/ disturbance [3148]. Temporary excavation pits may be required to access buried structures or enable removal of structures at or below seabed level [4387]. Damage to the seabed may be caused by deployment of anchors from vessels used in decommissioning of the oil and gas installation, the subsequent dragging and locking in of anchors and through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery [3223].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Structures placed in the marine environment immediately interact with the local current regime. Removal of structures during decommissioning will allow local currents to return to those of the surroundings environment, unaffected by interaction with structures.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Habitat change will occur due to placement of structures on the seabed including scour protection [3122],[3127],[3083],[3125].  Additional rock may be placed on the seabed during decommissioning to cover exposed structures or provide a stable rock berm for the placement of jack-up legs [4387].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710
