column3: Telecommunication cable: Laying, burial and protection
column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177]. Moreover, thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity - including in relation to the size of the water body, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). More specifically, the risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed for prolonged periods of time in migratory channels for fish species.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Telecommunication cable: Laying, burial and protection
column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: Direct penetration and disturbance of habitat will occur as a result of ploughing, trenching, rock placement and anchor placement. Depending on the installation method used, the footprint of the seabed disturbed by telecommunication cable installation machinery could be between 5-10 m wide per cable trench for ploughing and trenching. On average, the marine cables will be buried to a depth between 1 to 2 m [4926],[4345]. The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials [4971]. There is a tendency for the anchor to penetrate to deep depths in softer sediment as the opening of the anchor flukes prevents deep penetration in harder sediment [5076]. Typical maximum water depths for anchoring are between 100 m and 150 m. The pressure exerted by anchors will be low when smaller anchors are used and not applicable if Dynamic Positioning is used.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Telecommunication cable: Laying, burial and protection
column5: Though modern equipment and techniques reduce the re-suspension of sediment during cable burial, repair or removal, an increase in suspended sediment will occur but the magnitude depends on the silt fraction, the equipment used and background levels [3156]. For example, in one particular case ploughing on chalk in the English Channel was expected to increase suspended sediment to a distance of 700 m (<1 mg/L above background levels) with largest increases measurable at up to 100 m (10-20 mg/L) of the trench; whereas the depth-averaged and near bed concentration increases modelled for ploughing in sand at Goodwin Knoll (which has less than 3 % fines) were significantly less, being  < 0.5 mg/l above background [4345].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column5: Managed realignment may result in the removal of land or coastal defences (hard or soft) to allow inundation by water to occur. These schemes may act as a sink or source of sediment [3085],[2838],[3138],[3153],[3154],[3161].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Telecommunication cable: Laying, burial and protection
column5: During cable installation sediment re-suspension will occur and subsequent re-deposition on the seabed. The siltation rates will depend on the hydrological conditions and the sediment particle size distribution. A greater sediment dispersion distance means the sediment will be more thinly dispersed over a wider area, whilst a smaller sediment dispersion distance gives a high deposition depth over a smaller distance. For example, in one particular case ploughing on chalk in the English Channel was expected to increase suspended sediment to a distance of 700m (<1 mg/L above background levels) with largest increases measurable at up to 100 m (10-20 mg/L) of the trench; whereas at South Falls the impact was only predicted to extend to 500 m but with predicted deposition levels of <0.1 mm [4345]. For the Western HVDC Link the calculation of sediment dispersion predicted that all the displaced sediment will settle to form an even layer 50 m either side of each cable trench This would produce a temporary sedimentation layer 3 mm thick for trenching, which is the methodology most likely to be used in shallow high energy environments, and 0.75 mm for ploughing, which is most likely to be used for the majority of the deeper, low energy environments [4926]. For telecommunication cables the magnitude of the pressure is expected to be smaller due to the smaller size of the operation.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Telecommunication cable: Laying, burial and protection
column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: The laying of cables will lead to seabed abrasion and disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed in any circumstance, either if the cable is buried, protected or not [3156]. Ploughing, trenching, rock placement, and anchor placement will all result in abrasion and disturbance. Depending on the installation method used, the footprint of the seabed disturbed by telecommunication cable installation machinery could be between 5-10 m wide per cable trench for ploughing and trenching [4926],[4345]. Cables laid at the surface can result in some degree of abrasion mainly where there is high wave activity (in shallow waters of <20 m marks ranged from 6-45 cm wide) [4344]. Beyond this direct foot print, low intensity physical disturbance will also occur due to anchor handling inside the anchor corridor to a maximum of 1 km on each side of the cable. Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon engaging, dragging and embedding. The chain also causes abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery. The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials [4971]. The pressure exerted by anchors will be low when smaller anchors are used and not applicable if Dynamic Positioning is used.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Telecommunication cable: Laying, burial and protection
column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Structures placed in the marine environment immediately interact with the local current regime. The use of external cable protection which sits proud of the seabed can potentially result in localised changes in water flow resulting in localised turbulence (especially at peak flow). The impact of this is expected to be much localised and limited [4345]. Non-backfilled trenches dug for cable burial will result in localised flow speed changes until the trench is backfilled. The backfill usually occurs soon after ploughing but in some ground conditions this can take longer.  These will have limited impact and depend on the water depth and overall water depth change, similar to what has been modelled for marine aggregate extraction [4009].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column3: Telecommunication cable: Laying, burial and protection
column4: Physical loss (to land or freshwater habitat)
column5: The pressure relates to changes in coastal or marine habitat due to manmade structures. During cable laying protection measures alternative to burial are used to avoid cable damage resulting in habitat loss. These can be concrete mattresses, rock dumping, grout bags, frond mattresses, etc. resulting in a permanent loss of habitat where the structures are placed [3156]. For example, when using concrete mattressing or rock placement in soft sediment or where the rock is distinctly different from the natural rock i.e. granite protection on chalk bedrock.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column4: Habitat structure changes - removal of substratum (extraction)
column5: Navigation dredging results in the physical removal of substrate and thus associated habitats and species within the area to increase or maintain depths within navigation channels [3082],[2838],[3159].  The depth of material extracted during capital dredging projects can be over several metres.  For example, in Southampton it was necessary to deepen the existing berths from -10.2-12.2 m Chart Datum to -16 m Chart Datum as part of a berth extension project [4890].  The depth of material removed during maintenance dredging varies greatly depending on the location and target level required, generally between 0.5 m and 2 m of sediment is removed [4897],[4904].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Telecommunication cable: Laying, burial and protection
column5: Marine litter can be released into the marine environment by shipping vessels including cargo, bulk carrier, military, surveillance, research, passenger ships and non-commercial vessels, either accidentally (inappropriate storage) or deliberately [4974],[3160]. Shipping litter includes pallets, strapping bans and drums, as well as litter derived from containers lost at sea. Cargo may also be washed overboard during stormy weather and contribute to coastal litter levels. Shipping related litter contributes approximately 2 % of the litter found on UK beaches. Shipping related litter contributed approximately 45 litter items per kilometre around the UK on average between 2003 and 2007 [4915],[3160]. Litter should not be a licensing issue as all vessels adhere to MARPOL requirements, managed under the International Safety Management (ISM) Code which provides an International standard for the safe management and operation of ships and for pollution prevention.

column3: Telecommunication cable: Laying, burial and protection
column5: Shipping is an important source of underwater noise. Although the majority of this will come from the propeller cavitation, on-board machinery and turbulence around the hull can also result in underwater noise being transmitted underwater. Different part of the vessel and different vessels emit at different frequencies. Generally, lower frequency with increasing size. Low frequency sounds generally travel farther and have the potential of impacting larger areas. [4921],[4995],[5173],[5172].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column3: Telecommunication cable: Laying, burial and protection
column5: The pressure is potentially associated with construction, maintenance, operational lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4399]. Telecommunication operations close to shore do not usually occur during dark hours due to safety considerations. Therefore, the pressure will be relevant if night operations are planned in SPAs where sensitive species could be present and at sensitive times of the year.

column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Bird collisions with vessels occurs and it is documented to higher particularly at night on lighted ships near coastal areas. These are more frequent also under poor visibility [4337]. Telecommunication operations close to shore do not usually occur during dark hours due to safety considerations. Therefore, the pressure will be relevant if operations are planned in SPAs where sensitive species could be present and at sensitive times of the year.

column3: Telecommunication cable: Laying, burial and protection
column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120],[4987]. Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].

column5: The pressure relates to the vibration produced by certain activities and does not include vessels as it assumed not to be significant. Activities resulting in vibration are for example trenching for cable laying [3101],[3804], dredging as the draghead is carried over the seabed or grab is operated [3804]; military activities and other developments involving explosives [3144], oil and gas drilling [3111],[3149], and activities involving piling (especially if vibropiling is used) [3078],[3128],[3154].

column3: Telecommunication cable: Laying, burial and protection
column5: The pressure is associated with sediment mobilisation and increased of suspended sediments as well as the deposition of organic matter. The pressure can result from a variety of activities including dredging, aquaculture, outflow, etc. [1441],[1436],[2834],[3096],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3163],[3186]. The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the intensity of the activity, the dynamic nature of the area, the temperature and the sediment type, making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891],[4899].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). column5: Vessels, vehicles and people movement can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as marine mammals and seabirds [5106],[5117]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity (e.g., location and timing of operation).
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177]. Moreover, thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity - including in relation to the size of the water body, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). More specifically, the risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed for prolonged periods of time in migratory channels for fish species.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: If the cable needs to be reburied or uncovered for repair, abrasion and physical disturbance will occur. The frequency of the activity will be very low. Usually, free-swimming burial machines are deployed for repair and maintenance to shallow bury exposed sections of cable into the seabed [3101]. The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels comparable to those used in some cable repair operations have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials [4971]. There is a tendency for the anchor to penetrate to deep depths in softer sediment as the opening of the anchor flukes prevents deep penetration in harder sediment [5076]. Typical maximum water depths for anchoring are between 100 m and 150 m. The pressure exerted by anchors will be low when smaller anchors are used and not applicable if Dynamic Positioning is used.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Though modern equipment and techniques reduce the re-suspension of sediment during cable burial, repair or removal, an increase in suspended sediment will occur but the magnitude depends on the silt fraction and background levels [3156]. Usually, free-swimming ROV burial machines are deployed for repair and maintenance to shallow bury exposed sections of cable into the seabed [3101]. The frequency of the activity will be low.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: If the cable needs to be reburied or uncovered for repair, abrasion and physical disturbance resulting in sediment re-suspension and deposition will occur. The frequency of the activity will be very low. Usually, free-swimming ROV burial machines are deployed for repair and maintenance to shallow bury exposed sections of cable into the seabed [3101]. During the process sediment re-suspension will occur and subsequent re-deposition on the seabed. The siltation rates will depend on the hydrological conditions, the amount of interaction with the seabed and the sediment particle size distribution of the seabed [4926],[4345].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: If the cable needs to be reburied or uncovered for repair, abrasion and physical disturbance will occur. The frequency of the activity will be very low. Usually, free-swimming burial machines are deployed for repair and maintenance to shallow bury exposed sections of cable into the seabed [3101]. Beyond this direct foot print, physical disturbance will also occur due to anchor handling inside the anchor corridor to a maximum of 1 km on each side of the cable. Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying the anchor and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery. The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials [4971]. The pressure exerted by anchors will be low when smaller anchors are used and not applicable if Dynamic Positioning is used.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Structures placed in the marine environment immediately interact with the local current regime. The use of external cable protection which sits proud of the seabed can potentially result in localised changes in water flow resulting in localised turbulence (especially at peak flow). The impact of this is expected to be much localised and limited [4345].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column4: Physical loss (to land or freshwater habitat)
column5: The pressure relates to changes in coastal or marine habitat due to manmade structures. During cable maintenance laying cables might need to be reburied or protected if they become unburied. Protection measures can be concrete mattresses, rock dumping, grout bags, frond mattresses, etc. resulting in a permanent loss of habitat where the structures are placed [3156]. For example, when using concrete mattressing or rock placement in soft sediment or where the rock is distinctly different from the natural rock i.e. granite protection on chalk bedrock.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column5: Cables and the protective structures such as concrete mattresses, rock dumping, grout mattress, frond mattresses, etc. will result in a change of habitat type [4926],[4345],[3101],[3156].

column5: Marine litter can be released into the marine environment by shipping vessels including cargo, bulk carrier, military, surveillance, research, passenger ships and non-commercial vessels, either accidentally (inappropriate storage) or deliberately [4974],[3160]. Shipping litter includes pallets, strapping bans and drums, as well as litter derived from containers lost at sea. Cargo may also be washed overboard during stormy weather and contribute to coastal litter levels. Shipping related litter contributes approximately 2 % of the litter found on UK beaches. Shipping related litter contributed approximately 45 litter items per kilometre around the UK on average between 2003 and 2007 [4915],[3160]. Litter should not be a licensing issue as all vessels adhere to MARPOL requirements, managed under the International Safety Management (ISM) Code which provides an International standard for the safe management and operation of ships and for pollution prevention.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Shipping is an important source of underwater noise. Although the majority of this will come from the propeller cavitation, on-board machinery and turbulence around the hull can also result in underwater noise being transmitted underwater. Different part of the vessel and different vessels emit at different frequencies. Generally, lower frequency with increasing size. Low frequency sounds generally travel farther and have the potential of impacting larger areas. [4921],[4995],[5173],[5172].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column5: The pressure is potentially associated with construction, maintenance, operational lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4399]. Telecommunication operations close to shore do not usually occur during dark hours due to safety considerations. Therefore, the pressure will be relevant if night operations are planned in SPAs where sensitive species could be present and at sensitive times of the year.

column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Bird collisions with vessels occurs and it is documented to higher particularly at night on lighted ships near coastal areas. These are more frequent also under poor visibility [4337]. Telecommunication operations close to shore do not usually occur during dark hours due to safety considerations. Therefore, the pressure will be relevant if operations are planned in SPAs where sensitive species could be present and at sensitive times of the year.

column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120],[4987]. Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column5: Noise can arise from many activities in the associated with cable laying and operation. The use of machinery, vessels, and people will result in an increase of above water noise. However, the magnitude of pressure would depend on the scale, intensity and duration of the activity.

column5: The pressure relates to the vibration produced by certain activities and does not include vessels as it assumed not to be significant. Activities resulting in vibration are for example trenching for cable laying [3101],[3804], dredging as the draghead is carried over the seabed or grab is operated [3804]; military activities and other developments involving explosives [3144], oil and gas drilling [3111],[3149], and activities involving piling (especially if vibropiling is used) [3078],[3128],[3154].

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: Vehicles and vessels may be used to remove coastal structures or natural habitat/barriers to enable inundation by water.  The use of excavators (whether marine or land based) may result in abrasion of the substrate.  This will arise from the use of the digging apparatus and from either the tracks/wheels of vehicles or anchors/jack up legs on vessels.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Moreover, antifouling compounds like TBT and copper wash from ship coatings with larger concentrations in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3032],[3096],[3107],[3164],[3101],[4333],[4985].

column4: Habitat structure changes - removal of substratum (extraction)
column5: The decommissioning process aims to minimize environmental effects allowing safe use of the seabed for other users. Cables and cable protection are either removed or left buried. If removal is required, then the habitat that was created by the structure through time will be removed [4926],[4345],[4344].

column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: Cables and cable protection are either removed or left on the seabed (cable protection) or buried. If the cable needs to be removed or cut for decommissioning, abrasion and physical disturbance will occur. For example to recover cables from the seabed to the surface a combination of towed grapnels and ROV techniques are used. The decommissioning process aims to minimize environmental effects allowing safe use of the seabed for other users. Cables and cable protection are either removed or left buried  [4926],[4345]. The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials [4971]. There is a tendency for the anchor to penetrate to deep depths in softer sediment as the opening of the anchor flukes prevents deep penetration in harder sediment [5076]. Typical maximum water depths for anchoring are between 100 m and 150 m. The pressure exerted by anchors will be low when smaller anchors are used and not applicable if Dynamic Positioning is used.

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: Cables and cable protection are either removed or left buried If the cable needs to be removed or cut for decommissioning, sediment disturbance will occur. For example to recover cables from the seabed to the surface a combination of towed grapnels and ROV techniques are used [4926],[4345],[4344]. Beyond this direct foot print, physical disturbance will also occur due to anchor handling inside the anchor corridor to a maximum of 1 km on each side of the cable. Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying the anchor and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery. The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials [4971]. The pressure exerted by anchors will be low when smaller anchors are used and not applicable if Dynamic Positioning is used.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Structures placed in the marine environment immediately interact with the local current regime. The use of external cable protection which sits proud of the seabed can potentially result in localised changes in water flow resulting in localised turbulence (especially at peak flow). The impact of this is expected to be very localised and limited [4345]. The removal if required during decommissioning will result in reversed impact.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Cables and the protective structures such as concrete mattresses, rock dumping, grout mattress, frond mattresses, etc. will result in a change of habitat type. The decommissioning process aims to minimize environmental effects allowing safe use of the seabed for other users, and in some circumstances this means just the disconnection of the cable and leaving it buried [4926],[4345],[3101],[3156],[4344].

column5: Marine litter can be released into the marine environment by shipping vessels including cargo, bulk carrier, military, surveillance, research, passenger ships and non-commercial vessels, either accidentally (inappropriate storage) or deliberately [4974],[3160]. Shipping litter includes pallets, strapping bans and drums, as well as litter derived from containers lost at sea. Cargo may also be washed overboard during stormy weather and contribute to coastal litter levels. Shipping related litter contributes approximately 2 % of the litter found on UK beaches. Shipping related litter contributed approximately 45 litter items per kilometre around the UK on average between 2003 and 2007 [4915],[3160]. Litter should not be a licensing issue as all vessels adhere to MARPOL requirements, managed under the International Safety Management (ISM) Code which provides an International standard for the safe management and operation of ships and for pollution prevention.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Habitat structure changes - removal of substratum (extraction)
column5: Navigation dredging results in the physical removal of substrate and thus associated habitats and species within the area to increase or maintain depths within navigation channels [3082],[2838],[3159].  The depth of material extracted during capital dredging projects can be over several metres.  For example, in Southampton it was necessary to deepen the existing berths from -10.2-12.2 m Chart Datum to -16 m Chart Datum as part of a berth extension project [4890].  The depth of material removed during maintenance dredging varies greatly depending on the location and target level required, generally between 0.5 m and 2 m of sediment is removed [4897],[4904].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Shipping is an important source of underwater noise. Although the majority of this will come from the propeller cavitation, on-board machinery and turbulence around the hull can also result in underwater noise being transmitted underwater. Different part of the vessel and different vessels emit at different frequencies. Generally, lower frequency with increasing size. Low frequency sounds generally travel farther and have the potential of impacting larger areas. [4921],[4995],[5173],[5172].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column5: The pressure is potentially associated with construction, maintenance, operational lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4399]. Telecommunication operations close to shore do not usually occur during dark hours due to safety considerations. Therefore, the pressure will be relevant if night operations are planned in SPAs where sensitive species could be present and at sensitive times of the year.

column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Bird collisions with vessels occurs and it is documented to higher particularly at night on lighted ships near coastal areas. These are more frequent also under poor visibility [4337]. Telecommunication operations close to shore do not usually occur during dark hours due to safety considerations. Therefore, the pressure will be relevant if operations are planned in SPAs where sensitive species could be present and at sensitive times of the year.

column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120],[4987]. Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].

column5: Noise can arise from many activities in the associated with cable laying and operation. The use of machinery, vessels, and people will result in an increase of above water noise. However, the magnitude of pressure would depend on the scale, intensity and duration of the activity.

column5: The pressure relates to the vibration produced by certain activities and does not include vessels as it assumed not to be significant. Activities resulting in vibration are for example trenching for cable laying [3101],[3804], dredging as the draghead is carried over the seabed or grab is operated [3804]; military activities and other developments involving explosives [3144], oil and gas drilling [3111],[3149], and activities involving piling (especially if vibropiling is used) [3078],[3128],[3154].

column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Moreover, antifouling compounds like TBT and copper wash from ship coatings with larger concentrations in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3032],[3096],[3107],[3164],[3101],[4333],[4985].

column5: There are several sources of organic and nutrient enrichment in the marine environment: outflows of domestic/industrial origin, sludge, sediment resuspension, aquaculture food and faeces, and others. Sediment mobilisation during dredging/trenching can increase the levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145],[5121]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899]. Sediments can have elevated levels of nutrients and organic matter locked within them (for example near aquaculture facilities or estuaries) and activities disturbing the sediment will release these nutrients making them available [4899].

column5: The pressure is associated with sediment mobilisation and increased of suspended sediments as well as the deposition of organic matter. The pressure can result from a variety of activities including dredging, aquaculture, outflow, etc. [1441],[1436],[2834],[3096],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3163],[3186]. The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the intensity of the activity, the dynamic nature of the area, the temperature and the sediment type, making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891],[4899].

column5: Ports and harbour (from construction, maintenance or operational ) activities including vessel, vehicle movement, plus people presence and movement can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as fish, marine mammals, seabirds and coastal birds [2497],[2763],[3134],[3154],[3106].  The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity, plus other factors such as species present and age, weather conditions, degree of habituation to disturbance source [5106],[5117],[4977].

column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur [3164],[3132],[3070].  All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177].  Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water, these include bacteria and other microbes, small invertebrates, eggs, cysts and larvae of various species.  It is estimated that 4,500 different species are carried around the world at any one time in ballast tanks.  During the last three decades, a significant number of introduced, non-indigenous species have been transported through ships’ ballast tanks [5023],[3164].  Artificial structures in the marine environment e.g. breakwaters and jetties, have the potential to act as ‘stepping stones’ for the spread of non-native species.  For example, the Australasian barnacle has been found to colonize concrete breakwaters rapidly in the Netherlands [5086].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity - including in relation to the size of the water body, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). More specifically, the risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed for prolonged periods of time in migratory channels for fish species.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Construction activities associated with excavation and navigation dredging result in the physical removal of substrate and thus associated habitats and species within the area.  Dredging and excavation will remove the biological habitats and communities within an area, however the significance of this removal depends on the extent and value of the habitats/species removed, plus recolonisation and recovery of disturbed areas.  [2838],[3145],[3159],[4899],[4379],[4380]
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: A variety of ports and harbour activities can result in penetration/disturbance/abrasion of the seabed; including structures placed (e.g. geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) or driven (e.g. piles) into the seabed [3106],[2838],[3159],[3161],[3145],[4912],[4903],[4913],[3223].  Piles used in coastal developments can be driven to depths of over -30 m Chart Datum, tubular piles are typically 1-2 m diameter, sheet piles typically 0.5-1 m wide and 0.1-0.2 m thick [4896],[4898],[4890].  Vessel movements can cause localised scour of the seabed, in shallow water, berth pockets, and navigation channels [5174],[3145].  Anchors can penetrate and disturb the seabed on deployment/recovery and due to dragging of the anchor and anchor chain.  The anchors of large vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed up to 1 m [4971], while small vessel anchors have been found to cause surface ‘scars’ of typically 1-4 m2 [5175]; and scouring of 6 m radius has been recorded on intertidal mudflats caused by anchor chains [5179],[4981].  Mooring chains from swinging moorings can also scour/disturb the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide [3223].  Navigation dredging and excavation activities result in the penetration of the seabed due to the physical removal of substrate [3082],[2838],[3159]; the depth of penetration during capital dredging can be several metres.  For example, in Southampton it was necessary to deepen the existing berths by 4-6 m as part of a berth extension project [4890].  The depth of material removed during maintenance dredging varies greatly, generally between 0.5 m and 2 m of sediment is removed [4897],[4904].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Dredging will cause local increases in suspended sediment, particularly in the direct vicinity of a dredge site. This sediment includes material disturbed at the drag head of the dredger and also some the overflow.  The relative elevation of suspended sediment above background levels will depend on dredge location, natural background level, type intensity, and duration of dredging, sediment characteristics.  The magnitude and spatial extent of the suspended sediment plume around dredging operations is a function of the type of dredge used, the physical and biological characteristics of the material being dredged (e.g., density, grain size, organic content) and site-specific hydrological conditions (e.g., currents, water body size/configuration).  A generalized "worst case" field can be defined as having suspended sediment levels less than or equal to 500 mg/L at distances less than or equal to 500 m from the dredge, with maximum concentrations generally restricted to the lower water column within 50-100 m, decreasing rapidly with distance [4899],[2838],[3082],[3106],[3159].  For example, the increase in suspended sediment concentrations as part of capital dredge project for a berth deepening in Southampton Water was predicted to be a few hundred mg/l above background levels immediately at the bucket/beneath the barge, with levels decreasing considerably within 100 m from the source and increases in suspended sediment concentrations between 10-20 mg/l expected along the plume [5078].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Dredging may cause local deposition of sediment in the area surrounding the dredge site [3159],[2838],[3106],[3082],[3134].  This sediment includes material disturbed at the drag head of the dredger and also material from the overflow.  Best available evidence suggests that such effects would be constrained to an area about half the size of the dredge site itself [4902].  Capital dredging typically causes siltation rate changes in the order of tens of millimetres. For example, the maximum amount of sedimentation during recent capital dredging for berth deepening works in Southampton Water was predicted to be up to 50 mm immediately beneath the dredger with very minor deposition (of the order of millimetres) predicted to occur in the wider area from the sediment plume.  Capital dredging as part of another project in Southampton Water was predicted to cause siltation of between  2-3 mm  and 60 mm in the surrounding area outside the deepened berth [4890],[4891],[5078].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Dredging may cause local deposition of sediment in the area surrounding the dredge site [3159],[2838],[3106],[3082],[3134].  This sediment includes material disturbed at the drag head of the dredger and also material from the overflow.  Best available evidence suggests that such effects would be constrained to an area about half the size of the dredge site itself [4902].  Capital dredging typically causes siltation rate changes in the order of tens of millimetres. For example, the maximum amount of sedimentation during recent capital dredging for berth deepening works in Southampton Water was predicted to be up to 50 mm immediately beneath the dredger with very minor deposition (of the order of millimetres) predicted to occur in the wider area from the sediment plume.  Capital dredging as part of another project in Southampton Water was predicted to cause siltation of between  2-3 mm  and 60 mm in the surrounding area outside the deepened berth [4890],[4891],[5078].

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: A variety of ports and harbour activities can result in abrasion/disturbance of the seabed; including structures placed (e.g. geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) or driven (e.g. piles) into the seabed [3106],[2838],[3159],[3161],[3145],[4912],[4903],[4913],[3223].  Piles used in coastal developments can be driven to depths of over -30 m Chart Datum, tubular piles are typically 1-2 m diameter, sheet piles typically 0.5-1 m wide and 0.1-0.2 m thick [4896],[4898],[4890].  Vessel movements can cause localised scour of the seabed, in shallow locations, berth pockets, in navigation channels [5174],[3145].  Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying/recovery plus abrasion caused by anchor dragging and the anchor chain.  The anchors of large vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed unto 1 m, depth of penetration by smaller inshore vessel anchors is expected to be less [4971].  Small vessel anchors have been found to cause surface ‘scars’ of typically 1-4 m2 [5175]; while scouring of 6 m radius has been recorded on intertidal mudflats caused by anchor chains [5179],[4981].  Mooring chains from swinging moorings can also scour the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide [3223].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Clearance of port and harbour structures and water ways
column5: Clearance of structures and slipways can mobilise material, increased suspended sediment, and subsequent siltation.  However will be below bench mark and pressure will be short-term.  The placement of structures in the marine environment can cause localised and temporary changes in suspended sediments and siltation, including those driven into the seabed (such as piles used in berths) or placed on the seabed (such as geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) [3145]
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Structures or material placed in the marine environment associated with ports and harbours (including solid and piled structures) will change the form/profile of an area of seabed or an estuary.  This results in localised changes flow rates and tidal regime, intercepting flows causing changes in speed and direction to flow round, past, or across new structures e.g. coastal developments, ports and harbour structures, jetties, breakwaters, land reclaim, dredge disposal, habitat creation.  The magnitude and effect will be related to the size, type, and shape of the structure/placement of material, the magnitude of change to the seabed/estuary profile compared to the overall size of the system/estuary [2817],[3079],[3154],[3159],[3153],[3161],[3106],[3082],[4892],[4893],[3145],[5075],[4873].  For example a large reclaim or structure at the mouth of an estuary could result in  changes which impact an entire estuary and the surrounding marine environment, whereas a new small structure within an estuary is likely to result in more limited localised changes [4892],[3079],[4376].  Similarly changing seabed/estuary profile due to the removal of substrate (capital dredging) or structures (decommissioning) will result in similar changes, causing localised changes to the hydrodynamic flow in an area.  The magnitude and type of effect relates to the overall size of the excavation/removal compared to the overall size of the system/estuary, these changes are then sustained by maintenance dredging [3145],[4899],[2838],[3082],[3134].  For example, flow speed changes of just over 0.1 m/s were predicted for a large capital dredging in Southampton Water [4891].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Emergence regime changes, including tidal level change considerations
column5: Structures or material placed in the marine environment associated with ports and harbours (including solid and piled structures) will change the form/profile of an area of seabed or estuary, resulting in localised changes to the tide.  Construction of (large scale) ports and harbour infrastructure particularly in estuaries (and associated activities, capital dredging, land reclaim), will alter seabed/estuary profile resulting in changes in tidal flows, propagation altering the tidal curve and tidal in an area/estuary [3161],[3153],[4376].  For example a large reclaim or new structure at the mouth of an estuary can result in tidal regime changes which impact an entire estuary [4892],[4376].  Similarly changes in seabed/estuary profile due to the removal of substrate (capital dredging) or structures (decommissioning) will result in similar changes [3159],[2838].  For example, a large capital dredging in Southampton Water resulted in tidal regime changes causing in a reduction of a few millimetres around Southampton Water [4891].  The magnitude and effect will be related to the size, type, and shape of the structure/excavation, the magnitude of change to the seabed/estuary profile compared to the overall size of the system/estuary [3159],[3153],[3161],[3106],[3082],[4892],[4893],[3145],[5075].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Construction of new ports and harbour infrastructure and associated activities including capital dredging, land reclaim, piling, can result in localised changes to wave exposure.  Structures used in coastal port and marina development such as breakwaters and marina walls can cause sheltering effects on the lee of structures and increased wave reflection effects  [3106],[3154],[3161],[3153].  For example, a proposed breakwater extension project in Cowes, Isle of Wight was predicted to cause up to a 60 % reduction in significant wave height inside the breakwater and an increase in wave reflection from northerly winds outside the breakwater [4892].  Local changes in shore profile and topography associated with the disposal of dredged material for environmental beneficial use, intertidal or beach recharge, and the re-profiling of the shore to enable habitat creation can also result in changes to wave exposure [2838],[1669],[1674],[3085].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The materials used for construction or placement activities can alter seabed type, materials used include: timber; iron and steel; concrete; clay, silt, sand, gravel or stone/rock; plastic or other synthetic materials [3161].  Construction and presence of structures in ports and harbours will cause a change in habitat type, typically from soft sediment to a hard substratum type; examples include steel piles used in berths/jetties, concrete and rock used in breakwaters/quays [4892],[4890].  Construction activities associated with excavation and navigation dredging result in the physical removal of substrate and associated habitats and species resulting in a change in seabed type.  The degree of change will depend on the sensitivity and recoverability of the communities and frequency, duration and magnitude of activity.  Changes in seabed type can also arise from the alteration of the topography, hydrography, and sediment compositions associated resulting from these activities.  Alteration of hydrodynamic conditions as a result of capital dredge (or land reclaim) can change seabed sediment composition and distribution e.g. reduced current flow causing deposition of finer sediment and consequential change in benthic community. Capital dredging can also remove substrate to a depth that the underlying substrate is altered, thus result in a change in habitat and benthic community [2838],[3134],[3145],[3159],[4899],[4379],[4380].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

Construction activities associated with excavation and navigation dredging result in the physical removal of substrate and associated habitats and species resulting in a change in seabed type.  The degree of change will depend on the sensitivity and recoverability of the communities and frequency, duration and magnitude of activity.  Changes in seabed type can also arise from the alteration of the topography, hydrography, and sediment compositions associated resulting from these activities.  Alteration of hydrodynamic conditions as a result of capital dredge (or land reclaim) can change seabed sediment composition and distribution e.g. reduced current flow causing deposition of finer sediment and consequential change in benthic community. Capital dredging can also remove substrate to a depth that the underlying substrate is altered, thus result in a change in habitat and benthic community [2838],[3134],[3145],[3159],[4899],[4379],[4380].

column5: Ports construction and maintenance works and on-going operations can result in underwater noise, including from vessels, dredging, engineering works.  Underwater noise can result in disturbance particularly to mobile receptors such as fish, bird, mammals [3152],[3164],[3159],[3106],[2074],[3128],[3069],[4995].  Shipping vessels are important source of underwater noise, and is the dominant contributor to ambient noise in shallow water areas close to shipping lanes and in deeper waters [5173],[5172].  Shipping noise is most evident in the 50-300 Hz frequency range, with the majority of noise coming from propeller cavitation, on-board machinery, and turbulence around the hull.  The noise emitted from vessels varies, in general larger vessels generate lower frequency sound.  The source levels associated with large ships (supertankers/container ships) is in the range 180-190 dB re 1 µPa-m (RMS).  Small sea going vessels typically produce broadband noise at source levels of 160-180 dB re 1 µPa-m (RMS) [3096],[4908].  Measurements of underwater noise from backhoe dredging operations have indicated that the highest levels of underwater noise occur when the excavator is in contact with the seabed.  Dredging produces broadband and continuous sound, mainly at lower frequencies (<1 kHz; source sound pressure levels 160 to more than 190 dB re 1 µPa at 1 m) [4908],[3152].  However it is impulsive/impact sound generated by explosives/piling which causes the most concern of injury and displacement of mobile species from underwater noise [3152],[2074],[3128],[3069].  Impact piling generates high levels of underwater noise, a typical peak to peak source noise pressure levels underwater for tubular piles used in coastal environments range of 220-235 dB re. 1 uPa @ 1 m. Sheet piling noise is generally lower with typical predicted peak to peak source noise level of 212 dB re. 1 uPa @ 1 m (for 600mm sheet pile) [4908].Engineering works in coastal environments using blasting to remove unwanted hard substrate can to produce source peak noise levels of 257 dB re: 1 µPa (borehole blasting with a charge of 20 kg ) [4916].

column5: The pressure is potentially associated with construction, maintenance, operational lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4339].

column5: The pressure refers to obstructions to species movement caused by physical barrier or prolonged exposure to noise, light, visual disturbance or changes in water quality.  The scale of the impact will depend on scale of activity and the location and will need to be considered on case-by-case basis to determine relevance to given feature/site.  Coastal development can result in barriers to species movement through increase noise (e.g. construction, shipping, acoustic deterrents), lighting, presence of structures, changes to water quality and suspended sediments [2817],[3085],[3096],[3106],[3195],[2763],[3111],[2834],[3152],[3273],[2707],[2825],[1533],[3136],[3145],[3169].  Coastal defences and structures can also result in barrier to species by restricting access to rivers/streams/estuaries or for species to adapt to sea level rise and coastal change [2817],[3096],[3154].  The noise and turbidity arising from dredging operations may pose a barrier to species migration when occurring on or in proximity of specific migratory routes [3152],[3080],[2757],[2838].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Pressure associated with vessels and vessel movements associated with this sub-activity, also presence of relevant underwater structures.  Seabirds can be impacted directly by a wide range of artificial light sources within marine environment: seabirds can be attracted to and collide with lighthouses, coastal resorts and other urban lighting, offshore hydrocarbon platforms, commercial fishing vessels and other boats using lights [4378],[4337].  Evidence indicates some bird species are attracted to light sources, which may increase the risk of bird strikes.  Most related studies conclude that increased darkness, coupled with inclement weather, increases attraction by birds to lighted vessels and structures.  Birds drawn to light often become disoriented and can then collide with these vessels/structures resulting in injury and death [4377].  In the case of vessels, it known that nocturnal bird strikes tend to occur when bright, artificial light sources are used at times of poor visibility, typically during bad weather, often angled outwards or upwards from the vessel and when the vessel is relatively close to large breeding aggregations of seabirds (rather than further offshore); however, here are relatively few sources of quantified information relating to seabird strikes on vessels [4378],[4337].

column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Pressure associated with vessels and vessel movements associated with this sub-activity, also presence of relevant underwater structures.  Vessels are documented to have collided with mobile marine species (particularly marine mammals).  Almost all vessel sizes and classes have been involved in collisions with marine mammals, including cargo ships, ferries (particularly the newer models of high-speed ferry), cruise liners, navy ships, recreational vessels, and research vessels.  Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull.  The most lethal and serious injuries are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots [5120].  Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long.  Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120],[4987].  A lack of information exists regarding collision risk of animals (e.g. birds, fish, marine mammals) with underwater structures, especially for birds.  The response of birds will depend on their detection of a device and any associated structures.  The risk of collision may be increased if the devices alter the characteristics of the current, especially if such changes create new foraging opportunities, since this may impact on the manoeuvrability and underwater swimming agility of birds [4959],[5075].  Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].

column5: Noise can arise from many activities in the marine environment, the use of machinery, vessels, equipment, explosives, and people will generate airborne (above water) noise.  Port construction, maintenance, and operation activities generate airborne noise and can increase noise above background/ambient noise levels; this can result in disturbance particularly to mobile receptors such as fish, bird, mammals [2817],[3085],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3164],[3082],[2763].  Examples of noise sources vessels, construction plant/operations, piling, operational use of machinery [2817],[1533],[3136],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3169],[3145].  However, the magnitude of pressure would depend on the scale, intensity, and duration of the activity, and relative increase in noise above the natural ambient background noise levels and the type of noise generated [3136],[3078],[3195],[1536].

column5: The pressure relates to the vibration produced by certain activities and does not include vessels as it assumed not to be significant.  Ports and harbour activities which can result in vibration include dredging, piling and other construction works [3078],[3128],[3154],[4367],[4366].  Note most vibration transmitted into the water column will radiate as underwater noise, most vibration is transmitted through the ground/seabed [4366].

column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5:
The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Moreover, antifouling compounds like TBT and copper wash from ship coatings with larger concentrations in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3096],[3106],[3107],[3164],[3155],[4985].

Activities can also result in the re-mobilisation of contaminants/substances (e.g. from sediments) during construction/maintenance/operational activities.  The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of existing contamination and intensity of activity.  High levels of contaminants do occur in fine sediments of some industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated areas/sediments is rare in the England [4899],[3145],[2838],[3159].

column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs).  Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999.  This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur.  Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year.  Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers) [3096],[3106],[3164],[4968],[4972],[4985].  Organic based contaminants such as PAHs can be effectively ‘locked into’ the seabed sediments in ports and harbours.  These stable compounds do not decompose readily; subsequent re-mobilisation (e.g. by dredging) can release these contaminants into the water column.  The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of sediment contamination and level of re-mobilisation of the sediment.  The highest levels of contaminants generally occur in fine sediment in industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated sediments is rare in the England [2838],[3159],[3163],[4899],[3145].
