column4: Synthetic compound contamination (incl. pesticides, antifoulants, pharmaceuticals).  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Synthetic compounds used in a variety of substances for commercial applications are carried by shipping tankers and cargo ships.  These can be spilled into the sea through loss of cargo, collision, grounding, mechanical failure, and deliberate dumping.  Many of these compounds are considered toxic or hazardous.  Accidental spillages around the UK are generally rare.  Chemicals can also be released into the sea through ships ‘flushing’, or washing, their tanks and clearing ballast water [3096],[3106],[3107],[3164],[3157],[4968],[4972].  For example it is currently legal to discharge Polyisobutene (PIB) from ships into the marine environment under certain conditions; PIB is a man-made synthetic product used in the manufacture of sealants, adhesive tape and chewing gum.  PIB is a hydrophobic substance though, so on contact with water it coalesces into a waxy, glue-like formation, generally floating at or just underneath the surface.  As such it is extremely hazardous to a range of seabird species, which dive to find food [4975].  Synthetic compounds e.g. polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) can be effectively ‘locked into’ the seabed sediments in ports and harbours.  These stable compounds do not decompose readily.  Subsequent re-mobilisation of the sediments (e.g. by dredging) can release these contaminants into the water column. The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of sediment contamination and level of re-mobilisation of the sediment.  The highest levels of contaminants generally occur in fine sediment in industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated sediments is rare in the England [2838],[3159],[4899],[3145].

column4: Introduction of other substances (solid, liquid or gas)
column5:
Ports and Harbour activity can result in the accidental, operational, incidental release of substances (e.g. via vessels/vehicles from ballast water, antifoulants, hull contamination, waste products, litter), much of which is restricted/regulated [3106],[3107],[3164],[3157],[3160],[3159].

Activities can also result in the re-mobilisation of contaminants/substances (e.g. from sediments) during construction/maintenance/operational activities.  The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of existing contamination and intensity of activity.  High levels of contaminants do occur in fine sediments of some industrialised estuaries. However, the occurrence of very contaminated areas/sediments is rare in the England [4899],[3145],[2838].

column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: All estuarine/marine sediments are radioactive to different degrees, these may be entirely natural or be naturally-occurring but in enhanced concentrations due to human activities or as a result of nuclear power generation and nuclear weapons production/use [4899].  Radionuclides from several categories may co-exist.  Estuarine and coastal sediments can contain elevated levels of radionuclides as a result of human activity and can reveal a history of local contamination [4483].  The London Convention (LC), modified in 1990s, bans the sea disposal of all radioactive wastes.  However further consideration was required due to ubiquitous nature of radioactivity (natural and artificial), as a strict interpretation of the LC would prohibited all disposal of any materials.  The International Atomic Energy Agency developed the concept of de minimis, for concentrations sufficiently low to allow their disposal; based on the principle, that protection of the human population would ensure adequate protection of non-human populations [4371].  The Environment Agency authorises discharges of radioactive waste to the environment in England, under the Radioactive Substances Act 1993 [4372],[4373].  They have assessed the impact of these discharges on Natura 2000 sites [4373], involving the calculation of dose rates to organisms in coastal, freshwater and terrestrial environments.  The total dose rates were compared to a threshold of 40microgray/h, below which the Environment Agency, Natural England and the Countryside Council for Wales agreed there would be no adverse effect to the integrity of a Natura 2000 sites.  The total dose rates are less than 40 microgray/h for all but two Natura 2000 sites (Ribble and Alt Estuaries SPA and Drigg Coast SAC).  The calculated total dose rate to the worst affected organism for the Ribble and Alt Estuaries SAC was 520 microgray/h, significantly in excess of the threshold.  A further assessment has been undertaken and new limits for industry on the Ribble implemented to ensure that the dose will be less than 40 microgray/h [4375].  The total dose rate for the Drigg Coast SAC is just greater than the 40 microgray/h threshold [4373].  Under the LC dredged material containing radioactivity at/below de minimis levels can be disposed of at sea; regulators require an assessment where compliance with de minimis levels has not been established or may be exceeded.  A 2006 review for dredging operations in England and Wales found that in most regions radionuclide concentrations fell well within de minimis criteria [4374].  Dredging operations in the Irish Sea included material that approached the de minimis criteria, these higher doses at ports such as Mayport on the Cumbrian coast, were due to a combination of artificial radionuclides released from the Sellafield nuclear fuel reprocessing plant (especially 137Cs, 241Am, Pu isotopes) and enhanced levels of naturally-occurring radionuclides resulting from non-nuclear industry (phosphate processing) near Whitehaven [4374],[4484],[4899],[4375].

column5: There are several sources of organic and nutrient enrichment in the marine environment which can result from ports and harbour activities; including discharges, outflows, sediment mobilisation, and dredge disposal [3145],[3106].  The mobilisation of sediment due to vessel movements, dredging, and disposal (including disposal associated with habitat creation) can increase levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145],[2838].  However, monitoring has shown that elevated nutrient and organic matter levels following most dredging campaigns are localised, temporal and maybe within natural variability [4899].  Disposal of wastes including regulated discharge of wastewater into the marine environment can result in nutrient enrichment [4915],[3185],[2293],[3096].  Excessive nutrient enrichment can lead to a risk of eutrophication, changes in the species composition of communities, algal blooms, development of hypoxic conditions due to decomposition of excess plant biomass, fatalities of fauna due to oxygen deficiencies [4915],[2293].

Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The pressure is associated with sediment mobilisation and increased of suspended sediments as well as the deposition of organic matter.  The pressure can result from a variety of ports and harbour activities including dredging, dredge disposal including alternative disposal and beneficial use of sediments , mobilisation of sediment due to vessel movements and construction activities [2834],[3096],[3153],[3161],[3163],[3106],[3159].  The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the dynamic nature and physical characteristics of the area, sediment type, temperature; making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891].  For example the release of organic rich sediments during dredging or disposal can result in the localised removal of oxygen from the surrounding water [3159],[2834],[3163],[4899].  Dredging activities in areas with an existing problem with dissolved oxygen, or extensive dredging of sediments with a high chemical oxygen demand, could affect dissolved oxygen.  However, in practice, monitoring data suggests that such effects are unlikely in most cases [4902].  Following the placement of dredged material at a disposal site, there is the potential for some localised reduction in dissolved oxygen concentrations in the water column.  Given the dynamic nature of many disposal sites, the water column is likely to be rapidly re-oxygenated, making any changes localised and very short-lived [3163],[2834],[4891].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.

column5: Ports and harbour (from construction, maintenance or operational ) activities including vessel, vehicle movement, plus people presence and movement can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as fish, marine mammals, seabirds and coastal birds [2497],[2763],[3134],[3154],[3106].  The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity, plus other factors such as species present and age, weather conditions, degree of habituation to disturbance source [5106],[5117],[4977].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur [3164],[3132],[3070].  All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177].  Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water, these include bacteria and other microbes, small invertebrates, eggs, cysts and larvae of various species.  It is estimated that 4,500 different species are carried around the world at any one time in ballast tanks.  During the last three decades, a significant number of introduced, non-indigenous species have been transported through ships’ ballast tanks [5023],[3164].  Artificial structures in the marine environment e.g. breakwaters and jetties, have the potential to act as ‘stepping stones’ for the spread of non-native species.  For example, the Australasian barnacle has been found to colonize concrete breakwaters rapidly in the Netherlands [5086].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity - including in relation to the size of the water body, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). More specifically, the risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed for prolonged periods of time in migratory channels for fish species.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Operation
column5: The presence and operation of coastal flood defences can result in changes to sediment patterns with scour or erosion in some areas and siltation or accretion in others [2817].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: A variety of ports and harbour activities can result in penetration/disturbance/abrasion of the seabed; including structures placed (e.g. geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) or driven (e.g. piles) into the seabed [3106],[2838],[3159],[3161],[3145],[4912],[4903],[4913],[3223].  Piles used in coastal developments can be driven to depths of over -30 m Chart Datum, tubular piles are typically 1-2 m diameter, sheet piles typically 0.5-1 m wide and 0.1-0.2 m thick [4896],[4898],[4890].  Vessel movements can cause localised scour of the seabed, in shallow water, berth pockets, and navigation channels [5174],[3145].  Anchors can penetrate and disturb the seabed on deployment/recovery and due to dragging of the anchor and anchor chain.  The anchors of large vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed up to 1 m [4971], while small vessel anchors have been found to cause surface ‘scars’ of typically 1-4 m2 [5175]; and scouring of 6 m radius has been recorded on intertidal mudflats caused by anchor chains [5179],[4981].  Mooring chains from swinging moorings can also scour/disturb the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide [3223].  Navigation dredging and excavation activities result in the penetration of the seabed due to the physical removal of substrate [3082],[2838],[3159]; the depth of penetration during capital dredging can be several metres.  For example, in Southampton it was necessary to deepen the existing berths by 4-6 m as part of a berth extension project [4890].  The depth of material removed during maintenance dredging varies greatly, generally between 0.5 m and 2 m of sediment is removed [4897],[4904].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Dredging will cause local increases in suspended sediment, particularly in the direct vicinity of a dredge site. This sediment includes material disturbed at the drag head of the dredger and also some the overflow.  The relative elevation of suspended sediment above background levels will depend on dredge location, natural background level, type intensity, and duration of dredging, sediment characteristics.  The magnitude and spatial extent of the suspended sediment plume around dredging operations is a function of the type of dredge used, the physical and biological characteristics of the material being dredged (e.g., density, grain size, organic content) and site-specific hydrological conditions (e.g., currents, water body size/configuration).  A generalized "worst case" field can be defined as having suspended sediment levels less than or equal to 500 mg/L at distances less than or equal to 500 m from the dredge, with maximum concentrations generally restricted to the lower water column within 50-100 m, decreasing rapidly with distance [4899],[2838],[3082],[3106],[3159].  For example, the increase in suspended sediment concentrations as part of capital dredge project for a berth deepening in Southampton Water was predicted to be a few hundred mg/l above background levels immediately at the bucket/beneath the barge, with levels decreasing considerably within 100 m from the source and increases in suspended sediment concentrations between 10-20 mg/l expected along the plume [5078].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Dredging may cause local deposition of sediment in the area surrounding the dredge site [3159],[2838],[3106],[3082],[3134].  This sediment includes material disturbed at the drag head of the dredger and also material from the overflow.  Best available evidence suggests that such effects would be constrained to an area about half the size of the dredge site itself [4902].  Capital dredging typically causes siltation rate changes in the order of tens of millimetres. For example, the maximum amount of sedimentation during recent capital dredging for berth deepening works in Southampton Water was predicted to be up to 50 mm immediately beneath the dredger with very minor deposition (of the order of millimetres) predicted to occur in the wider area from the sediment plume.  Capital dredging as part of another project in Southampton Water was predicted to cause siltation of between  2-3 mm  and 60 mm in the surrounding area outside the deepened berth [4890],[4891],[5078].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Dredging may cause local deposition of sediment in the area surrounding the dredge site [3159],[2838],[3106],[3082],[3134].  This sediment includes material disturbed at the drag head of the dredger and also material from the overflow.  Best available evidence suggests that such effects would be constrained to an area about half the size of the dredge site itself [4902].  Capital dredging typically causes siltation rate changes in the order of tens of millimetres. For example, the maximum amount of sedimentation during recent capital dredging for berth deepening works in Southampton Water was predicted to be up to 50 mm immediately beneath the dredger with very minor deposition (of the order of millimetres) predicted to occur in the wider area from the sediment plume.  Capital dredging as part of another project in Southampton Water was predicted to cause siltation of between  2-3 mm  and 60 mm in the surrounding area outside the deepened berth [4890],[4891],[5078].

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: A variety of ports and harbour activities can result in abrasion/disturbance of the seabed; including structures placed (e.g. geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) or driven (e.g. piles) into the seabed [3106],[2838],[3159],[3161],[3145],[4912],[4903],[4913],[3223].  Piles used in coastal developments can be driven to depths of over -30 m Chart Datum, tubular piles are typically 1-2 m diameter, sheet piles typically 0.5-1 m wide and 0.1-0.2 m thick [4896],[4898],[4890].  Vessel movements can cause localised scour of the seabed, in shallow locations, berth pockets, in navigation channels [5174],[3145].  Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying/recovery plus abrasion caused by anchor dragging and the anchor chain.  The anchors of large vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed unto 1 m, depth of penetration by smaller inshore vessel anchors is expected to be less [4971].  Small vessel anchors have been found to cause surface ‘scars’ of typically 1-4 m2 [5175]; while scouring of 6 m radius has been recorded on intertidal mudflats caused by anchor chains [5179],[4981].  Mooring chains from swinging moorings can also scour the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide [3223].

column5: Ports and harbour (from construction, maintenance or operational ) activities including vessel, vehicle movement, plus people presence and movement can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as fish, marine mammals, seabirds and coastal birds [2497],[2763],[3134],[3154],[3106].  The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity, plus other factors such as species present and age, weather conditions, degree of habituation to disturbance source [5106],[5117],[4977].

column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Structures or material placed in the marine environment associated with ports and harbours (including solid and piled structures) will change the form/profile of an area of seabed or an estuary.  This results in localised changes flow rates and tidal regime, intercepting flows causing changes in speed and direction to flow round, past, or across new structures e.g. coastal developments, ports and harbour structures, jetties, breakwaters, land reclaim, dredge disposal, habitat creation.  The magnitude and effect will be related to the size, type, and shape of the structure/placement of material, the magnitude of change to the seabed/estuary profile compared to the overall size of the system/estuary [2817],[3079],[3154],[3159],[3153],[3161],[3106],[3082],[4892],[4893],[3145],[5075],[4873].  For example a large reclaim or structure at the mouth of an estuary could result in  changes which impact an entire estuary and the surrounding marine environment, whereas a new small structure within an estuary is likely to result in more limited localised changes [4892],[3079],[4376].  Similarly changing seabed/estuary profile due to the removal of substrate (capital dredging) or structures (decommissioning) will result in similar changes, causing localised changes to the hydrodynamic flow in an area.  The magnitude and type of effect relates to the overall size of the excavation/removal compared to the overall size of the system/estuary, these changes are then sustained by maintenance dredging [3145],[4899],[2838],[3082],[3134].  For example, flow speed changes of just over 0.1 m/s were predicted for a large capital dredging in Southampton Water [4891].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Emergence regime changes, including tidal level change considerations
column5: Structures or material placed in the marine environment associated with ports and harbours (including solid and piled structures) will change the form/profile of an area of seabed or estuary, resulting in localised changes to the tide.  Construction of (large scale) ports and harbour infrastructure particularly in estuaries (and associated activities, capital dredging, land reclaim), will alter seabed/estuary profile resulting in changes in tidal flows, propagation altering the tidal curve and tidal in an area/estuary [3161],[3153],[4376].  For example a large reclaim or new structure at the mouth of an estuary can result in tidal regime changes which impact an entire estuary [4892],[4376].  Similarly changes in seabed/estuary profile due to the removal of substrate (capital dredging) or structures (decommissioning) will result in similar changes [3159],[2838].  For example, a large capital dredging in Southampton Water resulted in tidal regime changes causing in a reduction of a few millimetres around Southampton Water [4891].  The magnitude and effect will be related to the size, type, and shape of the structure/excavation, the magnitude of change to the seabed/estuary profile compared to the overall size of the system/estuary [3159],[3153],[3161],[3106],[3082],[4892],[4893],[3145],[5075].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Ports construction and maintenance works and on-going operations can result in underwater noise, including from vessels, dredging, engineering works.  Underwater noise can result in disturbance particularly to mobile receptors such as fish, bird, mammals [3152],[3164],[3159],[3106],[2074],[3128],[3069],[4995].  Shipping vessels are important source of underwater noise, and is the dominant contributor to ambient noise in shallow water areas close to shipping lanes and in deeper waters [5173],[5172].  Shipping noise is most evident in the 50-300 Hz frequency range, with the majority of noise coming from propeller cavitation, on-board machinery, and turbulence around the hull.  The noise emitted from vessels varies, in general larger vessels generate lower frequency sound.  The source levels associated with large ships (supertankers/container ships) is in the range 180-190 dB re 1 µPa-m (RMS).  Small sea going vessels typically produce broadband noise at source levels of 160-180 dB re 1 µPa-m (RMS) [3096],[4908].  Measurements of underwater noise from backhoe dredging operations have indicated that the highest levels of underwater noise occur when the excavator is in contact with the seabed.  Dredging produces broadband and continuous sound, mainly at lower frequencies (<1 kHz; source sound pressure levels 160 to more than 190 dB re 1 µPa at 1 m) [4908],[3152].  However it is impulsive/impact sound generated by explosives/piling which causes the most concern of injury and displacement of mobile species from underwater noise [3152],[2074],[3128],[3069].  Impact piling generates high levels of underwater noise, a typical peak to peak source noise pressure levels underwater for tubular piles used in coastal environments range of 220-235 dB re. 1 uPa @ 1 m. Sheet piling noise is generally lower with typical predicted peak to peak source noise level of 212 dB re. 1 uPa @ 1 m (for 600 mm sheet pile) [4908].Engineering works in coastal environments using blasting to remove unwanted hard substrate can to produce source peak noise levels of 257 dB re: 1 µPa (borehole blasting with a charge of 20 kg ) [4916].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.

column5: The pressure is potentially associated with construction, maintenance, operational lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4339].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column5: The pressure refers to obstructions to species movement caused by physical barrier or prolonged exposure to noise, light, visual disturbance or changes in water quality.  The scale of the impact will depend on scale of activity and the location and will need to be considered on case-by-case basis to determine relevance to given feature/site.  Coastal development can result in barriers to species movement through increase noise (e.g. construction, shipping, acoustic deterrents), lighting, presence of structures, changes to water quality and suspended sediments [2817],[3085],[3096],[3106],[3195],[2763],[3111],[2834],[3152],[3273],[2707],[2825],[1533],[3136],[3145],[3169].  Coastal defences and structures can also result in barrier to species by restricting access to rivers/streams/estuaries or for species to adapt to sea level rise and coastal change [2817],[3096],[3154].  The noise and turbidity arising from dredging operations may pose a barrier to species migration when occurring on or in proximity of specific migratory routes [3152],[3080],[2757],[2838].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Depending on methods used removal of foundations and scour protection may lead to temporary increases in suspended solids and siltation [4387], although levels of sediment disturbed may be lower than during construction [4388]. The dragging of anchors used by vessels involved in decommissioning activities can cause localised and temporary increases in suspended sediments [3223].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Pressure associated with vessels and vessel movements associated with this sub-activity, also presence of relevant underwater structures.  Seabirds can be impacted directly by a wide range of artificial light sources within marine environment: seabirds can be attracted to and collide with lighthouses, coastal resorts and other urban lighting, offshore hydrocarbon platforms, commercial fishing vessels and other boats using lights [4378],[4337].  Evidence indicates some bird species are attracted to light sources, which may increase the risk of bird strikes.  Most related studies conclude that increased darkness, coupled with inclement weather, increases attraction by birds to lighted vessels and structures.  Birds drawn to light often become disoriented and can then collide with these vessels/structures resulting in injury and death [4377].  In the case of vessels, it known that nocturnal bird strikes tend to occur when bright, artificial light sources are used at times of poor visibility, typically during bad weather, often angled outwards or upwards from the vessel and when the vessel is relatively close to large breeding aggregations of seabirds (rather than further offshore); however, here are relatively few sources of quantified information relating to seabird strikes on vessels [4378],[4337].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Pressure associated with vessels and vessel movements associated with this sub-activity, also presence of relevant underwater structures.  Vessels are documented to have collided with mobile marine species (particularly marine mammals).  Almost all vessel sizes and classes have been involved in collisions with marine mammals, including cargo ships, ferries (particularly the newer models of high-speed ferry), cruise liners, navy ships, recreational vessels, and research vessels.  Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull.  The most lethal and serious injuries are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots [5120].  Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long.  Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120],[4987].  A lack of information exists regarding collision risk of animals (e.g. birds, fish, marine mammals) with underwater structures, especially for birds.  The response of birds will depend on their detection of a device and any associated structures.  The risk of collision may be increased if the devices alter the characteristics of the current, especially if such changes create new foraging opportunities, since this may impact on the manoeuvrability and underwater swimming agility of birds [4959],[5075].  Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].

column5: Noise can arise from many activities in the marine environment, the use of machinery, vessels, equipment, explosives, and people will generate airborne (above water) noise.  Port construction, maintenance, and operation activities generate airborne noise and can increase noise above background/ambient noise levels; this can result in disturbance particularly to mobile receptors such as fish, bird, mammals [2817],[3085],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3164],[3082],[2763].  Examples of noise sources vessels, construction plant/operations, piling, operational use of machinery [2817],[1533],[3136],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3169],[3145].  However, the magnitude of pressure would depend on the scale, intensity, and duration of the activity, and relative increase in noise above the natural ambient background noise levels and the type of noise generated [3136],[3078],[3195],[1536].

column5: The pressure relates to the vibration produced by certain activities and does not include vessels as it assumed not to be significant.  Ports and harbour activities which can result in vibration include dredging, piling and other construction works [3078],[3128],[3154],[4367],[4366].  Note most vibration transmitted into the water column will radiate as underwater noise, most vibration is transmitted through the ground/seabed [4366].

column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5:
The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Moreover, antifouling compounds like TBT and copper wash from ship coatings with larger concentrations in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3096],[3106],[3107],[3164],[3155],[4985].

Activities can also result in the re-mobilisation of contaminants/substances (e.g. from sediments) during construction/maintenance/operational activities.  The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of existing contamination and intensity of activity.  High levels of contaminants do occur in fine sediments of some industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated areas/sediments is rare in the England [4899],[3145],[2838],[3159].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs).  Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999.  This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur.  Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year.  Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers) [3096],[3106],[3164],[4968],[4972],[4985].  Organic based contaminants such as PAHs can be effectively ‘locked into’ the seabed sediments in ports and harbours.  These stable compounds do not decompose readily; subsequent re-mobilisation (e.g. by dredging) can release these contaminants into the water column.  The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of sediment contamination and level of re-mobilisation of the sediment.  The highest levels of contaminants generally occur in fine sediment in industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated sediments is rare in the England [2838],[3159],[3163],[4899],[3145].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Synthetic compound contamination (incl. pesticides, antifoulants, pharmaceuticals).  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Synthetic compounds used in a variety of substances for commercial applications are carried by shipping tankers and cargo ships.  These can be spilled into the sea through loss of cargo, collision, grounding, mechanical failure, and deliberate dumping.  Many of these compounds are considered toxic or hazardous.  Accidental spillages around the UK are generally rare.  Chemicals can also be released into the sea through ships ‘flushing’, or washing, their tanks and clearing ballast water [3096],[3106],[3107],[3164],[3157],[4968],[4972].  For example it is currently legal to discharge Polyisobutene (PIB) from ships into the marine environment under certain conditions; PIB is a man-made synthetic product used in the manufacture of sealants, adhesive tape and chewing gum.  PIB is a hydrophobic substance though, so on contact with water it coalesces into a waxy, glue-like formation, generally floating at or just underneath the surface.  As such it is extremely hazardous to a range of seabird species, which dive to find food [4975].  Synthetic compounds e.g. polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) can be effectively ‘locked into’ the seabed sediments in ports and harbours.  These stable compounds do not decompose readily.  Subsequent re-mobilisation of the sediments (e.g. by dredging) can release these contaminants into the water column. The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of sediment contamination and level of re-mobilisation of the sediment.  The highest levels of contaminants generally occur in fine sediment in industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated sediments is rare in the England [2838],[3159],[4899],[3145].

column4: Introduction of other substances (solid, liquid or gas)
column5:
Ports and Harbour activity can result in the accidental, operational, incidental release of substances (e.g. via vessels/vehicles from ballast water, antifoulants, hull contamination, waste products, litter), much of which is restricted/regulated [3106],[3107],[3164],[3157],[3160],[3159].

Activities can also result in the re-mobilisation of contaminants/substances (e.g. from sediments) during construction/maintenance/operational activities.  The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of existing contamination and intensity of activity.  High levels of contaminants do occur in fine sediments of some industrialised estuaries. However, the occurrence of very contaminated areas/sediments is rare in the England [4899],[3145],[2838].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: All estuarine/marine sediments are radioactive to different degrees, these may be entirely natural or be naturally-occurring but in enhanced concentrations due to human activities or as a result of nuclear power generation and nuclear weapons production/use [4899].  Radionuclides from several categories may co-exist.  Estuarine and coastal sediments can contain elevated levels of radionuclides as a result of human activity and can reveal a history of local contamination [4483].  The London Convention (LC), modified in 1990s, bans the sea disposal of all radioactive wastes.  However further consideration was required due to ubiquitous nature of radioactivity (natural and artificial), as a strict interpretation of the LC would prohibited all disposal of any materials.  The International Atomic Energy Agency developed the concept of de minimis, for concentrations sufficiently low to allow their disposal; based on the principle, that protection of the human population would ensure adequate protection of non-human populations [4371].  The Environment Agency authorises discharges of radioactive waste to the environment in England, under the Radioactive Substances Act 1993 [4372],[4373].  They have assessed the impact of these discharges on Natura 2000 sites [4373], involving the calculation of dose rates to organisms in coastal, freshwater and terrestrial environments.  The total dose rates were compared to a threshold of 40 microgray/h, below which the Environment Agency, Natural England and the Countryside Council for Wales agreed there would be no adverse effect to the integrity of a Natura 2000 sites.  The total dose rates are less than 40 microgray/h for all but two Natura 2000 sites (Ribble and Alt Estuaries SPA and Drigg Coast SAC).  The calculated total dose rate to the worst affected organism for the Ribble and Alt Estuaries SAC was 520 microgray/h, significantly in excess of the threshold.  A further assessment has been undertaken and new limits for industry on the Ribble implemented to ensure that the dose will be less than 40 microgray/h [4375].  The total dose rate for the Drigg Coast SAC is just greater than the 40 microgray/h threshold [4373].  Under the LC dredged material containing radioactivity at/below de minimis levels can be disposed of at sea; regulators require an assessment where compliance with de minimis levels has not been established or may be exceeded.  A 2006 review for dredging operations in England and Wales found that in most regions radionuclide concentrations fell well within de minimis criteria [4374].  Dredging operations in the Irish Sea included material that approached the de minimis criteria, these higher doses at ports such as Mayport on the Cumbrian coast, were due to a combination of artificial radionuclides released from the Sellafield nuclear fuel reprocessing plant (especially 137 Cs, 241 Am, Pu isotopes) and enhanced levels of naturally-occurring radionuclides resulting from non-nuclear industry (phosphate processing) near Whitehaven [4374],[4484],[4899],[4375].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.

column5: There are several sources of organic and nutrient enrichment in the marine environment which can result from ports and harbour activities; including discharges, outflows, sediment mobilisation, and dredge disposal [3145],[3106].  The mobilisation of sediment due to vessel movements, dredging, and disposal (including disposal associated with habitat creation) can increase levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145],[2838].  However, monitoring has shown that elevated nutrient and organic matter levels following most dredging campaigns are localised, temporal and maybe within natural variability [4899].  Disposal of wastes including regulated discharge of wastewater into the marine environment can result in nutrient enrichment [4915],[3185],[2293],[3096].  Excessive nutrient enrichment can lead to a risk of eutrophication, changes in the species composition of communities, algal blooms, development of hypoxic conditions due to decomposition of excess plant biomass, fatalities of fauna due to oxygen deficiencies [4915],[2293].

column3: Port and harbour structures: Maintenance (if relevant see also ‘Slipway: Maintenance and construction')
column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur [3164],[3132],[3070].  All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177].  Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water, these include bacteria and other microbes, small invertebrates, eggs, cysts and larvae of various species.  It is estimated that 4,500 different species are carried around the world at any one time in ballast tanks.  During the last three decades, a significant number of introduced, non-indigenous species have been transported through ships’ ballast tanks [5023],[3164].  Artificial structures in the marine environment e.g. breakwaters and jetties, have the potential to act as ‘stepping stones’ for the spread of non-native species.  For example, the Australasian barnacle has been found to colonize concrete breakwaters rapidly in the Netherlands [5086].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity - including in relation to the size of the water body, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). More specifically, the risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed for prolonged periods of time in migratory channels for fish species.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The pressure is associated with sediment mobilisation and increased of suspended sediments as well as the deposition of organic matter.  The pressure can result from a variety of ports and harbour activities including dredging, dredge disposal including alternative disposal and beneficial use of sediments , mobilisation of sediment due to vessel movements and construction activities [2834],[3096],[3153],[3161],[3163],[3106],[3159].  The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the dynamic nature and physical characteristics of the area, sediment type, temperature; making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891].  For example the release of organic rich sediments during dredging or disposal can result in the localised removal of oxygen from the surrounding water [3159],[2834],[3163],[4899].  Dredging activities in areas with an existing problem with dissolved oxygen, or extensive dredging of sediments with a high chemical oxygen demand, could affect dissolved oxygen.  However, in practice, monitoring data suggests that such effects are unlikely in most cases [4902].  Following the placement of dredged material at a disposal site, there is the potential for some localised reduction in dissolved oxygen concentrations in the water column.  Given the dynamic nature of many disposal sites, the water column is likely to be rapidly re-oxygenated, making any changes localised and very short-lived [3163],[2834],[4891].

column3: Clearance of port and harbour structures and water ways
column5: Ports and harbour (from construction, maintenance or operational ) activities including vessel, vehicle movement, plus people presence and movement can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as fish, marine mammals, seabirds and coastal birds [2497],[2763],[3134],[3154],[3106].  The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity, plus other factors such as species present and age, weather conditions, degree of habituation to disturbance source [5106],[5117],[4977].

column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur [3164],[3132],[3070].  All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177].  Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water, these include bacteria and other microbes, small invertebrates, eggs, cysts and larvae of various species. During the last three decades, a significant number of introduced, non-indigenous species have been transported through ships’ ballast tanks [5023],[3164].  Artificial structures in the marine environment e.g. breakwaters and jetties, have the potential to act as ‘stepping stones’ for the spread of non-native species. column3: Clearance of port and harbour structures and water ways
column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: A variety of ports and harbour activities can result in penetration/disturbance/abrasion of the seabed; including structures placed (e.g. geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) or driven (e.g. piles) into the seabed [3106],[2838],[3159],[3161],[3145],[4912],[4903],[4913],[3223].  Piles used in coastal developments can be driven to depths of over -30 m Chart Datum, tubular piles are typically 1-2 m diameter, sheet piles typically 0.5-1 m wide and 0.1-0.2 m thick [4896],[4898],[4890].  Vessel movements can cause localised scour of the seabed, in shallow water, berth pockets, and navigation channels [5174],[3145].  Anchors can penetrate and disturb the seabed on deployment/recovery and due to dragging of the anchor and anchor chain.  The anchors of large vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed up to 1 m [4971], while small vessel anchors have been found to cause surface ‘scars’ of typically 1-4 m2 [5175]; and scouring of  6m radius has been recorded on intertidal mudflats caused by anchor chains [5179],[4981].  Mooring chains from swinging moorings can also scour/disturb the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide [3223].  Navigation dredging and excavation activities result in the penetration of the seabed due to the physical removal of substrate [3082],[2838],[3159]; the depth of penetration during capital dredging can be several metres.  For example, in Southampton it was necessary to deepen the existing berths by 4-6 m as part of a berth extension project [4890].  The depth of material removed during maintenance dredging varies greatly, generally between 0.5 m and 2 m of sediment is removed [4897],[4904].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.

column5: Clearance of structures and slipways can mobilise material and cause increase in suspended sediment.  However will be below bench mark and pressure will be short-term. The placement of structures in the marine environment can cause localised and temporary changes in suspended sediments, including those driven into the seabed (such as piles used in berths) or placed on the seabed (such as geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) [3145]

column5: The presence and operation of coastal flood defences can result in changes to sediment patterns with scour or erosion in some areas and siltation or accretion in others [2817].

column3: Clearance of port and harbour structures and water ways
column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: A variety of ports and harbour activities can result in abrasion/disturbance of the seabed; including structures placed (e.g. geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) or driven (e.g. piles) into the seabed [3106],[2838],[3159],[3161],[3145],[4912],[4903],[4913],[3223].  Piles used in coastal developments can be driven to depths of over -30 m Chart Datum, tubular piles are typically 1-2 m diameter, sheet piles typically 0.5-1 m wide and 0.1-0.2 m thick [4896],[4898],[4890].  Vessel movements can cause localised scour of the seabed, in shallow locations, berth pockets, in navigation channels [5174],[3145].  Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying/recovery plus abrasion caused by anchor dragging and the anchor chain.  The anchors of large vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed unto 1 m, depth of penetration by smaller inshore vessel anchors is expected to be less [4971].  Small vessel anchors have been found to cause surface ‘scars’ of typically 1-4m2 [5175]; while scouring of 6 m radius has been recorded on intertidal mudflats caused by anchor chains [5179],[4981].  Mooring chains from swinging moorings can also scour the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide [3223].

column3: Clearance of port and harbour structures and water ways
column5: Ports construction and maintenance works and on-going operations can result in underwater noise, including from vessels, dredging, engineering works.  Underwater noise can result in disturbance particularly to mobile receptors such as fish, bird, mammals [3152],[3164],[3159],[3106],[2074],[3128],[3069],[4995].  Shipping vessels are important source of underwater noise, and is the dominant contributor to ambient noise in shallow water areas close to shipping lanes and in deeper waters [5173],[5172].  Shipping noise is most evident in the 50-300 Hz frequency range, with the majority of noise coming from propeller cavitation, on-board machinery, and turbulence around the hull.  The noise emitted from vessels varies, in general larger vessels generate lower frequency sound.  The source levels associated with large ships (supertankers/container ships) is in the range 180-190 dB re 1µPa-m (RMS).  Small sea going vessels typically produce broadband noise at source levels of 160-180 dB re 1µPa-m (RMS) [3096],[4908].  Measurements of underwater noise from backhoe dredging operations have indicated that the highest levels of underwater noise occur when the excavator is in contact with the seabed.  Dredging produces broadband and continuous sound, mainly at lower frequencies (<1 kHz; source sound pressure levels 160 to more than 190 dB re 1 µPa at 1 m) [4908],[3152].  However it is impulsive/impact sound generated by explosives/piling which causes the most concern of injury and displacement of mobile species from underwater noise [3152],[2074],[3128],[3069].  Impact piling generates high levels of underwater noise, a typical peak to peak source noise pressure levels underwater for tubular piles used in coastal environments range of 220-235 dB re. 1 uPa @ 1 m. Sheet piling noise is generally lower with typical predicted peak to peak source noise level of 212 dB re. 1 uPa @ 1 m (for 600mm sheet pile) [4908].Engineering works in coastal environments using blasting to remove unwanted hard substrate can to produce source peak noise levels of 257 dB re: 1 µPa (borehole blasting with a charge of 20kg ) [4916].

column3: Clearance of port and harbour structures and water ways
column5: The pressure is potentially associated with construction, maintenance, operational lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4339].

column3: Clearance of port and harbour structures and water ways
column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Pressure associated with vessels and vessel movements associated with this sub-activity, also presence of relevant underwater structures.  Vessels are documented to have collided with mobile marine species (particularly marine mammals).  Almost all vessel sizes and classes have been involved in collisions with marine mammals, including cargo ships, ferries (particularly the newer models of high-speed ferry), cruise liners, navy ships, recreational vessels, and research vessels.  Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull.  The most lethal and serious injuries are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots [5120].  Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long.  Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120],[4987].  A lack of information exists regarding collision risk of animals (e.g. birds, fish, marine mammals) with underwater structures, especially for birds.  The response of birds will depend on their detection of a device and any associated structures.  The risk of collision may be increased if the devices alter the characteristics of the current, especially if such changes create new foraging opportunities, since this may impact on the manoeuvrability and underwater swimming agility of birds [4959],[5075].  Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].

column3: Clearance of port and harbour structures and water ways
column5: Noise can arise from many activities in the marine environment, the use of machinery, vessels, equipment, explosives, and people will generate airborne (above water) noise.  Port construction, maintenance, and operation activities generate airborne noise and can increase noise above background/ambient noise levels; this can result in disturbance particularly to mobile receptors such as fish, bird, mammals [2817],[3085],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3164],[3082],[2763].  Examples of noise sources vessels, construction plant/operations, piling, operational use of machinery [2817],[1533],[3136],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3169],[3145].  However, the magnitude of pressure would depend on the scale, intensity, and duration of the activity, and relative increase in noise above the natural ambient background noise levels and the type of noise generated [3136],[3078],[3195],[1536].

Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Clearance of port and harbour structures and water ways
column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5:
The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Moreover, antifouling compounds like TBT and copper wash from ship coatings with larger concentrations in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3096],[3106],[3107],[3164],[3155],[4985].

Activities can also result in the re-mobilisation of contaminants/substances (e.g. from sediments) during construction/maintenance/operational activities.  The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of existing contamination and intensity of activity.  High levels of contaminants do occur in fine sediments of some industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated areas/sediments is rare in the England [4899],[3145],[2838],[3159].

column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Clearance of port and harbour structures and water ways
column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs).  Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999.  This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur.  Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year.  Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers) [3096],[3106],[3164],[4968],[4972],[4985].  Organic based contaminants such as PAHs can be effectively ‘locked into’ the seabed sediments in ports and harbours.  These stable compounds do not decompose readily; subsequent re-mobilisation (e.g. by dredging) can release these contaminants into the water column.  The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of sediment contamination and level of re-mobilisation of the sediment.  The highest levels of contaminants generally occur in fine sediment in industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated sediments is rare in the England [2838],[3159],[3163],[4899],[3145].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Clearance of port and harbour structures and water ways
column4: Synthetic compound contamination (incl. pesticides, antifoulants, pharmaceuticals).  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Synthetic compounds used in a variety of substances for commercial applications are carried by shipping tankers and cargo ships.  These can be spilled into the sea through loss of cargo, collision, grounding, mechanical failure, and deliberate dumping.  Many of these compounds are considered toxic or hazardous.  Accidental spillages around the UK are generally rare.  Chemicals can also be released into the sea through ships ‘flushing’, or washing, their tanks and clearing ballast water [3096],[3106],[3107],[3164],[3157],[4968],[4972].  For example it is currently legal to discharge Polyisobutene (PIB) from ships into the marine environment under certain conditions; PIB is a man-made synthetic product used in the manufacture of sealants, adhesive tape and chewing gum.  PIB is a hydrophobic substance though, so on contact with water it coalesces into a waxy, glue-like formation, generally floating at or just underneath the surface.  As such it is extremely hazardous to a range of seabird species, which dive to find food [4975].  Synthetic compounds e.g. polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) can be effectively ‘locked into’ the seabed sediments in ports and harbours.  These stable compounds do not decompose readily.  Subsequent re-mobilisation of the sediments (e.g. by dredging) can release these contaminants into the water column. The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of sediment contamination and level of re-mobilisation of the sediment.  The highest levels of contaminants generally occur in fine sediment in industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated sediments is rare in the England [2838],[3159],[4899],[3145].

column3: Clearance of port and harbour structures and water ways
column4: Introduction of other substances (solid, liquid or gas)
column5:
Ports and Harbour activity can result in the accidental, operational, incidental release of substances (e.g. via vessels/vehicles from ballast water, antifoulants, hull contamination, waste products, litter), much of which is restricted/regulated [3106],[3107],[3164],[3157],[3160],[3159].

Activities can also result in the re-mobilisation of contaminants/substances (e.g. from sediments) during construction/maintenance/operational activities.  The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of existing contamination and intensity of activity.  High levels of contaminants do occur in fine sediments of some industrialised estuaries. However, the occurrence of very contaminated areas/sediments is rare in the England [4899],[3145],[2838].

column3: Port and harbour structures: Maintenance (if relevant see also ‘Slipway: Maintenance and construction')
column5: Ports and harbour (from construction, maintenance or operational ) activities including vessel, vehicle movement, plus people presence and movement can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as fish, marine mammals, seabirds and coastal birds [2497],[2763],[3134],[3154],[3106].  The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity, plus other factors such as species present and age, weather conditions, degree of habituation to disturbance source [5106],[5117],[4977].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Operation
column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: The presence and operation of coastal flood defences can result in changes to sediment patterns with scour or erosion in some areas and siltation or accretion in others [2817].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Port and harbour structures: Maintenance (if relevant see also ‘Slipway: Maintenance and construction')
column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: A variety of ports and harbour activities can result in penetration/disturbance/abrasion of the seabed; including structures placed (e.g. geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) or driven (e.g. piles) into the seabed [3106],[2838],[3159],[3161],[3145],[4912],[4903],[4913],[3223].  Piles used in coastal developments can be driven to depths of over -30 m Chart Datum, tubular piles are typically 1-2 m diameter, sheet piles typically 0.5-1 m wide and 0.1-0.2 m thick [4896],[4898],[4890].  Vessel movements can cause localised scour of the seabed, in shallow water, berth pockets, and navigation channels [5174],[3145].  Anchors can penetrate and disturb the seabed on deployment/recovery and due to dragging of the anchor and anchor chain.  The anchors of large vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed up to 1 m [4971], while small vessel anchors have been found to cause surface ‘scars’ of typically 1-4 m2 [5175]; and scouring of 6 m radius has been recorded on intertidal mudflats caused by anchor chains [5179],[4981].  Mooring chains from swinging moorings can also scour/disturb the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide [3223].  Navigation dredging and excavation activities result in the penetration of the seabed due to the physical removal of substrate [3082],[2838],[3159]; the depth of penetration during capital dredging can be several metres.  For example, in Southampton it was necessary to deepen the existing berths by 4-6 m as part of a berth extension project [4890].  The depth of material removed during maintenance dredging varies greatly, generally between 0.5m and 2 m of sediment is removed [4897],[4904].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Port and harbour structures: Maintenance (if relevant see also ‘Slipway: Maintenance and construction')
column5: Associated with mobilisation of sediments and increased suspended material, linked to dredging, dredge disposal, structure construction, replacement, and repair activities.  Construction work activities and the placement of structures in the marine environment can cause localised and temporary changes in suspended sediments, including those driven into the seabed (such as piles used in berths) or placed on the seabed (such as geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) [3145],[4892],[4890].  Dredging will cause local increases in suspended sediment, particularly in the direct vicinity of a dredge site. This sediment includes material disturbed at the drag head of the dredger and also some the overflow.  The relative elevation of suspended sediment above background levels will depend on dredge location, natural background level, type intensity, and duration of dredging, sediment characteristics.  [4899],[2838],[3082],[3106],[3159].  Disposal of dredged material will cause increases in suspended sediment concentrations with the extent of sediment plumes dependant on the scale of the activity and type of material [3159],[3082],[2838].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Port and harbour structures: Maintenance (if relevant see also ‘Slipway: Maintenance and construction')
column5: Associated with works activity, also associated dredging, dredgings disposal, alternative use of sediment, causing mobilisation of sediment and increased siltation rates.  The placement and burial of structures can cause localised and temporary changes in suspended sediments. This can lead to increases in siltation rates in the direct vicinity of the works [4892],[3145],[4890].  Dredging may cause local deposition of sediment in the area surrounding the dredge site [3159],[2838],[3106],[3082],[3134].  This sediment includes material disturbed at the drag head of the dredger and also material from the overflow.  Best available evidence suggests that such effects would be constrained to an area about half the size of the dredge site itself [4902].  Disposal of dredged material can cause localised increases in siltation rates [3159],[2838],[3106].  During an experiment in the southern North Sea which aimed to replicate the disposal of maintenance dredged material, fluid mud layers were observed forming due to the settling of suspended matter [5085].

High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.

column5: Associated with works activity, also associated dredging, dredgings disposal, alternative use of sediment, causing mobilisation of sediment and increased siltation rates. Best available evidence suggests that such effects would be constrained to an area about half the size of the dredge site itself [4902]. column3: Port and harbour structures: Maintenance (if relevant see also ‘Slipway: Maintenance and construction')
column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: A variety of ports and harbour activities can result in abrasion/disturbance of the seabed; including structures placed (e.g. geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) or driven (e.g. piles) into the seabed [3106],[2838],[3159],[3161],[3145],[4912],[4903],[4913],[3223].  Piles used in coastal developments can be driven to depths of over -30 m Chart Datum, tubular piles are typically 1-2 m diameter, sheet piles typically 0.5-1 m wide and 0.1-0.2 m thick [4896],[4898],[4890].  Vessel movements can cause localised scour of the seabed, in shallow locations, berth pockets, in navigation channels [5174],[3145].  Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying/recovery plus abrasion caused by anchor dragging and the anchor chain.  The anchors of large vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed unto 1 m, depth of penetration by smaller inshore vessel anchors is expected to be less [4971].  Small vessel anchors have been found to cause surface ‘scars’ of typically 1-4 m2 [5175]; while scouring of 6 m radius has been recorded on intertidal mudflats caused by anchor chains [5179],[4981].  Mooring chains from swinging moorings can also scour the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide [3223].

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Operation
column5: The pressure can result when a coastal structure inhibits/restricts/regulates sea water intrusion or percolation of seawater through sand/shingle to lagoons or seeps [2817],[3154],[1674].
