column5: Noise can arise from many activities in the marine environment, the use of machinery, vessels, equipment, explosives, and people will generate airborne (above water) noise.  Port construction, maintenance, and operation activities generate airborne noise and can increase noise above background/ambient noise levels; this can result in disturbance particularly to mobile receptors such as fish, bird, mammals [2817],[3085],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3164],[3082],[2763].  Examples of noise sources vessels, construction plant/operations, piling, operational use of machinery [2817],[1533],[3136],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3169],[3145].  However, the magnitude of pressure would depend on the scale, intensity, and duration of the activity, and relative increase in noise above the natural ambient background noise levels and the type of noise generated [3136],[3078],[3195],[1536].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5:
The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Moreover, antifouling compounds like TBT and copper wash from ship coatings with larger concentrations in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3096],[3106],[3107],[3164],[3155],[4985].

Activities can also result in the re-mobilisation of contaminants/substances (e.g. from sediments) during construction/maintenance/operational activities.  The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of existing contamination and intensity of activity.  High levels of contaminants do occur in fine sediments of some industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated areas/sediments is rare in the England [4899],[3145],[2838],[3159].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs).  Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999.  This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur.  Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year.  Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers) [3096],[3106],[3164],[4968],[4972],[4985].  Organic based contaminants such as PAHs can be effectively ‘locked into’ the seabed sediments in ports and harbours.  These stable compounds do not decompose readily; subsequent re-mobilisation (e.g. by dredging) can release these contaminants into the water column.  The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of sediment contamination and level of re-mobilisation of the sediment.  The highest levels of contaminants generally occur in fine sediment in industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated sediments is rare in the England [2838],[3159],[3163],[4899],[3145].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Synthetic compound contamination (incl. pesticides, antifoulants, pharmaceuticals).  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Synthetic compounds used in a variety of substances for commercial applications are carried by shipping tankers and cargo ships.  These can be spilled into the sea through loss of cargo, collision, grounding, mechanical failure, and deliberate dumping.  Many of these compounds are considered toxic or hazardous.  Accidental spillages around the UK are generally rare.  Chemicals can also be released into the sea through ships ‘flushing’, or washing, their tanks and clearing ballast water [3096],[3106],[3107],[3164],[3157],[4968],[4972].  For example it is currently legal to discharge Polyisobutene (PIB) from ships into the marine environment under certain conditions; PIB is a man-made synthetic product used in the manufacture of sealants, adhesive tape and chewing gum.  PIB is a hydrophobic substance though, so on contact with water it coalesces into a waxy, glue-like formation, generally floating at or just underneath the surface.  As such it is extremely hazardous to a range of seabird species, which dive to find food [4975].  Synthetic compounds e.g. polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) can be effectively ‘locked into’ the seabed sediments in ports and harbours.  These stable compounds do not decompose readily.  Subsequent re-mobilisation of the sediments (e.g. by dredging) can release these contaminants into the water column. The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of sediment contamination and level of re-mobilisation of the sediment.  The highest levels of contaminants generally occur in fine sediment in industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated sediments is rare in the England [2838],[3159],[4899],[3145].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Introduction of other substances (solid, liquid or gas)
column5:
Ports and Harbour activity can result in the accidental, operational, incidental release of substances (e.g. via vessels/vehicles from ballast water, antifoulants, hull contamination, waste products, litter), much of which is restricted/regulated [3106],[3107],[3164],[3157],[3160],[3159].

Activities can also result in the re-mobilisation of contaminants/substances (e.g. from sediments) during construction/maintenance/operational activities.  The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of existing contamination and intensity of activity.  High levels of contaminants do occur in fine sediments of some industrialised estuaries. However, the occurrence of very contaminated areas/sediments is rare in the England [4899],[3145],[2838].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Ports and harbour (from construction, maintenance or operational ) activities including vessel, vehicle movement, plus people presence and movement can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as fish, marine mammals, seabirds and coastal birds [2497],[2763],[3134],[3154],[3106].  The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity, plus other factors such as species present and age, weather conditions, degree of habituation to disturbance source [5106],[5117],[4977].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Operation
column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5:
Structures placed in the marine environment immediately interact with the local current regime. Structures added to the coastal environment as a result of coastal defence schemes, coastal developments, artificial reefs, etc., can change local flow conditions. In particular, cross-shore structures such as groynes and harbour arms can intercept flow paths, causing flows to divert around or across the structures [4892],[4893],[4894],[4873],[5075],[4960],[3125],[4961]. 
Coastal defence structures can result in changing coastal regime, and substantial schemes especially in estuaries could result in changes to tides/water flow, especially where associated with reclaim or dredging [2817],[3085],[3096],[3138],[3154],[1674].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur [3164],[3132],[3070].  All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177].  Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water, these include bacteria and other microbes, small invertebrates, eggs, cysts and larvae of various species.  It is estimated that 4,500 different species are carried around the world at any one time in ballast tanks.  During the last three decades, a significant number of introduced, non-indigenous species have been transported through ships’ ballast tanks [5023],[3164].  Artificial structures in the marine environment e.g. breakwaters and jetties, have the potential to act as ‘stepping stones’ for the spread of non-native species.  For example, the Australasian barnacle has been found to colonize concrete breakwaters rapidly in the Netherlands [5086].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity - including in relation to the size of the water body, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). More specifically, the risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed for prolonged periods of time in migratory channels for fish species.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Construction activities associated with excavation and navigation dredging result in the physical removal of substrate and thus associated habitats and species within the area.  Dredging and excavation will remove the biological habitats and communities within an area, however the significance of this removal depends on the extent and value of the habitats/species removed, plus recolonisation and recovery of disturbed areas.  [2838],[3145],[3159],[4899],[4379],[4380]
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: A variety of ports and harbour activities can result in penetration/disturbance/abrasion of the seabed; including structures placed (e.g. geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) or driven (e.g. piles) into the seabed [3106],[2838],[3159],[3161],[3145],[4912],[4903],[4913],[3223].  Piles used in coastal developments can be driven to depths of over -30 m Chart Datum, tubular piles are typically 1-2 m diameter, sheet piles typically 0.5-1 m wide and 0.1-0.2 m thick [4896],[4898],[4890].  Vessel movements can cause localised scour of the seabed, in shallow water, berth pockets, and navigation channels [5174],[3145].  Anchors can penetrate and disturb the seabed on deployment/recovery and due to dragging of the anchor and anchor chain.  The anchors of large vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed up to 1 m [4971], while small vessel anchors have been found to cause surface ‘scars’ of typically 1-4 m2 [5175]; and scouring of 6 m radius has been recorded on intertidal mudflats caused by anchor chains [5179],[4981].  Mooring chains from swinging moorings can also scour/disturb the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide [3223].  Navigation dredging and excavation activities result in the penetration of the seabed due to the physical removal of substrate [3082],[2838],[3159]; the depth of penetration during capital dredging can be several metres.  For example, in Southampton it was necessary to deepen the existing berths by 4-6 m as part of a berth extension project [4890].  The depth of material removed during maintenance dredging varies greatly, generally between 0.5 m and 2 m of sediment is removed [4897],[4904].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Construction activities and the placement of structures in the marine environment can cause localised and temporary changes in suspended sediments, including those driven into the seabed (such as piles used in berths) or placed on the seabed (such as geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) [3145],[4892],[4890]. Activities associated with intertidal recharge or alternative use of sediment will result in mobilisation of sediment and result in localised increases suspended sediment [3134],[2838],[3106],[3145].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Associated with works activity, also associated dredging, dredgings disposal, alternative use of sediment, causing mobilisation of sediment and increased siltation rates.  The placement and burial of structures can cause localised and temporary changes in suspended sediments. This can lead to increases in siltation rates in the direct vicinity of the works [4892],[3145],[4890].  Dredging may cause local deposition of sediment in the area surrounding the dredge site [3159],[2838],[3106],[3082],[3134].  This sediment includes material disturbed at the drag head of the dredger and also material from the overflow.  Best available evidence suggests that such effects would be constrained to an area about half the size of the dredge site itself [4902].  Disposal of dredged material can cause localised increases in siltation rates [3159],[2838],[3106].  During an experiment in the southern North Sea which aimed to replicate the disposal of maintenance dredged material, fluid mud layers were observed forming due to the settling of suspended matter [5085].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Associated with works activity, also associated dredging, dredgings disposal, alternative use of sediment, causing mobilisation of sediment and increased siltation rates.  The placement and burial of structures can cause localised and temporary changes in suspended sediments. This can lead to increases in siltation rates in the direct vicinity of the works [4892],[3145],[4890].  Dredging may cause local deposition of sediment in the area surrounding the dredge site [3159],[2838],[3106],[3082],[3134].  This sediment includes material disturbed at the drag head of the dredger and also material from the overflow.  Best available evidence suggests that such effects would be constrained to an area about half the size of the dredge site itself [4902].  Disposal of dredged material can cause localised increases in siltation rates [3159],[2838],[3106].  During an experiment in the southern North Sea which aimed to replicate the disposal of maintenance dredged material, fluid mud layers were observed forming due to the settling of suspended matter [5085].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Port and harbour structures: Construction (if relevant see also 'Slipway: Maintenance and construction')
column4: Physical loss (to land or freshwater habitat)
column5: Ports and harbour developments through land reclaim, construction of new structures can result in the loss of marine habitat to terrestrial/freshwater habitat; the scale and type of loss is depend on the scale and type of construction project [3096],[3106],[2838],[3153],[3154].  For example, the Cardiff Barrage which was built as part of a dockland redevelopment project in 1999 involved the loss of c. 200 ha of intertidal habitat in Cardiff Bay and conversion to a freshwater lake [4381].  In Southampton Water berth extensions since the 1960s has reclaimed over 80 ha of subtidal and intertidal habitat with individual projects varying in size from several hectares to over 40 ha [4890].  Dredged material (capital and maintenance) has been used for land reclamation, creation of freshwater/terrestrial habitats [2838],[3163],[3153],[4382].  For example, maintenance dredging spoil was used to reclaim over 170 ha of land in Dibden Bay, Southampton Water between 1930 and 1970 [4890].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: A variety of ports and harbour activities can result in abrasion/disturbance of the seabed; including structures placed (e.g. geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) or driven (e.g. piles) into the seabed [3106],[2838],[3159],[3161],[3145],[4912],[4903],[4913],[3223].  Piles used in coastal developments can be driven to depths of over -30 m Chart Datum, tubular piles are typically 1-2 m diameter, sheet piles typically 0.5-1 m wide and 0.1-0.2 m thick [4896],[4898],[4890].  Vessel movements can cause localised scour of the seabed, in shallow locations, berth pockets, in navigation channels [5174],[3145].  Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying/recovery plus abrasion caused by anchor dragging and the anchor chain.  The anchors of large vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed unto 1 m, depth of penetration by smaller inshore vessel anchors is expected to be less [4971].  Small vessel anchors have been found to cause surface ‘scars’ of typically 1-4 m2 [5175]; while scouring of 6 m radius has been recorded on intertidal mudflats caused by anchor chains [5179],[4981].  Mooring chains from swinging moorings can also scour the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide [3223].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Structures or material placed in the marine environment associated with ports and harbours (including solid and piled structures) will change the form/profile of an area of seabed or an estuary.  This results in localised changes flow rates and tidal regime, intercepting flows causing changes in speed and direction to flow round, past, or across new structures e.g. coastal developments, ports and harbour structures, jetties, breakwaters, land reclaim, dredge disposal, habitat creation.  The magnitude and effect will be related to the size, type, and shape of the structure/placement of material, the magnitude of change to the seabed/estuary profile compared to the overall size of the system/estuary [2817],[3079],[3154],[3159],[3153],[3161],[3106],[3082],[4892],[4893],[3145],[5075],[4873].  For example a large reclaim or structure at the mouth of an estuary could result in  changes which impact an entire estuary and the surrounding marine environment, whereas a new small structure within an estuary is likely to result in more limited localised changes [4892],[3079],[4376].  Similarly changing seabed/estuary profile due to the removal of substrate (capital dredging) or structures (decommissioning) will result in similar changes, causing localised changes to the hydrodynamic flow in an area.  The magnitude and type of effect relates to the overall size of the excavation/removal compared to the overall size of the system/estuary, these changes are then sustained by maintenance dredging [3145],[4899],[2838],[3082],[3134].  For example, flow speed changes of just over 0.1 m/s were predicted for a large capital dredging in Southampton Water [4891].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Emergence regime changes, including tidal level change considerations
column5: Structures or material placed in the marine environment associated with ports and harbours (including solid and piled structures) will change the form/profile of an area of seabed or estuary, resulting in localised changes to the tide.  Construction of (large scale) ports and harbour infrastructure particularly in estuaries (and associated activities, capital dredging, land reclaim), will alter seabed/estuary profile resulting in changes in tidal flows, propagation altering the tidal curve and tidal in an area/estuary [3161],[3153],[4376].  For example a large reclaim or new structure at the mouth of an estuary can result in tidal regime changes which impact an entire estuary [4892],[4376].  Similarly changes in seabed/estuary profile due to the removal of substrate (capital dredging) or structures (decommissioning) will result in similar changes [3159],[2838].  For example, a large capital dredging in Southampton Water resulted in tidal regime changes causing in a reduction of a few millimetres around Southampton Water [4891].  The magnitude and effect will be related to the size, type, and shape of the structure/excavation, the magnitude of change to the seabed/estuary profile compared to the overall size of the system/estuary [3159],[3153],[3161],[3106],[3082],[4892],[4893],[3145],[5075].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Construction of new ports and harbour infrastructure and associated activities including capital dredging, land reclaim, piling, can result in localised changes to wave exposure.  Structures used in coastal port and marina development such as breakwaters and marina walls can cause sheltering effects on the lee of structures and increased wave reflection effects  [3106],[3154],[3161],[3153].  For example, a proposed breakwater extension project in Cowes, Isle of Wight was predicted to cause up to a 60 % reduction in significant wave height inside the breakwater and an increase in wave reflection from northerly winds outside the breakwater [4892].  Local changes in shore profile and topography associated with the disposal of dredged material for environmental beneficial use, intertidal or beach recharge, and the re-profiling of the shore to enable habitat creation can also result in changes to wave exposure [2838],[1669],[1674],[3085].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Physical loss (to land or freshwater habitat)
column5: Ports and harbour developments through land reclaim, construction of new structures can result in the loss of marine habitat to terrestrial/freshwater habitat; the scale and type of loss is depend on the scale and type of construction project [3096],[3106],[2838],[3153],[3154].  For example, the Cardiff Barrage which was built as part of a dockland redevelopment project in 1999 involved the loss of c. 200 ha of intertidal habitat in Cardiff Bay and conversion to a freshwater lake [4381].  In Southampton Water berth extensions since the 1960s has reclaimed over 80 ha of subtidal and intertidal habitat with individual projects varying in size from several hectares to over 40 ha [4890].  Dredged material (capital and maintenance) has been used for land reclamation, creation of freshwater/terrestrial habitats [2838],[3163],[3153],[4382].  For example, maintenance dredging spoil was used to reclaim over 170 ha of land in Dibden Bay, Southampton Water between 1930 and 1970 [4890].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The materials used for construction or placement activities can alter seabed type, materials used include: timber; iron and steel; concrete; clay, silt, sand, gravel or stone/rock; plastic or other synthetic materials [3161].  Construction and presence of structures in ports and harbours will cause a change in habitat type, typically from soft sediment to a hard substratum type; examples include steel piles used in berths/jetties, concrete and rock used in breakwaters/quays [4892],[4890].  Operation of infrastructure can change seabed due to the continuous disturbance e.g. ongoing use of berths, moorings, anchoring, and navigation channels.  The degree and duration of change will depend on the frequency, magnitude, and location of activity, type of seabed substrate and sensitivity of benthic communities.  Where activities occur over sensitive habitats (e.g. shellfish beds, sea grass, maerl, reefs) and/or areas are heavily used, the opportunity and degree of recovery of habitats can be limited and result in a permanent/long-term change to benthic communities and habitat composition [3145].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The materials used for construction or placement activities can alter seabed type, materials used include: timber; iron and steel; concrete; clay, silt, sand, gravel or stone/rock; plastic or other synthetic materials [3161].  Construction and presence of structures in ports and harbours will cause a change in habitat type, typically from soft sediment to a hard substratum type; examples include steel piles used in berths/jetties, concrete and rock used in breakwaters/quays [4892],[4890].  Construction activities associated with excavation and navigation dredging result in the physical removal of substrate and associated habitats and species resulting in a change in seabed type.  The degree of change will depend on the sensitivity and recoverability of the communities and frequency, duration and magnitude of activity.  Changes in seabed type can also arise from the alteration of the topography, hydrography, and sediment compositions associated resulting from these activities.  Alteration of hydrodynamic conditions as a result of capital dredge (or land reclaim) can change seabed sediment composition and distribution e.g. reduced current flow causing deposition of finer sediment and consequential change in benthic community. Capital dredging can also remove substrate to a depth that the underlying substrate is altered, thus result in a change in habitat and benthic community [2838],[3134],[3145],[3159],[4899],[4379],[4380].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The materials used for construction or placement activities can alter seabed type, materials used include: timber; iron and steel; concrete; clay, silt, sand, gravel or stone/rock; plastic or other synthetic materials [3161].  Construction and presence of structures in ports and harbours will cause a change in habitat type, typically from soft sediment to a hard substratum type; examples include steel piles used in berths/jetties, concrete and rock used in breakwaters/quays [4892],[4890].  Construction activities associated with excavation and navigation dredging result in the physical removal of substrate and associated habitats and species resulting in a change in seabed type.  The degree of change will depend on the sensitivity and recoverability of the communities and frequency, duration and magnitude of activity.  Changes in seabed type can also arise from the alteration of the topography, hydrography, and sediment compositions associated resulting from these activities.  Alteration of hydrodynamic conditions as a result of capital dredge (or land reclaim) can change seabed sediment composition and distribution e.g. reduced current flow causing deposition of finer sediment and consequential change in benthic community. Capital dredging can also remove substrate to a depth that the underlying substrate is altered, thus result in a change in habitat and benthic community [2838],[3134],[3145],[3159],[4899],[4379],[4380].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Ports construction and maintenance works and on-going operations can result in underwater noise, including from vessels, dredging, engineering works.  Underwater noise can result in disturbance particularly to mobile receptors such as fish, bird, mammals [3152],[3164],[3159],[3106],[2074],[3128],[3069],[4995].  Shipping vessels are important source of underwater noise, and is the dominant contributor to ambient noise in shallow water areas close to shipping lanes and in deeper waters [5173],[5172].  Shipping noise is most evident in the 50-300 Hz frequency range, with the majority of noise coming from propeller cavitation, on-board machinery, and turbulence around the hull.  The noise emitted from vessels varies, in general larger vessels generate lower frequency sound.  The source levels associated with large ships (supertankers/container ships) is in the range 180-190 dB re 1µPa-m (RMS).  Small sea going vessels typically produce broadband noise at source levels of 160-180 dB re 1µPa-m (RMS) [3096],[4908].  Measurements of underwater noise from backhoe dredging operations have indicated that the highest levels of underwater noise occur when the excavator is in contact with the seabed.  Dredging produces broadband and continuous sound, mainly at lower frequencies (<1 kHz; source sound pressure levels 160 to more than 190 dB re 1 µPa at 1 m) [4908],[3152].  However it is impulsive/impact sound generated by explosives/piling which causes the most concern of injury and displacement of mobile species from underwater noise [3152],[2074],[3128],[3069].  Impact piling generates high levels of underwater noise, a typical peak to peak source noise pressure levels underwater for tubular piles used in coastal environments range of 220-235 dB re. 1 uPa @ 1 m. Sheet piling noise is generally lower with typical predicted peak to peak source noise level of 212 dB re. 1 uPa @ 1 m (for 600 mm sheet pile) [4908].Engineering works in coastal environments using blasting to remove unwanted hard substrate can to produce source peak noise levels of 257 dB re: 1 µPa (borehole blasting with a charge of 20 kg ) [4916].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The pressure is potentially associated with construction, maintenance, operational lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4339].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The pressure refers to obstructions to species movement caused by physical barrier or prolonged exposure to noise, light, visual disturbance or changes in water quality.  The scale of the impact will depend on scale of activity and the location and will need to be considered on case-by-case basis to determine relevance to given feature/site.  Coastal development can result in barriers to species movement through increase noise (e.g. construction, shipping, acoustic deterrents), lighting, presence of structures, changes to water quality and suspended sediments [2817],[3085],[3096],[3106],[3195],[2763],[3111],[2834],[3152],[3273],[2707],[2825],[1533],[3136],[3145],[3169].  Coastal defences and structures can also result in barrier to species by restricting access to rivers/streams/estuaries or for species to adapt to sea level rise and coastal change [2817],[3096],[3154].  The noise and turbidity arising from dredging operations may pose a barrier to species migration when occurring on or in proximity of specific migratory routes [3152],[3080],[2757],[2838].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The pressure is potentially associated with construction, maintenance, operational lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4399].

column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Pressure associated with vessels and vessel movements associated with this sub-activity, also presence of relevant underwater structures.  Seabirds can be impacted directly by a wide range of artificial light sources within marine environment: seabirds can be attracted to and collide with lighthouses, coastal resorts and other urban lighting, offshore hydrocarbon platforms, commercial fishing vessels and other boats using lights [4378],[4337].  Evidence indicates some bird species are attracted to light sources, which may increase the risk of bird strikes.  Most related studies conclude that increased darkness, coupled with inclement weather, increases attraction by birds to lighted vessels and structures.  Birds drawn to light often become disoriented and can then collide with these vessels/structures resulting in injury and death [4377].  In the case of vessels, it known that nocturnal bird strikes tend to occur when bright, artificial light sources are used at times of poor visibility, typically during bad weather, often angled outwards or upwards from the vessel and when the vessel is relatively close to large breeding aggregations of seabirds (rather than further offshore); however, here are relatively few sources of quantified information relating to seabird strikes on vessels [4378],[4337].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Pressure associated with vessels and vessel movements associated with this sub-activity, also presence of relevant underwater structures.  Vessels are documented to have collided with mobile marine species (particularly marine mammals).  Almost all vessel sizes and classes have been involved in collisions with marine mammals, including cargo ships, ferries (particularly the newer models of high-speed ferry), cruise liners, navy ships, recreational vessels, and research vessels.  Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull.  The most lethal and serious injuries are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots [5120].  Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long.  Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120],[4987].  A lack of information exists regarding collision risk of animals (e.g. birds, fish, marine mammals) with underwater structures, especially for birds.  The response of birds will depend on their detection of a device and any associated structures.  The risk of collision may be increased if the devices alter the characteristics of the current, especially if such changes create new foraging opportunities, since this may impact on the manoeuvrability and underwater swimming agility of birds [4959],[5075].  Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Noise can arise from many activities in the marine environment, the use of machinery, vessels, equipment, explosives, and people will generate airborne (above water) noise.  Port construction, maintenance, and operation activities generate airborne noise and can increase noise above background/ambient noise levels; this can result in disturbance particularly to mobile receptors such as fish, bird, mammals [2817],[3085],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3164],[3082],[2763].  Examples of noise sources vessels, construction plant/operations, piling, operational use of machinery [2817],[1533],[3136],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3169],[3145].  However, the magnitude of pressure would depend on the scale, intensity, and duration of the activity, and relative increase in noise above the natural ambient background noise levels and the type of noise generated [3136],[3078],[3195],[1536].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5:
The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Moreover, antifouling compounds like TBT and copper wash from ship coatings with larger concentrations in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3096],[3106],[3107],[3164],[3155],[4985].

Activities can also result in the re-mobilisation of contaminants/substances (e.g. from sediments) during construction/maintenance/operational activities.  The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of existing contamination and intensity of activity.  High levels of contaminants do occur in fine sediments of some industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated areas/sediments is rare in the England [4899],[3145],[2838],[3159].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs).  Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999.  This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur.  Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year.  Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers) [3096],[3106],[3164],[4968],[4972],[4985].  Organic based contaminants such as PAHs can be effectively ‘locked into’ the seabed sediments in ports and harbours.  These stable compounds do not decompose readily; subsequent re-mobilisation (e.g. by dredging) can release these contaminants into the water column.  The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of sediment contamination and level of re-mobilisation of the sediment.  The highest levels of contaminants generally occur in fine sediment in industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated sediments is rare in the England [2838],[3159],[3163],[4899],[3145].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Synthetic compound contamination (incl. pesticides, antifoulants, pharmaceuticals).  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Synthetic compounds used in a variety of substances for commercial applications are carried by shipping tankers and cargo ships.  These can be spilled into the sea through loss of cargo, collision, grounding, mechanical failure, and deliberate dumping.  Many of these compounds are considered toxic or hazardous.  Accidental spillages around the UK are generally rare.  Chemicals can also be released into the sea through ships ‘flushing’, or washing, their tanks and clearing ballast water [3096],[3106],[3107],[3164],[3157],[4968],[4972].  For example it is currently legal to discharge Polyisobutene (PIB) from ships into the marine environment under certain conditions; PIB is a man-made synthetic product used in the manufacture of sealants, adhesive tape and chewing gum.  PIB is a hydrophobic substance though, so on contact with water it coalesces into a waxy, glue-like formation, generally floating at or just underneath the surface.  As such it is extremely hazardous to a range of seabird species, which dive to find food [4975].  Synthetic compounds e.g. polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) can be effectively ‘locked into’ the seabed sediments in ports and harbours.  These stable compounds do not decompose readily.  Subsequent re-mobilisation of the sediments (e.g. by dredging) can release these contaminants into the water column. The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of sediment contamination and level of re-mobilisation of the sediment.  The highest levels of contaminants generally occur in fine sediment in industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated sediments is rare in the England [2838],[3159],[4899],[3145].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Introduction of other substances (solid, liquid or gas)
column5:
Ports and Harbour activity can result in the accidental, operational, incidental release of substances (e.g. via vessels/vehicles from ballast water, antifoulants, hull contamination, waste products, litter), much of which is restricted/regulated [3106],[3107],[3164],[3157],[3160],[3159].

Activities can also result in the re-mobilisation of contaminants/substances (e.g. from sediments) during construction/maintenance/operational activities.  The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of existing contamination and intensity of activity.  High levels of contaminants do occur in fine sediments of some industrialised estuaries. However, the occurrence of very contaminated areas/sediments is rare in the England [4899],[3145],[2838].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The pressure is associated with sediment mobilisation and increased of suspended sediments as well as the deposition of organic matter.  The pressure can result from a variety of ports and harbour activities including dredging, dredge disposal including alternative disposal and beneficial use of sediments , mobilisation of sediment due to vessel movements and construction activities [2834],[3096],[3153],[3161],[3163],[3106],[3159].  The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the dynamic nature and physical characteristics of the area, sediment type, temperature; making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891].  For example the release of organic rich sediments during dredging or disposal can result in the localised removal of oxygen from the surrounding water [3159],[2834],[3163],[4899].  Dredging activities in areas with an existing problem with dissolved oxygen, or extensive dredging of sediments with a high chemical oxygen demand, could affect dissolved oxygen.  However, in practice, monitoring data suggests that such effects are unlikely in most cases [4902].  Following the placement of dredged material at a disposal site, there is the potential for some localised reduction in dissolved oxygen concentrations in the water column.  Given the dynamic nature of many disposal sites, the water column is likely to be rapidly re-oxygenated, making any changes localised and very short-lived [3163],[2834],[4891].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Ports and harbour (from construction, maintenance or operational ) activities including vessel, vehicle movement, plus people presence and movement can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as fish, marine mammals, seabirds and coastal birds [2497],[2763],[3134],[3154],[3106].  The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity, plus other factors such as species present and age, weather conditions, degree of habituation to disturbance source [5106],[5117],[4977].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur [3164],[3132],[3070].  All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177].  Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water, these include bacteria and other microbes, small invertebrates, eggs, cysts and larvae of various species.  It is estimated that 4,500 different species are carried around the world at any one time in ballast tanks.  During the last three decades, a significant number of introduced, non-indigenous species have been transported through ships’ ballast tanks [5023],[3164].  Artificial structures in the marine environment e.g. breakwaters and jetties, have the potential to act as ‘stepping stones’ for the spread of non-native species.  For example, the Australasian barnacle has been found to colonize concrete breakwaters rapidly in the Netherlands [5086].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity - including in relation to the size of the water body, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). More specifically, the risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed for prolonged periods of time in migratory channels for fish species.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Operation
column5: Sluices and other structures can result in an increase in noise level in the system once they are in operation [2187],[3814]
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: A variety of ports and harbour activities can result in penetration/disturbance/abrasion of the seabed; including structures placed (e.g. geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) or driven (e.g. piles) into the seabed [3106],[2838],[3159],[3161],[3145],[4912],[4903],[4913],[3223].  Piles used in coastal developments can be driven to depths of over -30m Chart Datum, tubular piles are typically 1-2 m diameter, sheet piles typically 0.5-1m wide and 0.1-0.2m thick [4896],[4898],[4890].  Vessel movements can cause localised scour of the seabed, in shallow water, berth pockets, and navigation channels [5174],[3145].  Anchors can penetrate and disturb the seabed on deployment/recovery and due to dragging of the anchor and anchor chain.  The anchors of large vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed up to 1m [4971], while small vessel anchors have been found to cause surface ‘scars’ of typically 1-4m2 [5175]; and scouring of 6m radius has been recorded on intertidal mudflats caused by anchor chains [5179],[4981].  Mooring chains from swinging moorings can also scour/disturb the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide [3223].  Navigation dredging and excavation activities result in the penetration of the seabed due to the physical removal of substrate [3082],[2838],[3159]; the depth of penetration during capital dredging can be several metres.  For example, in Southampton it was necessary to deepen the existing berths by 4-6m as part of a berth extension project [4890].  The depth of material removed during maintenance dredging varies greatly, generally between 0.5m and 2m of sediment is removed [4897],[4904].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The movement of ships through water can result in the pressure both through the generation of waves and propeller-induced turbidity in the water column.  The suspension of sediments from the bottom and margins of navigation channels can occur as a result of vessel movements.  Vessel movements can also result in erosion at channel margins.  The amount of sediment mobilised will depend on the speed, size, and position of the vessel, plus the water depth and sediment characteristics.  In general shipping and boating activity represents a minor localised source of suspended sediments [3145],[3106],[3107].  The dragging of anchors and scouring caused by moorings can cause localised and temporary increases in suspended sediments and siltation [3223].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The movement of ships through water can result in the pressure both through the generation of waves and propeller-induced turbidity in the water column and subsequent siltation.  The suspension of sediments from the bottom and margins of navigation channels can occur as a result of vessel movements.  Vessel movements can also result in erosion at channel margins.  The amount of sediment mobilised and subsequently re-deposited will depend on the speed, size, and position of the vessel, plus the water depth and sediment characteristics.  In general shipping and boating activity represents a minor localised source of suspended sediments and siltation [3145],[3106],[3107].  The dragging of anchors and scouring caused by moorings can cause localised and temporary increases in suspended sediments and siltation [3223].

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: A variety of ports and harbour activities can result in abrasion/disturbance of the seabed; including structures placed (e.g. geotextile bags or rocks used in breakwaters) or driven (e.g. piles) into the seabed [3106],[2838],[3159],[3161],[3145],[4912],[4903],[4913],[3223].  Piles used in coastal developments can be driven to depths of over -30m Chart Datum, tubular piles are typically 1-2 m diameter, sheet piles typically 0.5-1m wide and 0.1-0.2m thick [4896],[4898],[4890].  Vessel movements can cause localised scour of the seabed, in shallow locations, berth pockets, in navigation channels [5174],[3145].  Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying/recovery plus abrasion caused by anchor dragging and the anchor chain.  The anchors of large vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed up to 1m, depth of penetration by smaller inshore vessel anchors is expected to be less [4971].  Small vessel anchors have been found to cause surface ‘scars’ of typically 1-4m2 [5175]; while scouring of 6m radius has been recorded on intertidal mudflats caused by anchor chains [5179],[4981].  Mooring chains from swinging moorings can also scour the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide [3223].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Structures or material placed in the marine environment associated with ports and harbours (including solid and piled structures) will change the form/profile of an area of seabed or an estuary.  This results in localised changes flow rates and tidal regime, intercepting flows causing changes in speed and direction to flow round, past, or across new structures e.g. coastal developments, ports and harbour structures, jetties, breakwaters, land reclaim, dredge disposal, habitat creation.  The magnitude and effect will be related to the size, type, and shape of the structure/placement of material, the magnitude of change to the seabed/estuary profile compared to the overall size of the system/estuary [2817],[3079],[3154],[3159],[3153],[3161],[3106],[3082],[4892],[4893],[3145],[5075],[4873].  For example a large reclaim or structure at the mouth of an estuary could result in  changes which impact an entire estuary and the surrounding marine environment, whereas a new small structure within an estuary is likely to result in more limited localised changes [4892],[3079],[4376].  Similarly changing seabed/estuary profile due to the removal of substrate (capital dredging) or structures (decommissioning) will result in similar changes, causing localised changes to the hydrodynamic flow in an area.  The magnitude and type of effect relates to the overall size of the excavation/removal compared to the overall size of the system/estuary, these changes are then sustained by maintenance dredging [3145],[4899],[2838],[3082],[3134].  For example, flow speed changes of just over 0.1 m/s were predicted for a large capital dredging in Southampton Water [4891].

column3: Piling: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes
column5: Construction involving piling may result in the permanent excavation and or smothering of habitat by man made structures [3161],[4890]. Flat, reflective structures can also induce bed scour by reflecting waves.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column5: The materials used for construction or placement activities can alter seabed type, materials used include: timber; iron and steel; concrete; clay, silt, sand, gravel or stone/rock; plastic or other synthetic materials [3161].  Construction and presence of structures in ports and harbours will cause a change in habitat type, typically from soft sediment to a hard substratum type; examples include steel piles used in berths/jetties, concrete and rock used in breakwaters/quays [4892],[4890].  Operation of infrastructure can change seabed due to the continuous disturbance e.g. ongoing use of berths, moorings, anchoring, and navigation channels.  The degree and duration of change will depend on the frequency, magnitude, and location of activity, type of seabed substrate and sensitivity of benthic communities.  Where activities occur over sensitive habitats (e.g. shellfish beds, sea grass, maerl, reefs) and/or areas are heavily used, the opportunity and degree of recovery of habitats can be limited and result in a permanent/long-term change to benthic communities and habitat composition [3145].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Marine litter is items made or used by people and deliberately discarded or unintentionally lost into the sea and on beaches; including those transported into the marine environment from land by rivers, draining or sewage systems or winds.  Marine litter consists of: plastics, wood, metals, glass, rubber, clothing, paper etc.  Litter derived from shipping vessels including pallets, strapping bans, cargo/containers lost at sea, is a minor component of marine litter, contributing 2% of the litter found on UK beaches.  Ports and harbours generate litter from a number of sources including operational and domestic waste from vessels, waste from cargo activities, waste from maintenance activities and marine industry activities, plus domestic (office) waste.  The latter is not unique to ports/harbours, but the however the other sources if not properly managed have the potential to impacts on the environment.  Environmental legislation and international conventions, regulate ports and harbour waste, including EU Port Waste Directive 2001, Merchant shipping (Port Waste Reception Facilities) Regulations 2003, International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL 73/78).  In general ports and harbours manage waste effectively and have Port Waste Master plans and initiatives to increased awareness among port and harbour staff and users of the problems associated with waste [3096],[3160],[3145],[4974],[4368].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Ports construction and maintenance works and on-going operations can result in underwater noise, including from vessels, dredging, engineering works.  Underwater noise can result in disturbance particularly to mobile receptors such as fish, bird, mammals [3152],[3164],[3159],[3106],[2074],[3128],[3069],[4995].  Shipping vessels are important source of underwater noise, and is the dominant contributor to ambient noise in shallow water areas close to shipping lanes and in deeper waters [5173],[5172].  Shipping noise is most evident in the 50-300 Hz frequency range, with the majority of noise coming from propeller cavitation, on-board machinery, and turbulence around the hull.  The noise emitted from vessels varies, in general larger vessels generate lower frequency sound.  The source levels associated with large ships (super tankers/container ships) is in the range 180-190 dB re 1µPa-m (RMS).  Small sea going vessels typically produce broadband noise at source levels of 160-180 dB re 1µPa-m (RMS) [3096],[4908].  Measurements of underwater noise from backhoe dredging operations have indicated that the highest levels of underwater noise occur when the excavator is in contact with the seabed.  Dredging produces broadband and continuous sound, mainly at lower frequencies (<1 kHz; source sound pressure levels 160 to more than 190 dB re 1 µPa at 1 m) [4908],[3152].  However it is impulsive/impact sound generated by explosives/piling which causes the most concern of injury and displacement of mobile species from underwater noise [3152],[2074],[3128],[3069].  Impact piling generates high levels of underwater noise, a typical peak to peak source noise pressure levels underwater for tubular piles used in coastal environments range of 220-235 dB re. 1 uPa @ 1 m. Sheet piling noise is generally lower with typical predicted peak to peak source noise level of 212 dB re. 1 uPa @ 1 m (for 600mm sheet pile) [4908].Engineering works in coastal environments using blasting to remove unwanted hard substrate can to produce source peak noise levels of 257 dB re: 1 µPa (borehole blasting with a charge of 20kg ) [4916].

column5: The pressure is potentially associated with construction, maintenance, operational lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4399].

column5: The pressure refers to obstructions to species movement caused by physical barrier or prolonged exposure to noise, light, visual disturbance or changes in water quality.  The scale of the impact will depend on scale of activity and the location and will need to be considered on case-by-case basis to determine relevance to given feature/site.  Coastal development can result in barriers to species movement through increase noise (e.g. construction, shipping, acoustic deterrents), lighting, presence of structures, changes to water quality and suspended sediments [2817],[3085],[3096],[3106],[3195],[2763],[3111],[2834],[3152],[3273],[2707],[2825],[1533],[3136],[3145],[3169].  Coastal defences and structures can also result in barrier to species by restricting access to rivers/streams/estuaries or for species to adapt to sea level rise and coastal change [2817],[3096],[3154].  The noise and turbidity arising from dredging operations may pose a barrier to species migration when occurring on or in proximity of specific migratory routes [3152],[3080],[2757],[2838].

column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Pressure associated with vessels and vessel movements associated with this sub-activity, also presence of relevant underwater structures.  Seabirds can be impacted directly by a wide range of artificial light sources within marine environment: seabirds can be attracted to and collide with lighthouses, coastal resorts and other urban lighting, offshore hydrocarbon platforms, commercial fishing vessels and other boats using lights [4378],[4337].  Evidence indicates some bird species are attracted to light sources, which may increase the risk of bird strikes.  Most related studies conclude that increased darkness, coupled with inclement weather, increases attraction by birds to lighted vessels and structures.  Birds drawn to light often become disoriented and can then collide with these vessels/structures resulting in injury and death [4377].  In the case of vessels, it known that nocturnal bird strikes tend to occur when bright, artificial light sources are used at times of poor visibility, typically during bad weather, often angled outwards or upwards from the vessel and when the vessel is relatively close to large breeding aggregations of seabirds (rather than further offshore); however, here are relatively few sources of quantified information relating to seabird strikes on vessels [4378],[4337].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Pressure associated with vessels and vessel movements associated with this sub-activity, also presence of relevant underwater structures.  Vessels are documented to have collided with mobile marine species (particularly marine mammals).  Almost all vessel sizes and classes have been involved in collisions with marine mammals, including cargo ships, ferries (particularly the newer models of high-speed ferry), cruise liners, navy ships, recreational vessels, and research vessels.  Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull.  The most lethal and serious injuries are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots [5120].  Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45m long.  Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120],[4987].  A lack of information exists regarding collision risk of animals (e.g. birds, fish, marine mammals) with underwater structures, especially for birds.  The response of birds will depend on their detection of a device and any associated structures.  The risk of collision may be increased if the devices alter the characteristics of the current, especially if such changes create new foraging opportunities, since this may impact on the manoeuvrability and underwater swimming agility of birds [4959],[5075].  Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].

column5: Noise can arise from many activities in the marine environment, the use of machinery, vessels, equipment, explosives, and people will generate airborne (above water) noise.  Port construction, maintenance, and operation activities generate airborne noise and can increase noise above background/ambient noise levels; this can result in disturbance particularly to mobile receptors such as fish, bird, mammals [2817],[3085],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3164],[3082],[2763].  Examples of noise sources vessels, construction plant/operations, piling, operational use of machinery [2817],[1533],[3136],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3169],[3145].  However, the magnitude of pressure would depend on the scale, intensity, and duration of the activity, and relative increase in noise above the natural ambient background noise levels and the type of noise generated [3136],[3078],[3195],[1536].
