Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: Reclaim and land take may require structures to be placed on or be buried into the seabed (such as piles or the foundations of concrete seawalls) [4912],[4903],[4913]. Dredging/extraction might also be required, which disturb the seabed and in turn will result in abrasion and sediment disturbance [2838],[4890]. Flat reflective surfaces may also induce bed scour by reflecting waves.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Pressure primarily relates to vessels associated with this sub-activity and their movement, but may also relate to the aquaculture facility itself. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled annually by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that lead to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Antifouling compounds like tributyltin (TBT; banned on vessels under 25 m in the UK since 1987, however) and copper wash from ship coatings enter and persist in the marine environment, with highest concentrations generally found in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3096],[3164],[3155],[2788],[3194],[4985].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text). The risk of introducing new species may also increase with the range of vessel/boat activity – e.g. travelling from locations outside the UK or dredging in areas with known presence of INIS.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Pressure primarily relates to vessels associated with this sub-activity and their movement. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled annually by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that lead to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers) [3096],[3164],[3194],[4985].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text). The risk of introducing new species may also increase with the range of vessel/boat activity – e.g. travelling from locations outside the UK or dredging in areas with known presence of INIS.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Synthetic compound contamination (incl. pesticides, antifoulants, pharmaceuticals).  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Synthetic compounds used in a variety of substances for commercial applications are carried by shipping tankers and cargo ships.  These can be spilled into the sea through loss of cargo, collision, grounding, mechanical failure, and deliberate dumping.  Many of these compounds are considered toxic or hazardous.  Accidental spillages around the UK are generally rare.  Chemicals can also be released into the sea through ships ‘flushing’, or washing, their tanks and clearing ballast water [3096],[3106],[3107],[3164],[3157],[4968],[4972].  For example it is currently legal to discharge Polyisobutene (PIB) from ships into the marine environment under certain conditions; PIB is a man-made synthetic product used in the manufacture of sealants, adhesive tape and chewing gum.  PIB is a hydrophobic substance though, so on contact with water it coalesces into a waxy, glue-like formation, generally floating at or just underneath the surface.  As such it is extremely hazardous to a range of seabird species, which dive to find food [4975].  Synthetic compounds e.g. polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) can be effectively ‘locked into’ the seabed sediments in ports and harbours.  These stable compounds do not decompose readily.  Subsequent re-mobilisation of the sediments (e.g. by dredging) can release these contaminants into the water column. The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of sediment contamination and level of re-mobilisation of the sediment.  The highest levels of contaminants generally occur in fine sediment in industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated sediments is rare in the England [2838],[3159],[4899],[3145].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Introduction of other substances (solid, liquid or gas)
column5:
Ports and Harbour activity can result in the accidental, operational, incidental release of substances (e.g. via vessels/vehicles from ballast water, antifoulants, hull contamination, waste products, litter), much of which is restricted/regulated [3106],[3107],[3164],[3157],[3160],[3159].

Activities can also result in the re-mobilisation of contaminants/substances (e.g. from sediments) during construction/maintenance/operational activities.  The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of existing contamination and intensity of activity.  High levels of contaminants do occur in fine sediments of some industrialised estuaries. However, the occurrence of very contaminated areas/sediments is rare in the England [4899],[3145],[2838].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: There are several sources of organic and nutrient enrichment in the marine environment which can result from ports and harbour activities; including discharges, outflows, sediment mobilisation, and dredge disposal [3145],[3106].  The mobilisation of sediment due to vessel movements, dredging, and disposal (including disposal associated with habitat creation) can increase levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145],[2838].  However, monitoring has shown that elevated nutrient and organic matter levels following most dredging campaigns are localised, temporal and maybe within natural variability [4899].  Disposal of wastes including regulated discharge of wastewater into the marine environment can result in nutrient enrichment [4915],[3185],[2293],[3096].  Excessive nutrient enrichment can lead to a risk of eutrophication, changes in the species composition of communities, algal blooms, development of hypoxic conditions due to decomposition of excess plant biomass, fatalities of fauna due to oxygen deficiencies [4915],[2293].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Structures added to the coastal environment as a result of coastal defence schemes, coastal developments, artificial reefs, etc., can change local flow conditions. In particular, cross shore structures such as groynes and harbour arms can intercept flow paths, causing flows to divert around or across the structures [4892],[4893],[4894],[4873],[5075],[4960],[3125],[4961].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: There are several sources of organic and nutrient enrichment in the marine environment which can result from ports and harbour activities; including discharges, outflows, sediment mobilisation, and dredge disposal [3145],[3106].  The mobilisation of sediment due to vessel movements, dredging, and disposal (including disposal associated with habitat creation) can increase levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145],[2838].  However, monitoring has shown that elevated nutrient and organic matter levels following most dredging campaigns are localised, temporal and maybe within natural variability [4899].  Disposal of wastes including regulated discharge of wastewater into the marine environment can result in nutrient enrichment [4915],[3185],[2293],[3096].  Excessive nutrient enrichment can lead to a risk of eutrophication, changes in the species composition of communities, algal blooms, development of hypoxic conditions due to decomposition of excess plant biomass, fatalities of fauna due to oxygen deficiencies [4915],[2293].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The pressure is associated with sediment mobilisation and increased of suspended sediments as well as the deposition of organic matter.  The pressure can result from a variety of ports and harbour activities including dredging, dredge disposal including alternative disposal and beneficial use of sediments , mobilisation of sediment due to vessel movements and construction activities [2834],[3096],[3153],[3161],[3163],[3106],[3159].  The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the dynamic nature and physical characteristics of the area, sediment type, temperature; making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891].  For example the release of organic rich sediments during dredging or disposal can result in the localised removal of oxygen from the surrounding water [3159],[2834],[3163],[4899].  Dredging activities in areas with an existing problem with dissolved oxygen, or extensive dredging of sediments with a high chemical oxygen demand, could affect dissolved oxygen.  However, in practice, monitoring data suggests that such effects are unlikely in most cases [4902].  Following the placement of dredged material at a disposal site, there is the potential for some localised reduction in dissolved oxygen concentrations in the water column.  Given the dynamic nature of many disposal sites, the water column is likely to be rapidly re-oxygenated, making any changes localised and very short-lived [3163],[2834],[4891].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column5: Vessels, vehicles  and people movement can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as marine mammals and seabirds [5106],[5117]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Vehicles and vessels used in intertidal recharge schemes may transfer terrestrial or aquatic organisms to new locations, where they can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur. Where material used in the reclaim originates from outside of the site, organisms within the substrate may be introduced into the site.  All vessels have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177]. Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity - including in relation to the size of the water body, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). More specifically, the risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed for prolonged periods of time in migratory channels for fish species.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: Installation of infrastructure will lead to penetration and abrasion of the seabed through the placement of the infrastructure itself, associated scour protection and the use of jack up barges and other installation vessels [3184],[3127]. Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying the anchor and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery. Mooring chains from swinging moorings may scour the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide. The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials. For example, for an 11.5 tonne anchor penetration of up to 0.88 m  occurred in soft sediment when the anchor was dropped and dragged 87 m [4971]. There is a tendency for the anchor to penetrate to deep depths in softer sediment as the opening of the anchor flukes prevents deep penetration in harder sediment [5076]. Typical maximum water depths for anchoring are between 100 m and 150 m.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column5: The pressure will occur when activities are associated with input of additional sediment [3154].  Sediment is deliberately added to a foreshore and near shore environment. This will temporarily increase sediment levels in an area. In some areas the siltation rate will be high and in some areas this will be low. Dredged material is commonly used for coastal protection/beach nourishment/land reclaim projects and their maintenance [4912],[4905]
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

This will temporarily increase sediment levels in an area. In some areas the siltation rate will be high and in some areas this will be low. Dredged material is commonly used for coastal protection/beach nourishment/land reclaim projects and their maintenance [4912],[4905]

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column5: The pressure will occur when activities are associated with input of additional sediment [3154].  Sediment is deliberately added to a foreshore and near shore environment. This will temporarily increase sediment levels in an area. In some areas the siltation rate will be high and in some areas this will be low. Dredged material is commonly used for coastal protection/beach nourishment/land reclaim projects and their maintenance [4912],[4905]

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column5: Structures added to the coastal environment as a result of coastal defence schemes, coastal developments, artificial reefs, etc., can change local flow conditions. In particular, cross shore structures such as groynes and harbour arms can intercept flow paths, causing flows to divert around or across the structures [4892],[4893],[4894],[4873],[5075],[4960],[3125],[4961]. Changes in flow may also alter wave exposure.  Land reclaim can cause wave attenuation to the project frontage, changing wave height in the local area. This includes sheltering effects on the lee of structures and increased wave reflection effects [4893]. Some coastal defence structures are designed specifically for this purpose, resulting in changes to wave height [2817],[3085],[3096],[3138],[3154],[1674]. Changes to shore planform can also increase wave action on adjacent frontages via wave refraction.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column4: Physical loss (to land or freshwater habitat)
column5: Coastal developments can result in the loss of marine habitat through land claim to freshwater or terrestrial habitat. The footprint of any land claim is dependent on the scale of the project. For example, the Cardiff Barrage which was built as part of a dockland redevelopment project in 1999 involved the loss of c. 200 ha of intertidal habitat in Cardiff Bay and conversion to a freshwater lake. In Southampton Water berth extensions since the 1960s has reclaimed over 80 ha of sub tidal and intertidal habitat with individual projects varying in size from several hectares to over 40 ha [4890].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column5: Coastal developments can result in the loss of marine habitat through land claim to create freshwater or terrestrial habitat. The footprint of any land claim is dependent on the scale of the project. For example, the Cardiff Barrage which was built as part of a dockland redevelopment project in 1999 involved the loss of c. 200 ha of intertidal habitat in Cardiff Bay and conversion to a freshwater lake. In Southampton Water berth extensions since the 1960s has reclaimed over 80 ha of sub tidal and intertidal habitat with individual projects varying in size from several hectares to over 40 ha [4890].

column5: Coastal developments can result in the loss of marine habitat through land claim to create freshwater or terrestrial habitat. The footprint of any land claim is dependent on the scale of the project. For example, the Cardiff Barrage which was built as part of a dockland redevelopment project in 1999 involved the loss of c. 200 ha of intertidal habitat in Cardiff Bay and conversion to a freshwater lake. In Southampton Water berth extensions since the 1960s has reclaimed over 80 ha of sub tidal and intertidal habitat with individual projects varying in size from several hectares to over 40 ha [4890].

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column5: If land reclaim involves piling this can create noise that may impact marine mammals and fish spawning and other sensitive life cycle stages. Important parameters are peak pressure, received energy (received sound pressure level), signal duration, spectral type, frequency (range), duty cycle, directionality and signal rise times. Possible effects on marine mammals can be divided into behavioural disturbance (including displacement), masking, and injury either as temporary threshold shift (TTS), permanent threshold shift (PTS) or other injuries such as tissue damage and, in extreme cases, death if the animal very close to pile-driving activities [3125]. However, factors such as pile diameter, water depth, geology and sea bed topography can all influence noise generation and propagation so values are likely to vary from site to site [3125]. Shipping is an important source of underwater noise. Although the majority of this will come from the propeller cavitation, on-board machinery and turbulence around the hull can also result in noise being transmitted underwater. Different part of the vessel and different vessels emit at different frequencies. Generally, lower frequency with increasing size. Low frequency sounds generally travel farther and have the potential of impacting larger areas.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column5: The pressure is potentially associated with construction, maintenance, operational lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4339]. Light can also be introduced from land based machinery including vehicles.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column5: The pressure refers to obstructions to species movement caused by physical barrier or prolonged exposure to noise, light, visual disturbance or changes in water quality. The scale of the impact will depend on scale of activity and the location and will need to be considered on case-by-case basis to determine relevance to given feature/site. Noise arising from  long-lived operations can also alter migration routes of sensitive species [4990]. Coastal development can result in barriers to species movement through increase noise (e.g. construction, shipping, acoustic deterrents), lighting, presence of structures, changes to water quality and suspended sediments [2817],[3085],[3096],[3106],[3195],[2763],[3111],[3149],[2834],[3151]. Coastal defences can also result in barrier to species by restricting access to rivers/streams/estuaries or to species adapted to sea level rise and coastal change [2817],[3096],[3154]. The noise and turbidity arising from dredging operations may pose a barrier to migration when occurring on or in proximity of specific migratory routes [3152],[3080],[2757].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Operation
column5: Presence and operation of schemes/structures may result in areas of scour/erosion or alternatively areas of siltation/accretion of sediment resulting in changes in  sediment dynamics [2817],[3085],[2838],[3115],[3154],[3161]
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Where operation is associated with vehicle and vessel movements, or where scheme operation involves physical movement/presence of structures. For example, it is documented for bird collisions with vessels to occur particularly at night on lighted ships near coastal areas. These are more frequent also under poor visibility [4337]. Therefore, the pressure will be relevant if operations are planned in SPAs where sensitive species could be present and at sensitive times of the year.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column5: Noise arises from many activities in the marine environment which can evoke a disturbance response in marine mammals and birds [2825],[3269],[3227],[2074]. In relation to managed realignment the operation of vessels and vehicles used in coastal developments and flood defences [2817],[3085],[2838],[3136],[3153],[3154],[3132], as well as presence of people, may result in an increase in above water noise. However, the magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity. Further, the impact of such disturbance on birds [3202] may be considered better captured by the pressure 'visual disturbance'.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Pressure primarily relates to vessels associated with this sub-activity and their movement, but potentially also mobilisation of contaminated sediments. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled annually by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that lead to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Antifouling compounds like tributyltin (TBT; banned on vessels under 25 m in the UK since 1987, however) and copper wash from ship coatings enter and persist in the marine environment, with highest concentrations generally found in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3096],[3164],[3155],[2788],[3194],[4985].  Further, sediment disturbance by activities could result in the remobilisation of contaminants/substances [4481]. However, the likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon factors such as the type and degree of existing contamination, the sediment type and intensity of activity. In many cases, natural disturbance may contribute the majority of contaminated sediment resuspension [4482].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Pressure primarily relates to vessels associated with this sub-activity and their movement. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled annually by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that lead to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers) [3096],[3164],[3194],[4985].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column4: Synthetic compound contamination (incl. pesticides, antifoulants, pharmaceuticals).  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Pressure primarily relates to vessels associated with this sub-activity and their movement, but potentially also mobilisation of contaminated sediments. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled annually by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that lead to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Antifouling compounds like tributyltin (TBT; banned on vessels under 25 m in the UK since 1987, however) and copper wash from ship coatings enter and persist in the marine environment, with highest concentrations generally found in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3096],[3164],[3155],[2788],[3194],[4985].  Further, sediment disturbance by fishing activities could result in the remobilisation of contaminants/substances [4481]. However, the likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon factors such as the type and degree of existing contamination, the sediment type and intensity of activity. In many cases, natural disturbance may contribute the majority of contaminated sediment resuspension [4482].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column4: Introduction of other substances (solid, liquid or gas)
column5: Some of the main pressures on the marine environment include operational and accidental discharges of chemicals, crude oil and produced water containing substances such as oil components, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, alkyl phenols and heavy metals [4941].

column3: Reclaim and land take (e.g. the footprint of coastal defences)
column5: There are several sources of organic and nutrient enrichment in the marine environment: outflows of domestic/industrial origin, sludge, sediment resuspension, aquaculture food and faeces, and others. Sediment mobilisation during dredging can increase the levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145],[5121]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899].  The extent of impacts is determined from the quantity and quality of the input and environmental conditions at the location [4939]. However, magnitude of pressure would depend on intensity/scale of activity and hydrographic conditions [2834],[3276],[3198],[4939]. Disposal of waste material into the marine environment includes the regulated discharge of wastewater and the disposal of hazardous and non-hazardous waste [4915].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Operation
column5: Vessels, vehicles and people movement can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as marine mammals and seabirds [5106],[5117]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Operation
column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5:
Presence and operation of schemes/structures may result in areas of scour/erosion or alternatively areas of siltation/accretion of sediment.  Causing disturbance, changes to seabed or siltation [2817],[3085],[2838],[3115],[2004],[3154],[3161].
Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying the anchor and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery. Anchors may penetrate to deep depths in softer sediment as the opening of the anchor flukes prevents deep penetration in harder sediment [5076].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Operation
column5: The pressure is potentially associated with construction, maintenance, operational lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4399].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Operation
column5: The pressure refers to obstructions to species movement caused by physical barrier or prolonged exposure to noise, light, visual disturbance or changes in water quality. The scale of the impact will depend on scale of activity and the location and will need to be considered on case-by-case basis to determine relevance to given feature/site. Coastal defences can also result in a barrier to species by restricting access to rivers/streams/estuaries or to species adapted to sea level rise and coastal change [2817],[3096],[3154]. The noise and turbidity arising from dredging operations may pose a barrier to migration when occurring on or in proximity of specific migratory routes [3152],[3080],[2757]. Coastal development can result in barriers to species movement through increase noise (e.g. construction, shipping, acoustic deterrents), lighting, presence of structures, changes to water quality and suspended sediments [2817],[3085],[3096],[3106],[3195],[2763],[3111],[3149],[2834],[3151].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Operation
column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of a vessel’s hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. However, collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120],[4987].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Operation
column5: Noise can arise from many activities in the marine environment. The use of machinery, vessels, explosives, people will result in an increase of above water noise. Some examples of sources of airborne noise are drilling rigs and support [3111],[3149], vessels used to service aquaculture facilities [2834],[3151],  vessels used in coastal developments and flood defences [2817],[3085],[2838],[3136],[3153],[3154],[3132], military activities, aggregate extraction [3152], cabling operations [3158],[3164], piling [1329],[3082], etc. However, the magnitude of pressure would depend on the scale, intensity and duration of the activity.

column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: The primary chemicals of environmental concern in oil and fuel incidents are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Moreover, antifouling compounds like TBT and copper wash from coatings with larger concentrations in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3032],[3096],[3107],[3164],[4333],[4985].

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column5: Modification of the seabed morphology can also impact the water flow regime. Structures placed in the marine environment immediately interact with the local current regime. Structures added to the coastal environment as a result of coastal defence schemes, coastal developments, artificial reefs, etc., can change local flow conditions. In particular, cross shore structures such as groynes and harbour arms can intercept flow paths, causing flows to divert around or across the structures [4892],[4893],[4894],[4873],[5075],[4960],[3125],[4961]. Changes in flow conditions may lead to alterations in emergence regimes.

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Operation
column5: The pressure is associated with sediment mobilisation and increased of suspended sediments as well as the deposition of organic matter. The pressure can result from a variety of activities including dredging, aquaculture, outflow, etc [1441],[1436],[2834],[3096],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3163],[3186]. The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the dynamic nature of the area, the temperature and the sediment type, making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column3: Piling: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes
column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: Installation of infrastructure will lead to penetration and abrasion of the seabed through the placement of the infrastructure itself, associated scour protection and the use of jack up barges and other installation vessels [3184],[3127]. Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying the anchor and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery. Mooring chains from swinging moorings may scour the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide. The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials. For example, for an 11.5 tonne anchor penetration of up to 0.88 m  occurred in soft sediment when the anchor was dropped and dragged 87 m [4971]. There is a tendency for the anchor to penetrate to deep depths in softer sediment as the opening of the anchor flukes prevents deep penetration in harder sediment [5076]. Typical maximum water depths for anchoring are between 100 m and 150m.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Construction involving piling may result in the permanent excavation and or smothering of habitat by man made structures [3161],[4890]. Flat, reflective structures can also induce bed scour by reflecting waves.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column4: Physical loss (to land or freshwater habitat)
column5: Ports and harbour developments through land reclaim, construction of new structures can result in the loss of marine habitat to terrestrial/freshwater habitat; the scale and type of loss is depend on the scale and type of construction project [3096],[3106],[2838],[3153],[3154].  For example, the Cardiff Barrage which was built as part of a dockland redevelopment project in 1999 involved the loss of c. 200 ha of intertidal habitat in Cardiff Bay and conversion to a freshwater lake [4381].  In Southampton Water berth extensions since the 1960s has reclaimed over 80 ha of subtidal and intertidal habitat with individual projects varying in size from several hectares to over 40 ha [4890].  Dredged material (capital and maintenance) has been used for land reclamation, creation of freshwater/terrestrial habitats [2838],[3163],[3153],[4382].  For example, maintenance dredging spoil was used to reclaim over 170 ha of land in Dibden Bay, Southampton Water between 1930 and 1970 [4890].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Piling: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes
column4: Physical loss (to land or freshwater habitat)
column5: Habitat change will occur due to placement of structures on the seabed [3122],[3127],[3083],[3125]. The habitat may be changed to steel, concrete, rock or other substances depending on the type of foundation or scour protection. Piles are  driven into the seabed (buried) and can change the seabed type within the footprint of the piling works from soft sediment to an artificial substratum [4898],[4997],[4890],[4892].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Pile driving will cause a highly localised and temporary increase in siltation levels in the direct vicinity of the works due to the deposition of suspended sediments created as a result of seabed disturbance [4892].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Synthetic compound contamination (incl. pesticides, antifoulants, pharmaceuticals).  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Synthetic compounds used in a variety of substances for commercial applications are carried by shipping tankers and cargo ships.  These can be spilled into the sea through loss of cargo, collision, grounding, mechanical failure, and deliberate dumping.  Many of these compounds are considered toxic or hazardous.  Accidental spillages around the UK are generally rare.  Chemicals can also be released into the sea through ships ‘flushing’, or washing, their tanks and clearing ballast water [3096],[3106],[3107],[3164],[3157],[4968],[4972].  For example it is currently legal to discharge Polyisobutene (PIB) from ships into the marine environment under certain conditions; PIB is a man-made synthetic product used in the manufacture of sealants, adhesive tape and chewing gum.  PIB is a hydrophobic substance though, so on contact with water it coalesces into a waxy, glue-like formation, generally floating at or just underneath the surface.  As such it is extremely hazardous to a range of seabird species, which dive to find food [4975].  Synthetic compounds e.g. polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) can be effectively ‘locked into’ the seabed sediments in ports and harbours.  These stable compounds do not decompose readily.  Subsequent re-mobilisation of the sediments (e.g. by dredging) can release these contaminants into the water column. The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of sediment contamination and level of re-mobilisation of the sediment.  The highest levels of contaminants generally occur in fine sediment in industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated sediments is rare in the England [2838],[3159],[4899],[3145].

column3: Piling: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes
column4: Synthetic compound contamination (incl. pesticides, antifoulants, pharmaceuticals).  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Pressure primarily relates to vessels associated with this sub-activity and their movement, but potentially also mobilisation of contaminated sediments. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled annually by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that lead to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Antifouling compounds like tributyltin (TBT; banned on vessels under 25 m in the UK since 1987, however) and copper wash from ship coatings enter and persist in the marine environment, with highest concentrations generally found in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3096],[3164],[3155],[2788],[3194],[4985].  Further, sediment disturbance by fishing activities could result in the remobilisation of contaminants/substances [4481]. However, the likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon factors such as the type and degree of existing contamination, the sediment type and intensity of activity. In many cases, natural disturbance may contribute the majority of contaminated sediment resuspension [4482].

column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5:
The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Moreover, antifouling compounds like TBT and copper wash from ship coatings with larger concentrations in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3096],[3106],[3107],[3164],[3155],[4985].

Activities can also result in the re-mobilisation of contaminants/substances (e.g. from sediments) during construction/maintenance/operational activities.  The likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon the type and degree of existing contamination and intensity of activity.  High levels of contaminants do occur in fine sediments of some industrialised estuaries.  However, the occurrence of very contaminated areas/sediments is rare in the England [4899],[3145],[2838],[3159].

Further, sediment disturbance by activities could result in the remobilisation of contaminants/substances [4481]. column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column4: Physical loss (to land or freshwater habitat)
column5: Habitat change will occur due to placement of structures on the seabed [3122],[3127],[3083],[3125]. The habitat may be changed to steel, concrete, rock or other substances depending on the type of foundation or scour protection. Piles are  driven into the seabed (buried) and can change the seabed type within the footprint of the piling works from soft sediment to an artificial substratum [4898],[4997],[4890],[4892].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column5: Construction of structures may result in areas of scour/erosion or alternatively areas of siltation/accretion of sediment, causing disturbance, changes to seabed or siltation [2817],[3085],[2838],[3115],[3154],[3161]
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column5: Construction of structures may result in areas of scour/erosion or alternatively areas of siltation/accretion of sediment, causing disturbance, changes to seabed or siltation [2817],[3085],[2838],[3115],[3154],[3161]
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Ports construction and maintenance works and on-going operations can result in underwater noise, including from vessels, dredging, engineering works.  Underwater noise can result in disturbance particularly to mobile receptors such as fish, bird, mammals [3152],[3164],[3159],[3106],[2074],[3128],[3069],[4995].  Shipping vessels are important source of underwater noise, and is the dominant contributor to ambient noise in shallow water areas close to shipping lanes and in deeper waters [5173],[5172].  Shipping noise is most evident in the 50-300 Hz frequency range, with the majority of noise coming from propeller cavitation, on-board machinery, and turbulence around the hull.  The noise emitted from vessels varies, in general larger vessels generate lower frequency sound.  The source levels associated with large ships (supertankers/container ships) is in the range 180-190 dB re 1µPa-m (RMS).  Small sea going vessels typically produce broadband noise at source levels of 160-180 dB re 1µPa-m (RMS) [3096],[4908].  Measurements of underwater noise from backhoe dredging operations have indicated that the highest levels of underwater noise occur when the excavator is in contact with the seabed.  Dredging produces broadband and continuous sound, mainly at lower frequencies (<1 kHz; source sound pressure levels 160 to more than 190 dB re 1 µPa at 1 m) [4908],[3152].  However it is impulsive/impact sound generated by explosives/piling which causes the most concern of injury and displacement of mobile species from underwater noise [3152],[2074],[3128],[3069].  Impact piling generates high levels of underwater noise, a typical peak to peak source noise pressure levels underwater for tubular piles used in coastal environments range of 220-235 dB re. 1 uPa @ 1 m. Sheet piling noise is generally lower with typical predicted peak to peak source noise level of 212 dB re. 1 uPa @ 1 m (for 600mm sheet pile) [4908].Engineering works in coastal environments using blasting to remove unwanted hard substrate can to produce source peak noise levels of 257 dB re: 1 µPa (borehole blasting with a charge of 20kg ) [4916].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Piling: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes
column5: Piling can create noise that may impact marine mammals and fish spawning and other sensitive life cycle stages. Important parameters are peak pressure, received energy (received sound pressure level), signal duration, spectral type, frequency (range), duty cycle, directionality and signal rise times. Possible effects on marine mammals can be divided into behavioural disturbance (including displacement), masking, and injury either as temporary threshold shift (TTS), permanent threshold shift (PTS) or other injuries such as tissue damage and, in extreme cases, death if the animal very close to pile-driving activities [3125]. However, factors such as pile diameter, water depth, geology and sea bed topography can all influence noise generation and propagation so values are likely to vary from site to site [3125]. Shipping is an important source of underwater noise. Although the majority of this will come from the propeller cavitation, on-board machinery and turbulence around the hull can also result in noise being transmitted underwater. Different part of the vessel and different vessels emit at different frequencies. Generally, lower frequency with increasing size. Low frequency sounds generally travel farther and have the potential of impacting larger areas.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The pressure relates to the vibration produced by certain activities and does not include vessels as it assumed not to be significant.  Ports and harbour activities which can result in vibration include dredging, piling and other construction works [3078],[3128],[3154],[4367],[4366].  Note most vibration transmitted into the water column will radiate as underwater noise, most vibration is transmitted through the ground/seabed [4366].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Piling: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes
column5: The pressure relates to the vibration produced by certain activities and does not include vessels as they are assumed not to be significant. Activities resulting in vibration involve piling (especially if vibro-piling is used) [3078],[3128],[3154].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Ports and harbour (from construction, maintenance or operational ) activities including vessel, vehicle movement, plus people presence and movement can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as fish, marine mammals, seabirds and coastal birds [2497],[2763],[3134],[3154],[3106].  The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity, plus other factors such as species present and age, weather conditions, degree of habituation to disturbance source [5106],[5117],[4977].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Piling: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes
column5: Vessels, vehicles  and people movement can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as marine mammals and seabirds [5106],[5117]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Structures or material placed in the marine environment associated with ports and harbours (including solid and piled structures) will change the form/profile of an area of seabed or an estuary.  This results in localised changes flow rates and tidal regime, intercepting flows causing changes in speed and direction to flow round, past, or across new structures e.g. coastal developments, ports and harbour structures, jetties, breakwaters, land reclaim, dredge disposal, habitat creation.  The magnitude and effect will be related to the size, type, and shape of the structure/placement of material, the magnitude of change to the seabed/estuary profile compared to the overall size of the system/estuary [2817],[3079],[3154],[3159],[3153],[3161],[3106],[3082],[4892],[4893],[3145],[5075],[4873].  For example a large reclaim or structure at the mouth of an estuary could result in  changes which impact an entire estuary and the surrounding marine environment, whereas a new small structure within an estuary is likely to result in more limited localised changes [4892],[3079],[4376].  Similarly changing seabed/estuary profile due to the removal of substrate (capital dredging) or structures (decommissioning) will result in similar changes, causing localised changes to the hydrodynamic flow in an area.  The magnitude and type of effect relates to the overall size of the excavation/removal compared to the overall size of the system/estuary, these changes are then sustained by maintenance dredging [3145],[4899],[2838],[3082],[3134].  For example, flow speed changes of just over 0.1 m/s were predicted for a large capital dredging in Southampton Water [4891].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Piling: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes
column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Structures placed in the marine environment immediately interact with the local current regime. Structures added to the coastal environment as a result of coastal defence schemes, coastal developments, artificial reefs, etc., can change local flow conditions. In particular, cross shore structures such as groynes and harbour arms can intercept flow paths, causing flows to divert around or across the structures [4892],[4893],[4894],[4873],[5075],[4960],[3125],[4961].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Construction of new ports and harbour infrastructure and associated activities including capital dredging, land reclaim, piling, can result in localised changes to wave exposure.  Structures used in coastal port and marina development such as breakwaters and marina walls can cause sheltering effects on the lee of structures and increased wave reflection effects  [3106],[3154],[3161],[3153].  For example, a proposed breakwater extension project in Cowes, Isle of Wight was predicted to cause up to a 60 % reduction in significant wave height inside the breakwater and an increase in wave reflection from northerly winds outside the breakwater [4892].  Local changes in shore profile and topography associated with the disposal of dredged material for environmental beneficial use, intertidal or beach recharge, and the re-profiling of the shore to enable habitat creation can also result in changes to wave exposure [2838],[1669],[1674],[3085].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.

column3: Piling: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes
column5: Piling may effect local wave conditions by causing reflection, refraction and breaking of waves. This could increase or decrease wave energy in nearby areas [3161].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column5: Vessels, vehicles  and people movement can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as marine mammals and seabirds [5106],[5117]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Vehicles and vessels used in developments may transfer terrestrial or aquatic organisms to new locations, where they can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur. Where material used in the development originates from outside of the site, organisms within the substrate may be introduced into the site.  All vessels have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177]. Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity - including in relation to the size of the water body, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). More specifically, the risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed for prolonged periods of time in migratory channels for fish species.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: Installation of infrastructure will lead to penetration and abrasion of the seabed through the placement of the infrastructure itself, associated scour protection and the use of jack up barges and other installation vessels [3184],[3127]. Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying the anchor and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery. Mooring chains from swinging moorings may scour the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide. The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials. For example, for an 11.5 tonne anchor penetration of up to 0.88 m occurred in soft sediment when the anchor was dropped and dragged 87 m [4971]. There is a tendency for the anchor to penetrate to deep depths in softer sediment as the opening of the anchor flukes prevents deep penetration in harder sediment [5076]. Typical maximum water depths for anchoring are between 100 m and 150 m.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column5: Structures placed in the marine environment as a result of coastal defence can be buried into the seabed (such as piles or the foundations of concrete seawalls) [4912],[4903],[4913]. The placement and burial of structures can cause localised and temporary changes in suspended sediments. This is likely to lead to negligible increases in siltation rates in the direct vicinity of the works [4892],[3145],[4890] .
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: Installation of infrastructure will lead to penetration and abrasion of the seabed through the placement of the infrastructure itself, associated scour protection and the use of jack up barges and other installation vessels [3184],[3127]. Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying the anchor and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery. Mooring chains from swinging moorings may scour the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide. The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials. For example, for an 11.5 tonne anchor penetration of up to 0.88 m  occurred in soft sediment when the anchor was dropped and dragged 87 m [4971]. There is a tendency for the anchor to penetrate to deep depths in softer sediment as the opening of the anchor flukes prevents deep penetration in harder sediment [5076]. Typical maximum water depths for anchoring are between 100 m and 150 m.
