column5: During marine dredging and recharge operations, sediment is released into the water column via one of the following: physical disturbance of seabed sediments by the drag head during sediment recovery or through the deposit of the material in the intertidal environment.  This sediment will be dispersed by tide and current and settle by gravity to the seabed.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column5: Piling can create noise that may impact marine mammals and fish spawning and other sensitive life cycle stages. Important parameters are peak pressure, received energy (received sound pressure level), signal duration, spectral type, frequency (range), duty cycle, directionality and signal rise times. Possible effects on marine mammals can be divided into behavioural disturbance (including displacement), masking, and injury either as temporary threshold shift (TTS), permanent threshold shift (PTS) or other injuries such as tissue damage and, in extreme cases, death if the animal very close to pile-driving activities [3125]. However, factors such as pile diameter, water depth, geology and sea bed topography can all influence noise generation and propagation so values are likely to vary from site to site [3125]. Shipping is an important source of underwater noise. Although the majority of this will come from the propeller cavitation, on-board machinery and turbulence around the hull can also result in noise being transmitted underwater. Different part of the vessel and different vessels emit at different frequencies. Generally, lower frequency with increasing size. Low frequency sounds generally travel farther and have the potential of impacting larger areas. The dredging of material will result in underwater noise similar to that generated in other marine operations such the use of sonars, seismic prospecting in the oil and gas industry, acoustic deterrents/harassing devices, turbine operation, piling, explosives, etc. [3804],[4921],[4995],[5173],[5172].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column5: The pressure is potentially associated with construction, maintenance, operational lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4339].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column5: The pressure refers to obstructions to species movement caused by physical barrier or prolonged exposure to noise, light, visual disturbance or changes in water quality. The scale of the impact will depend on scale of activity and the location and will need to be considered on case-by-case basis to determine relevance to given feature/site. Noise arising from  long-lived operations can also alter migration routes of sensitive species [4990]. Coastal development can result in barriers to species movement through increase noise (e.g. construction, shipping, acoustic deterrents), lighting, presence of structures, changes to water quality and suspended sediments [2817],[3085],[3096],[3106],[3195],[2763],[3111],[3149],[2834],[3151]. Coastal defences can also result in barrier to species by restricting access to rivers/streams/estuaries or to species adapted to sea level rise and coastal change [2817],[3096],[3154]. The noise and turbidity arising from dredging operations may pose a barrier to migration when occurring on or in proximity of specific migratory routes [3152],[3080],[2757].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Where operation is associated with vehicle and vessel movements, or where scheme operation involves physical movement/presence of structures. For example, it is documented for bird collisions with vessels to occur particularly at night on lighted ships near coastal areas. These are more frequent also under poor visibility [4337]. Therefore, the pressure will be relevant if operations are planned in SPAs where sensitive species could be present and at sensitive times of the year.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120],[4987]. A lack of information exists regarding collision risk of animals (e.g. birds, fish, marine mammals) with underwater structures, especially for birds. The response of birds will depend on their detection of a device and any associated structures. The risk of collision may be increased if the devices alter the characteristics of the current, especially if such changes create new foraging opportunities, since this may impact on the manoeuvrability and underwater swimming agility of birds [4959],[5075]. Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column5: Noise arises from many activities in the marine environment which can evoke a disturbance response in marine mammals and birds [2825],[3269],[3227],[2074]. In relation to managed realignment the operation of vessels and vehicles used in coastal developments and flood defences [2817],[3085],[2838],[3136],[3153],[3154],[3132], as well as presence of people, may result in an increase in above water noise. However, the magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity. Further, the impact of such disturbance on birds [3202] may be considered better captured by the pressure 'visual disturbance'.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Pressure primarily relates to vessels associated with this sub-activity and their movement. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled annually by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that lead to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers) [3096],[3164],[3194],[4985].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column4: Synthetic compound contamination (incl. pesticides, antifoulants, pharmaceuticals).  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Pressure primarily relates to vessels associated with this sub-activity and their movement, but potentially also mobilisation of contaminated sediments. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled annually by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that lead to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Antifouling compounds like tributyltin (TBT; banned on vessels under 25 m in the UK since 1987, however) and copper wash from ship coatings enter and persist in the marine environment, with highest concentrations generally found in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3096],[3164],[3155],[2788],[3194],[4985].  Further, sediment disturbance by fishing activities could result in the remobilisation of contaminants/substances [4481]. However, the likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon factors such as the type and degree of existing contamination, the sediment type and intensity of activity. In many cases, natural disturbance may contribute the majority of contaminated sediment resuspension [4482].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column4: Introduction of other substances (solid, liquid or gas)
column5: Some of the main pressures on the marine environment include operational and accidental discharges of chemicals, crude oil and produced water containing substances such as oil components, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, alkyl phenols and heavy metals [4941].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Coastal flood and erosion risk management schemes: Construction
column5: There are several sources of organic and nutrient enrichment in the marine environment: outflows of domestic/industrial origin, sludge, sediment resuspension, aquaculture food and faeces, and others. Sediment mobilisation during dredging can increase the levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145],[5121]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899].  The extent of impacts is determined from the quantity and quality of the input and environmental conditions at the location [4939]. However, magnitude of pressure would depend on intensity/scale of activity and hydrographic conditions [2834],[3276],[3198],[4939]. Disposal of waste material into the marine environment includes the regulated discharge of wastewater and the disposal of hazardous and non-hazardous waste [4915].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Vessels, vehicles  and people movement can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as marine mammals and seabirds [5106],[5117]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Vehicles and vessels used in intertidal recharge schemes may transfer terrestrial or aquatic organisms to new locations, where they can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur. Where material used in the recharge originates from outside of the site, organisms within the substrate may be introduced into the site.  All vessels have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177]. Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity - including in relation to the size of the water body, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). More specifically, the risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed for prolonged periods of time in migratory channels for fish species.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Habitat structure changes - removal of substratum (extraction)
column5: Intertidal recharge can remove habitat and could induce changes in habitat structure [3180]. The method of dredging material determines the topographical and bathymetrical changes: Trailer hopper suction dredging creates shallow furrows that may extend for several kilometres in length. The depressions are generally 2-3 m wide and initially only around 0.5 m deep. Static dredging tends to create deep (5-10 m) depressions in the seabed. [3081],[3102]
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5:
Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deployment and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery. Mooring chains from swinging moorings may scour the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide. 
The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials. For example, for an 11.5 tonne anchor penetration of up to 0.88 m  occurred in soft sediment when the anchor was dropped and dragged 87 m [4971]. There is a tendency for the anchor to penetrate to deep depths in softer sediment as the opening of the anchor flukes prevents deep penetration in harder sediment [5076]. Typical maximum water depths for anchoring are between 100 m and 150m aggregate extraction removes the surface layers of sediment from the seabed.  The method of dredging and the material used for intertidal recharge determines the magnitude and depth of the structural damage. Trailer hopper suction dredging creates shallow furrows that may extend for several kilometres in length. The depressions are generally 2-3 m wide and initially only around 0.5 m deep. Static dredging tends to create deep (5-10 m) depressions in the seabed. [3081],[3102],[3080]
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Intertidal recharge increases suspended solids in the water column.  This occurs at the draghead, via the spill ways or by screening.  Plumes generated by the draghead tend to be of small magnitude. The sediment overspilled or screened is dispersed laterally and vertically by waves and tides and forms a turbid plume.  Particles generally settle within 250 - 500 m but can travel up to 5 km where currents are strong [3080],[3102],[4336]
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: Intertidal recharge can alter the structure and composition of the substrate and the dredging associated with it removes the surface layers of sediment from the seabed. The method of dredging determines magnitude and depth of the structural damage. Trailer hopper suction dredging creates shallow furrows that may extend for several kilometres in length. The depressions are generally 2-3 m wide and initially only around 0.5 m deep. Static dredging tends to create deep (5-10 m) depressions in the seabed. On occasion this might result in the damage of seabed features or biologically important structures [3081],[3102],[3080]
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Modification of the seabed morphology can  impact the water flow regime. Dredging and recharge activities can cause localised change to the hydrodynamic flow in an area. The magnitude of the effect will be related to the overall size (depth and area) of the excavation compared to the overall area of the system [4899],[5198].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Emergence regime changes, including tidal level change considerations
column5: Modification of the seabed morphology can  impact the water flow regime. Dredging and recharge activities can cause localised change to the hydrodynamic flow in an area. The magnitude of the effect will be related to the overall size (depth and area) of the excavation compared to the overall area of the system [4899],[5198].

column5: Modification of the seabed morphology can impact the water flow regime. Dredging and recharge activities can cause localised change to the hydrodynamic flow in an area. column5: Removal of material and subsequently depositing it can change both the bathymetry and the physical characteristics of the intertidal seabed.  Extraction can result in the remaining sediment being of a different particle size composition to that prior to extraction [3102],[3080],[2751],[2817],[3085].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Removal of material and subsequently depositing it can change both the bathymetry and the physical characteristics of the intertidal seabed. column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Shipping is an important source of underwater noise. Although the majority of this will come from the propeller cavitation, on-board machinery and turbulence around the hull can also result in noise being transmitted underwater. Different part of the vessel and different vessels emit at different frequencies. Generally, lower frequency with increasing size. Low frequency sounds generally travel farther and have the potential of impacting larger areas. The dredging of material will result in underwater noise similar to that generated in other marine operations such the use of sonars, seismic prospecting in the oil and gas industry, acoustic deterrents/harassing devices, turbine operation, piling, explosives, etc. [3804],[4921],[4995],[5173],[5172].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The pressure is potentially associated with construction, maintenance, operational lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4339].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.

column5: The pressure refers to obstructions to species movement caused by physical barrier or prolonged exposure to noise, light, visual disturbance or changes in water quality. The scale of the impact will depend on scale of activity and the location and will need to be considered on case-by-case basis to determine relevance to given feature/site. Noise arising from  long-lived operations can also alter migration routes of sensitive species [4990]. Coastal development can result in barriers to species movement through increase noise (e.g. construction, shipping, acoustic deterrents), lighting, presence of structures, changes to water quality and suspended sediments [2817],[3085],[3096],[3106],[3195],[2763],[3111],[3149],[2834],[3151]. Coastal defences can also result in barrier to species by restricting access to rivers/streams/estuaries or to species adapted to sea level rise and coastal change [2817],[3096],[3154]. The noise and turbidity arising from dredging operations may pose a barrier to migration when occurring on or in proximity of specific migratory routes [3152],[3080],[2757].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Pressure relates to vessels associated with this sub-activity and their movement. Marine birds are frequently attracted to or become disorientated by artificial light sources, which can result in collision and therefore injury or death [4399],[4378],[2826]. Bird collisions with vessels [2826], have been recorded with the risk being greatest at night for lighted ships near coastal areas and when the vessel is relatively close to large breeding aggregations of seabirds (rather than further offshore). However, there are relatively few sources of quantified information relating to seabird strikes on vessels. Nocturnal bird strikes on vessels tend to occur when bright, artificial light sources are used at times of poor visibility, typically during bad weather, often angled outwards or upwards from the vessel [4466],[4378].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.

However, the likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon factors such as the type and degree of existing contamination, the sediment type and intensity of activity. In many cases, natural disturbance may contribute the majority of contaminated sediment resuspension [4482].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Introduction of other substances (solid, liquid or gas)
column5: Some of the main pressures on the marine environment include operational and accidental discharges of chemicals, crude oil and produced water containing substances such as oil components, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, alkyl phenols and heavy metals [4941].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: There are several sources of organic and nutrient enrichment in the marine environment: outflows of domestic/industrial origin, sludge, sediment resuspension, aquaculture food and faeces, and others. Sediment mobilisation during dredging can increase the levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145],[5121]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899].  The extent of impacts is determined from the quantity and quality of the input and environmental conditions at the location [4939]. However, magnitude of pressure would depend on intensity/scale of activity and hydrographic conditions [2834],[3276],[3198],[4939]. Disposal of waste material into the marine environment includes the regulated discharge of wastewater and the disposal of hazardous and non-hazardous waste [4915].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: All sediments used for intertidal recharge can only be used if considered clean and uncontaminated.  However material used could act as a source of nutrients and organic material.  There are several sources of organic and nutrient enrichment in the marine environment: outflows of domestic/industrial origin, sludge, sediment resuspension, aquaculture food and faeces, and others. Sediment mobilisation during dredging can increase the levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145],[5121]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899],[2817].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column5: The pressure can result from a variety of activities including dredging, aquaculture, outflow, etc. [1441],[1436],[2834],[3096],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3163],[3186]. The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the dynamic nature of the area, the temperature and the sediment type, making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891] - the effect is most pronounced in the warmer summer months.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column3: Offshore coastal defence structures (wave screens/breakwaters): Construction and operation
column5: Vessels, vehicles  and people movement can create visual stimuli which can evoke a disturbance response in mobile species such as marine mammals and seabirds [5106],[5117]. The magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature and scale/intensity of the activity.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Offshore coastal defence structures (wave screens/breakwaters): Construction and operation
column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Vehicles and vessels used in developments may transfer terrestrial or aquatic organisms to new locations, where they can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur. Where material used in the development originates from outside of the site, organisms within the substrate may be introduced into the site.  All vessels have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177]. Thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity - including in relation to the size of the water body, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). More specifically, the risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed for prolonged periods of time in migratory channels for fish species.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Offshore coastal defence structures (wave screens/breakwaters): Construction and operation
column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5: Installation of infrastructure will lead to penetration and abrasion of the seabed through the placement of the infrastructure itself, associated scour protection and the use of jack up barges and other installation vessels [3184],[3127]. Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying the anchor and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery. Mooring chains from swinging moorings may scour the seabed as the mooring slackens and rotates with the tide. The anchors of large shipping and cargo vessels have been found to penetrate the seabed at depths up to approximately 1 m in trials. For example, for an 11.5 tonne anchor penetration of up to 0.88 m occurred in soft sediment when the anchor was dropped and dragged 87 m [4971]. There is a tendency for the anchor to penetrate to deep depths in softer sediment as the opening of the anchor flukes prevents deep penetration in harder sediment [5076]. Typical maximum water depths for anchoring are between 100 m and 150 m.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Offshore coastal defence structures (wave screens/breakwaters): Construction and operation
column5: Structures placed in the marine environment as a result of coastal defence can be buried into the seabed (such as piles or the foundations of concrete seawalls) [4912],[4903],[4913]. The placement and burial of structures can cause localised and temporary changes in suspended sediments. This is likely to lead to negligible increases in siltation rates in the direct vicinity of the works [4892],[3145],[4890] .
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Abrasion/disturbance of the substrate on the surface of the seabed
column5: Installation of infrastructure will lead to penetration and abrasion of the seabed through the placement of the infrastructure itself, associated scour protection and the use of jack up barges and other installation vessels [3184],[3127].Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying the anchor and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery. For example, for an 11.5 tonne anchor penetration of up to 0.88 m occurred in soft sediment when the anchor was dropped and dragged 87 m [4971]. column3: Offshore coastal defence structures (wave screens/breakwaters): Construction and operation
column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: Structures placed in the marine environment immediately interact with the local current regime. Structures added to the coastal environment as a result of coastal defence schemes, coastal developments, artificial reefs, etc., can change local flow conditions. In particular, cross shore structures such as groynes and harbour arms can intercept flow paths, causing flows to divert around or across the structures [4892],[4893],[4894],[4873],[5075],[4960],[3125],[4961].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Offshore coastal defence structures (wave screens/breakwaters): Construction and operation
column4: Emergence regime changes, including tidal level change considerations
column5: Modification of the seabed morphology can also impact the water flow regime. Structures placed in the marine environment immediately interact with the local current regime. Structures added to the coastal environment as a result of coastal defence schemes, coastal developments, artificial reefs, etc., can change local flow conditions. In particular, cross shore structures such as groynes and harbour arms can intercept flow paths, causing flows to divert around or across the structures [4892],[4893],[4894],[4873],[5075],[4960],[3125],[4961]. Changes in flow conditions may lead to alterations in emergence regimes.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Offshore coastal defence structures (wave screens/breakwaters): Construction and operation
column5: Structures placed in the marine environment immediately interact with the local hydrological regime. Structures added to the coastal environment as a result of coastal defence schemes, coastal developments, artificial reefs, etc., can change local flow conditions. In particular, cross shore structures such as groynes and harbour arms can intercept flow paths, causing flows to divert around or across the structures [4892],[4893],[4894],[4873],[5075],[4960],[3125],[4961]. Structures used in coastal defence can cause wave attenuation to the project frontage, changing wave height in the local area. This includes sheltering effects on the lee of structures and increased wave reflection effects [4893].  Some coastal defence structures are designed specifically for this purpose, resulting in changes to wave height and the operation of structures will maintain this change [2817],[3085],[3096],[3138],[3154],[1674].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Offshore coastal defence structures (wave screens/breakwaters): Construction and operation
column4: Physical loss (to land or freshwater habitat)
column5: Where offshore structures abut the coast/make landfall, this may result in the loss of terrestrial habitat. Habitat change will occur due to placement of structures on the seabed [3122],[3127],[3083],[3125]. The habitat may be changed to steel, concrete, rock or other substances depending on the type of foundation or scour protection. Piles are  driven into the seabed (buried) and can change the seabed type within the footprint of the piling works from soft sediment to an artificial substratum [4898],[4997],[4890],[4892].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.

column3: Offshore coastal defence structures (wave screens/breakwaters): Construction and operation
column5: Construction of structures may result in areas of scour/erosion or alternatively areas of siltation/accretion of sediment, causing disturbance, changes to seabed or siltation [2817],[3085],[2838],[3115],[3154],[3161]
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Offshore coastal defence structures (wave screens/breakwaters): Construction and operation
column5: Construction of structures may result in areas of scour/erosion or alternatively areas of siltation/accretion of sediment, causing disturbance, changes to seabed or siltation [2817],[3085],[2838],[3115],[3154],[3161]
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Offshore coastal defence structures (wave screens/breakwaters): Construction and operation
column5: Piling can create noise that may impact marine mammals and fish spawning and other sensitive life cycle stages. Important parameters are peak pressure, received energy (received sound pressure level), signal duration, spectral type, frequency (range), duty cycle, directionality and signal rise times. Possible effects on marine mammals can be divided into behavioural disturbance (including displacement), masking, and injury either as temporary threshold shift (TTS), permanent threshold shift (PTS) or other injuries such as tissue damage and, in extreme cases, death if the animal very close to pile-driving activities [3125]. However, factors such as pile diameter, water depth, geology and sea bed topography can all influence noise generation and propagation so values are likely to vary from site to site [3125]. Shipping is an important source of underwater noise. Although the majority of this will come from the propeller cavitation, on-board machinery and turbulence around the hull can also result in noise being transmitted underwater. Different part of the vessel and different vessels emit at different frequencies. Generally, lower frequency with increasing size. Low frequency sounds generally travel farther and have the potential of impacting larger areas. The dredging of material will result in underwater noise similar to that generated in other marine operations such the use of sonars, seismic prospecting in the oil and gas industry, acoustic deterrents/harassing devices, turbine operation, piling, explosives, etc. [3804],[4921],[4995],[5173],[5172].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Offshore coastal defence structures (wave screens/breakwaters): Construction and operation
column5: The pressure is potentially associated with construction, maintenance, operational lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4339].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Offshore coastal defence structures (wave screens/breakwaters): Construction and operation
column5: The pressure refers to obstructions to species movement caused by physical barrier or prolonged exposure to noise, light, visual disturbance or changes in water quality. The scale of the impact will depend on scale of activity and the location and will need to be considered on case-by-case basis to determine relevance to given feature/site. Noise arising from  long-lived operations can also alter migration routes of sensitive species [4990]. Coastal development can result in barriers to species movement through increase noise (e.g. construction, shipping, acoustic deterrents), lighting, presence of structures, changes to water quality and suspended sediments [2817],[3085],[3096],[3106],[3195],[2763],[3111],[3149],[2834],[3151]. Coastal defences can also result in barrier to species by restricting access to rivers/streams/estuaries or to species adapted to sea level rise and coastal change [2817],[3096],[3154]. The noise and turbidity arising from dredging operations may pose a barrier to migration when occurring on or in proximity of specific migratory routes [3152],[3080],[2757].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Offshore coastal defence structures (wave screens/breakwaters): Construction and operation
column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Where operation is associated with vehicle and vessel movements, or where scheme operation involves physical movement/presence of structures. For example, it is documented for bird collisions with vessels to occur particularly at night on lighted ships near coastal areas. These are more frequent also under poor visibility [4337]. Therefore, the pressure will be relevant if operations are planned in SPAs where sensitive species could be present and at sensitive times of the year.
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Offshore coastal defence structures (wave screens/breakwaters): Construction and operation
column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120],[4987]. A lack of information exists regarding collision risk of animals (e.g. birds, fish, marine mammals) with underwater structures, especially for birds. The response of birds will depend on their detection of a device and any associated structures. The risk of collision may be increased if the devices alter the characteristics of the current, especially if such changes create new foraging opportunities, since this may impact on the manoeuvrability and underwater swimming agility of birds [4959],[5075]. Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Offshore coastal defence structures (wave screens/breakwaters): Construction and operation
column5: Noise arises from many activities in the marine environment which can evoke a disturbance response in marine mammals and birds [2825],[3269],[3227],[2074]. In relation to managed realignment the operation of vessels and vehicles used in coastal developments and flood defences [2817],[3085],[2838],[3136],[3153],[3154],[3132], as well as presence of people, may result in an increase in above water noise. However, the magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity. Further, the impact of such disturbance on birds [3202] may be considered better captured by the pressure 'visual disturbance'.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column3: Offshore coastal defence structures (wave screens/breakwaters): Construction and operation
column5: The pressure relates to the vibration produced by certain activities and does not include vessels as they are assumed not to be significant. Activities resulting in vibration are for example dredging as the draghead is carried over the seabed or grab is operated [3804]; developments involving explosives [3144] and activities involving piling (especially if vibro-piling is used) [3078],[3128],[3154].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column3: Offshore coastal defence structures (wave screens/breakwaters): Construction and operation
column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Pressure primarily relates to vessels associated with this sub-activity and their movement, but potentially also mobilisation of contaminated sediments. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled annually by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that lead to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Antifouling compounds like tributyltin (TBT; banned on vessels under 25 m in the UK since 1987, however) and copper wash from ship coatings enter and persist in the marine environment, with highest concentrations generally found in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3096],[3164],[3155],[2788],[3194],[4985].  Further, sediment disturbance by activities could result in the remobilisation of contaminants/substances [4481]. However, the likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon factors such as the type and degree of existing contamination, the sediment type and intensity of activity. In many cases, natural disturbance may contribute the majority of contaminated sediment resuspension [4482].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Water flow (tidal current) changes, including sediment transport considerations
column5: The removal of structures such as hard or soft coastal defences to allow salt water inundation will alter current patterns and wave exposure because structures added to the coastal environment as a result of coastal defence schemes, coastal developments, can change hydrological conditions. In particular, cross shore structures such as groynes and harbour arms can intercept flow paths, causing flows to divert around or across the structures [4892],[4893],[4894],[4873],[5075],[4960],[3125],[4961],[5199],[5200].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Physical loss (to land or freshwater habitat)
column5: Managed realignment is intended to bring about a change in land coverage.  Land will be lost through inundation by seawater.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: When sea defences (hard or soft) are removed this will result in inundation of land by seawater.  This will result in a change to the benthic environment. Existing benthic habitats may alter in composition due to alterations in the current or emergence regime.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: When sea defences (hard or soft) are removed this will result in inundation of land by seawater.  This will result in a change to the benthic environment. Existing benthic habitats may alter in composition due to alterations in the current or emergence regime.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: Shipping is an important source of underwater noise. Although the majority of this will come from the propeller cavitation, on-board machinery and turbulence around the hull can also result in noise being transmitted underwater. Different part of the vessel and different vessels emit at different frequencies. Generally, lower frequency with increasing size. Low frequency sounds generally travel farther and have the potential of impacting larger areas. The dredging of material will result in underwater noise similar to that generated in other marine operations such the use of sonars, seismic prospecting in the oil and gas industry, acoustic deterrents/harassing devices, turbine operation, piling, explosives, etc. [3804],[4921],[4995],[5173],[5172].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The pressure is potentially associated with construction, maintenance, operational lighting, plus navigation and operational lighting on vessels and structures. Lighting can cause disorientation or displace sensitive species. Lighted vessels and structures in open waters may pose a collision risk to many species of birds. Birds drawn to light may become disoriented and collide with these structures, which may result in injury and death. Light from vessels may also be of concern where significant levels of activity occur in close proximity to sensitive bird habitats including coastal inshore waters [3083],[3088],[3195],[2797],[3107],[4334],[4339].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column4: Collision ABOVE water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Pressure relates to vessels associated with this sub-activity and their movement. Marine birds are frequently attracted to or become disorientated by artificial light sources, which can result in collision and therefore injury or death [4399],[4378],[2826]. Bird collisions with vessels [2826], have been recorded with the risk being greatest at night for lighted ships near coastal areas and when the vessel is relatively close to large breeding aggregations of seabirds (rather than further offshore). However, there are relatively few sources of quantified information relating to seabird strikes on vessels. Nocturnal bird strikes on vessels tend to occur when bright, artificial light sources are used at times of poor visibility, typically during bad weather, often angled outwards or upwards from the vessel [4466],[4378].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.

column5: There are several sources of organic and nutrient enrichment in the marine environment: outflows of domestic/industrial origin, sludge, sediment resuspension, aquaculture food and faeces, and others. Sediment mobilisation during dredging or when  sea defences are removed can increase the levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145],[5121]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899],[2817].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. column4: Collision BELOW water with static or moving objects not naturally found in the marine environment (e.g., boats, machinery, and structures)
column5: Species can collide with the propeller or other parts of the hull causing collision injury or death. In general, the most lethal and serious injuries to mobile species such as marine mammals are caused by large ships (e.g. 80 m or longer) and vessels travelling at speeds faster than 14 knots. Most minor injuries, by contrast, involved collisions with vessels less than 45 m long. Collisions are rarely reported for vessels doing less than 10 km/hour [5120],[4987]. A lack of information exists regarding collision risk of animals (e.g. birds, fish, marine mammals) with underwater structures, especially for birds. The response of birds will depend on their detection of a device and any associated structures. The risk of collision may be increased if the devices alter the characteristics of the current, especially if such changes create new foraging opportunities, since this may impact on the manoeuvrability and underwater swimming agility of birds [4959],[5075]. Collision risks are most likely to pose the greatest risk in areas of strong water movement, such as areas of strong tidal flow or wave motion [3098].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.

column5: Noise arises from many activities in the marine environment which can evoke a disturbance response in marine mammals and birds [2825],[3269],[3227],[2074]. In relation to managed realignment the operation of vessels and vehicles used in coastal developments and flood defences [2817],[3085],[2838],[3136],[3153],[3154],[3132], as well as presence of people, may result in an increase in above water noise. However, the magnitude of the pressure will depend on the nature, scale, intensity and duration of the activity. Further, the impact of such disturbance on birds [3202] may be considered better captured by the pressure 'visual disturbance'.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Transition elements & organo-metal (e.g. TBT) contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: Pressure primarily relates to vessels associated with this sub-activity and their movement, but potentially also mobilisation of contaminated sediments. The primary chemicals of environmental concern in vessel oil and fuel are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures from ships are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled annually by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that lead to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Antifouling compounds like tributyltin (TBT; banned on vessels under 25 m in the UK since 1987, however) and copper wash from ship coatings enter and persist in the marine environment, with highest concentrations generally found in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3096],[3164],[3155],[2788],[3194],[4985].  Further, sediment disturbance by activities could result in the remobilisation of contaminants/substances [4481]. However, the likelihood and severity of any impact depends upon factors such as the type and degree of existing contamination, the sediment type and intensity of activity. In many cases, natural disturbance may contribute the majority of contaminated sediment resuspension [4482].

column4: Introduction of other substances (solid, liquid or gas)
column5: Some of the main pressures on the marine environment include operational and accidental discharges of chemicals, crude oil and produced water containing substances such as oil components, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, alkyl phenols and heavy metals [4941].

column5: There are several sources of organic and nutrient enrichment in the marine environment: outflows of domestic/industrial origin, sludge, sediment resuspension, aquaculture food and faeces, and others. Sediment mobilisation during dredging can increase the levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145],[5121]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899].  The extent of impacts is determined from the quantity and quality of the input and environmental conditions at the location [4939]. However, magnitude of pressure would depend on intensity/scale of activity and hydrographic conditions [2834],[3276],[3198],[4939]. Disposal of waste material into the marine environment includes the regulated discharge of wastewater and the disposal of hazardous and non-hazardous waste [4915].

column5: The pressure can result from a variety of activities including dredging, aquaculture, outflow, etc. [1441],[1436],[2834],[3096],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3163],[3186]. The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the dynamic nature of the area, the temperature and the sediment type, making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891] - the effect is most pronounced in the warmer summer months.

column4: Introduction or spread of invasive non-indigenous species (INIS)
column5: Aquatic organisms may be transferred to new locations as biofouling and can be harmful and invasive in locations where they do not naturally occur. All craft have some biofouling, even if recently cleaned or anti-fouled [4978],[5177]. Moreover, thousands of marine species can be carried in ships’ ballast water [3164].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity - including in relation to the size of the water body, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). More specifically, the risk of this pressure will increase where acoustic deterrents are deployed for prolonged periods of time in migratory channels for fish species.

column4: Habitat structure changes - removal of substratum (extraction)
column5: Maintenance works can require dredging/extraction, which results in the pressure [2838],[4890].
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Penetration and/or disturbance of the substrate below the surface of the seabed, including abrasion
column5:
Maintenance works can result in dredging/extraction, abrasion/disturbance to seabed, losses to land through increased reclaim or footprint of structures and physical changes to seabed through presence of new or additional materials/sediment [2817],[3085],[2838],[3115],[2004],[3153],[3154],[3161].
Anchors cause damage to the seabed upon deploying the anchor and the subsequent dragging and locking in and also through the chain causing abrasion and scour whilst at anchor and upon recovery. Anchors may penetrate to deep depths in softer sediment as the opening of the anchor flukes prevents deep penetration in harder sediment [5076].

column5: Noise can arise from many activities in the marine environment. The use of machinery, vessels, explosives, people will result in an increase of above water noise. Some examples of sources of airborne noise are drilling rigs and support [3111],[3149], vessels used to service aquaculture facilities [2834],[3151],  vessels used in coastal developments and flood defences [2817],[3085],[2838],[3136],[3153],[3154],[3132], military activities, aggregate extraction [3152], cabling operations [3158],[3164], piling [1329],[3082], etc. However, the magnitude of pressure would depend on the scale, intensity and duration of the activity.

column5: The pressure relates to the vibration produced by certain activities and does not include vessels as it assumed not to be significant. Activities resulting in vibration are for example trenching for cable laying [3804], dredging as the draghead is carried over the seabed or grab is operated [3804]; military activities and other developments involving explosives [3144], oil and gas drilling [3111],[3149], and activities involving piling (especially if vibropiling is used) [3078],[3128],[3154].

column4: Hydrocarbon & PAH contamination.  Includes those priority substances listed in Annex II of Directive 2008/105/EC.
column5: The primary chemicals of environmental concern in oil and fuel incidents are polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Deliberate discharges of oil or oil/water mixtures are prohibited within the North West European Waters Special Area, established by the International Maritime Organization under MARPOL Annex I in 1999. This includes all waters around the UK and its approaches. However, accidental discharges still occur. Information on accidental discharges of oil from ships and offshore platforms is compiled by the Advisory Committee on Protection of the Sea (ACOPS) on behalf of the Maritime and Coastguard Agency each year. Although the majority of incidents are minor, several incidents occur annually that have led to the actual or potential release of significant amounts of oil (typically from large shipping vessels and tankers). Moreover, antifouling compounds like TBT and copper wash from coatings with larger concentrations in heavily used shipping routes or within harbours [3032],[3096],[3107],[3164],[4333],[4985].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column4: Introduction of other substances (solid, liquid or gas)
column5: Some of the main pressures on the marine environment from oil and gas activities include operational and accidental discharges of chemicals, crude oil and produced water containing substances such as oil components, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, alkyl phenols and heavy metals [4941].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase as a result of non-compliance to legislation, codes of conduct or best practice (see Activity-Pressure justification text).
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: There are several sources of organic and nutrient enrichment in the marine environment: outflows of domestic/industrial origin, sludge, sediment resuspension, aquaculture food and faeces, and others. Sediment mobilisation during dredging can increase the levels of organic matter and nutrients [3145],[5121]; however, the effect is usually highly restricted in time and space [4899].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
column8: The associated evidence follows NE's evidence standards, particularly for "Analysis of Evidence" (NESTND024) and "Conservation Advice for MPAs" (NESTND036). See here for more information: http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/category/3769710

column5: The pressure is associated with sediment mobilisation and increased of suspended sediments as well as the deposition of organic matter. The pressure can result from a variety of activities including dredging, aquaculture, outflow, etc [1441],[1436],[2834],[3096],[3153],[3154],[3161],[3163],[3186]. The extent and nature of the changes will depend on the dynamic nature of the area, the temperature and the sediment type, making changes in many cases short lived and localised [4891].
column7: The risk of this pressure will increase depending on the spatial/ temporal scale and intensity of the activity, the proximity of the activity to the feature (in space and time) and the sensitivity of the feature to the pressure. Cumulative and in-combination effects of activities may increase the risk further (see Activity-Pressure justification text). High levels of discarding associated with the fishing activity combined with low flow conditions may increase the magnitude of this pressure.
